text.content:
It is less a village than a wound. Perhaps two hundred souls cling to existence here in hab-blocks of local grey stone, huddled together as if for warmth that never comes. The buildings lean against one another like drunks, their rockcrete foundations cracked, their windows shuttered and dark. The streets are unpaved mud, rutted by cart tracks and pooled with standing water that reflects a sky the colour of a bruise. Nothing moves. Nothing speaks. But you are watched — you feel it in the prickling of your skin, in the way the shutters on every window are cracked just enough for a pair of eyes. The village is not empty. It is terrified.

Key Facts

PropertyDetail
ActAct I — Descent into the Rift
Map ReferenceMap 1 (40x30 settlement map)
Population / Status~200 souls, feudal agri-settlement, terrified and dying under centuries of Strahd's rule
Primary ThreatPsychological — crushed populace, nightly warp-creature assaults on the Burgomaster's manor, Doru the warp-thrall beneath the chapel
Quest HooksBurgomaster's funeral, escort Ireena to Fortress Vallak, investigate the chapel basement (Doru), meet the Vostra scouts, receive Strahd's letter

The First Settlement

The Village of Barovus is the Acolytes' first encounter with civilisation on the surface of this cursed world. After the harrowing crash of the Vessel of Lament and the disorienting march through warp-fog, the village emerges from the grey like a half-remembered nightmare of Imperial order gone to rot. It is a place where the Aquila still stands above the chapel door, but its wings are tarnished and its meaning has been hollowed out by three centuries of isolation and despair.

The village serves a critical narrative function: it grounds the Acolytes in the reality of Barovus. The Vessel of Lament was a contained horror — a dungeon with walls. The village is an open wound, a community of real people who have lived under Strahd's dominion for generations and been broken by it. Every interaction here should reinforce the campaign's central themes: the erosion of faith, the corruption of authority, and the terrible cost of isolation from the Emperor's light. The villagers are not enemies — they are victims, and the Acolytes' response to their suffering will define the moral tone of the entire campaign.

Mechanically, the village is a resupply point (limited), a social hub, and the launching point for the escort mission to Fortress Vallak that drives Act II. The Acolytes should leave Barovus with Ireena in tow, the weight of Strahd's letter in their pockets, and the grim understanding that the Lord-Governor knows exactly where they are and what they intend to do about it.

Village Layout

The village is arranged around a central muddy square with four key structures and roughly twenty hab-blocks of grey stone housing the terrified populace. Roads lead north toward the Zarovich Spire and west toward Fortress Vallak. Ancient vox-casters mounted on poles throughout the village crackle to life at irregular intervals, broadcasting proclamations from Strahd. Half-functional propaganda servitors patrol the streets in pairs, their vox-grilles broadcasting loyalty oaths and their ocular sensors recording everything.

The Burgomaster's Manor

The Burgomaster's Manor is a two-storey stone structure that was once the finest building in the village. Its windows are boarded. Its doors are barricaded from the inside. Claw marks — deep, deliberate, and far too large to be human — score the exterior walls. The front garden is dead, and the iron fence that surrounds the property is bent inward in several places, as though something tried very hard to get in.

Inside, the manor is dim and claustrophobic, every window blocked, every entrance reinforced with furniture and scrap metal. The Burgomaster's body lies in an upper room, and Ireena Kolyana will not open the door unless Ismark vouches for the Acolytes. The barricades show weeks of desperate, improvised reinforcement — testament to the nightly assaults by Strahd's creatures that ultimately killed Kolyan Indirovich through sheer accumulated terror.

The Chapel of the God-Emperor

The Chapel is the only building the villagers maintain, though "maintain" is generous — the roof leaks, the pews are cracked, and the devotional murals have faded to ghosts. It is structurally sound and spiritually significant. A faint aura of sanctity clings to it, the last ember of faith in a world drowning in despair.

Father Donavich tends the chapel. He is a broken man — robes filthy, eyes red-rimmed and unfocused, hands trembling. Beneath the chapel floor, accessible by a trap door behind the altar, is the basement where his son Doru is chained. The sounds of scratching and a distorted voice moaning "Father..." can be heard during quiet moments, particularly during the funeral rites. The basement is a small root cellar reeking of warp corruption and human waste — and in the far corner, illuminated by a single sputtering candle, crouches what remains of a boy who wanted to be a hero.

The Blood of the Vein

The Blood of the Vein is the village tavern. Its interior is dim, its ale is thin, and its proprietor — Arik — serves drinks with the mechanical emptiness of a servitor. He responds to direct questions with monosyllables and stares at nothing. Three Vostra travellers sit in the corner: Ratka, Sorva, and Emilian — scouts from Madam Eva's camp, colourfully dressed, adorned with charms and fetishes, and utterly unconcerned by the gloom. They will offer cryptic warnings and directions to the Vostra camp if approached.

Bildrath's General Store

Bildrath's Provisions is run by Bildrath, a bitter, suspicious man who sells basic supplies at extortionate prices (300% markup). His stock is pathetic — a few candles, some rope, dried rations of uncertain provenance, and a single battered lasgun power pack. He has a massive, silent bodyguard named Parriwimple (Ogryn ancestry, clearly) who stands behind the counter and stares.

Village Square

The central square is little more than a patch of churned mud where the roads converge. The vox-casters are loudest here, and the propaganda servitors make regular circuits. This is where the funeral procession passes and where Strahd's servitor delivers his letter of welcome. At night, the square is deserted — every villager bolts their doors before dark, and nothing the Acolytes say will convince them otherwise.

Key NPCs

Ismark Kolyanovich

Ismark finds the Acolytes shortly after their arrival. He is a tall, broad-shouldered man in his early thirties, wearing the battered remnants of an Imperial Guard uniform (Barovian 12th Infantry — a regiment that existed three centuries ago). He carries a chainsword — old, well-maintained, clearly cherished — and moves with a soldier's discipline. His eyes are haunted.

Disposition: Honest, brave, and deeply frightened. Desperate for help but not pathetic — he carries himself with the bearing of a soldier who knows the odds and fights anyway.

Motivation: Protect his sister Ireena. Get her to Fortress Vallak, where walls and a garrison might slow Strahd's pursuit. He cannot do this alone.

Key Dialogue:

"You are offworlders. I can see it — the way you walk, the way you look at things, like you expect the world to make sense. It doesn't. Not here. Not for a long time."

"My father was the Burgomaster. He is dead. Strahd's creatures killed him — not with claws, but with fear. Weeks of it. They came every night, howling and scratching, and my father stood at the door with his pistol and his prayers, and each night he aged a year."

Social Tests: Responds well to honest, direct communication. Charm (Ordinary +10) or Command (Routine +20) earns his trust and full cooperation. Intimidation makes him defensive but compliant — he is too desperate to refuse help.

Ireena Kolyana

Ireena is inside the Burgomaster's manor, behind the barricades. She is mid-twenties, dark hair, pale angular face, striking violet eyes that shift and shimmer. She wears a worn bodyglove under a heavy coat and carries a laspistol with recent-use familiarity. Two circular, puckered wounds mar the skin of her throat — Strahd's bite marks, radiating faint psychic energy.

Disposition: Frightened but fierce. She will not suffer pity or condescension.

Motivation: Bury her father with proper rites before leaving. She refuses to depart until the funeral is complete.

Key Dialogue:

"If you have come to gawk at the Lord-Governor's prey, you may leave. If you have come to help, then help. My father needs to be buried before nightfall."

Secret: She is an emerging psyker — untrained, unregistered — experiencing objects moving when emotional, candle flames bending toward her, whispers others do not hear. A Psyniscience Test (Challenging +0) reveals her latent ability. She has told no one.

Father Donavich

Father Donavich performs the Burgomaster's funeral rites in a hollow monotone. He is a broken man — filthy robes, red-rimmed unfocused eyes, trembling hands. His faith is shattered by the horror chained beneath his own chapel.

Motivation: He prays constantly over his mutated son Doru, hoping for a cure that will never come. He will resist any attempt to enter the basement but can be convinced with compassion.

Doru

Doru is Donavich's son, chained in the chapel basement. He led a doomed assault on the Zarovich Spire months ago. Strahd slaughtered the attackers and sent Doru back changed — a warp-touched mutant with limbs too long, joints bending wrong, skin the colour of a bruise. His eyes remain human and aware and begging.

Key Dialogue:

"Kill me. Please. Emperor. Kill me."

Combat Profile: Use Mutant profile (DH core), Fear Rating 1, plus Regeneration (1), Unnatural Strength x2, and a psychic despair aura (all within 10m must pass Willpower, Challenging +0, or suffer -10 to all tests for 1d5 rounds). Killing him is an act of mercy.

Minor NPCs

Arik (barkeep) — hollow-eyed, monosyllabic, severe long-term psychological trauma. Functional but barely present.

Bildrath (merchant) — bitter, suspicious, 300% markup. Accompanied by Parriwimple, his Ogryn-ancestry bodyguard.

Ratka, Sorva, Emilian (Vostra scouts) — colourful, warp-touched traders in the tavern. Offer cryptic warnings: "The Lord of the Spire sees all, but he is blind to what the cards reveal." They provide directions to the Vostra camp.

Encounters

The Funeral Procession: Carrying the Burgomaster's body from the manor to the chapel. No villagers will assist — the Acolytes and Ismark must bear the coffin themselves. The procession is sombre and exposed. Strahd may observe from the fog but does not intervene.

Strahd's Letter: A lone, elegant servitor in formal livery approaches the most senior-looking Acolyte, extending a silver tray bearing a sealed envelope with an ornate "S" pressed into black wax. The letter is civil, warm, and absolutely menacing — Strahd knows their names, their mission, their location, and their connection to Ireena.

Nightly Assaults (if the Acolytes remain after dark): Warp-hounds and servitor-soldiers probe the manor's defences. These are not full combat encounters but atmospheric events — howling, scratching, shapes in the fog — designed to demonstrate why Kolyan Indirovich died of fear.

Skill Tests

Corruption and Insanity Triggers

Loot and Items of Interest

  • Bildrath's Store: Candles, rope, dried rations (all at 300% markup), single battered lasgun power pack.
  • Data-slate from the road corpse: Repeating log entry: "Do not go to the village. Do not trust the children. Do not enter the ship." Dated 237 years ago.
  • Vessel of Lament crash salvage: Data-slate with Captain Durst's records (+10 to Common Lore (Barovus) tests), sanctified mono-knife (Best-Quality with Sanctified quality), 2 doses of de-tox, single frag grenade.
  • Kolyan Indirovich's letter: Found on/near the Burgomaster's body (Handout 3). Documents weeks of siege and desperate pleas for aid.
  • Strahd's letter of welcome: Delivered by servitor (Handout 2). Establishes that Strahd knows everything about the Acolytes.

Quest Connections

  • Main Plot — Ireena: The escort mission to Fortress Vallak is the primary thread driving the Acolytes into Act II. Ireena will not leave until her father is buried.
  • Main Plot — Strahd: His letter and first encounter establish him as omniscient antagonist. His interest in Ireena (calling her "Tatyana") hints at the reincarnation cycle central to the story.
  • Relics — Blessed Ammunition: Father Donavich can perform blessings on bolt ammunition if restored to sanity — requires resolving Doru's situation with compassion.
  • Side Quest — Vostra Camp: The three Vostra scouts in the tavern direct Acolytes to Madam Eva for the Emperor's Tarot reading (Chapter 4).
  • Side Quest — Doru: Killing or freeing Doru is an act of mercy that affects Donavich's willingness to assist and his ability to bless ammunition.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd is omnipresent but rarely seen in the village. His influence manifests through:

  • Vox-caster broadcasts: Smooth, cultured voice delivering proclamations, tithe reminders, curfew warnings, and personal messages designed to torment specific villagers.
  • Propaganda servitors: Shambling pairs broadcasting loyalty oaths and recording everything with ocular sensors. Not combat-capable but serve as Strahd's eyes and ears.
  • The letter: Delivered at a dramatically appropriate moment. Demonstrates total awareness of the Acolytes' identities, mission, and connection to Ireena.
  • First direct encounter: Triggered at the GM's discretion (on the road, during the funeral, leaving the Vostra camp, or during the first night). This is a narrative encounter — Strahd cannot be defeated. Any attack is effortlessly deflected. He demonstrates absolute power, expresses delighted interest, and departs on his own terms.
  • Nightly probing: If Acolytes stay in the village, warp-creatures test the manor's defences after dark — atmospheric, not mechanical combat.

Encounter Guide

The Village of Barovus is the Acolytes' first settlement after the crash of the Vessel of Lament. It is a place of quiet desperation — ~200 souls ground into learned helplessness by centuries of Strahd's rule. Every interaction should reinforce isolation and urgency. The Acolytes should leave wanting to escape this place as badly as its inhabitants do.

The Approach Road

RiskTranquil
TypeDiscovery

Discoveries: This is Lost Expedition Site 1: The Pilgrim's Bones — the first expedition to Barovus, approximately 280 years ago. A Ministorum missionary party. A skeleton in Ministorum robes has been crucified against a road marker — ancient, centuries old. On the corpse: a sanctified rosary (grants +5 to one WP test vs warp entities, then crumbles to dust) and a sealed parchment containing a prayer that trails off mid-word.

Sealed Parchment: "Most Holy God-Emperor, Sovereign of Mankind, Light Eternal upon the Throne of Terra — I commend my soul unto Your keeping. We came to this world bearing Your word and Your mercy. We found neither welcome nor salvation. The fog has a voice. It speaks our names. Brother Castiel is gone — taken in the night, his screams swallowed by the grey. I alone remain. I write this prayer as the last act of a faithful servant. I beg You, Lord, deliver me from this — I beg You — I"

Corruption/Insanity: 1 IP (first evidence that others came before and failed).

GM Notes: This is emotional setup, not mechanical challenge. Do not rush it. Let the players absorb the implications — someone from the Imperium came here centuries ago, with faith and purpose, and died nailed to a signpost. The rosary is a small gift and a grim omen. Let silence do the work.

Burgomaster's Manor

RiskTense
TypeSocial, Discovery

Social: Meeting Ireena and Ismark. Ismark seeks out the Acolytes — in the tavern, on the street, or at the manor itself. He needs convincing to trust them fully: Charm (Ordinary +10) or presenting Inquisitorial credentials (automatic success). Command (Routine +20) also works — he responds to authority and directness. Intimidate makes him defensive but compliant; he is too desperate to refuse. Ireena will not open the manor door unless Ismark vouches for the Acolytes. She is traumatised but resolute — fierce, not fragile.

Discoveries: The manor exterior bears deep claw marks far too large to be human. Windows are boarded and barricaded from inside. The iron fence is bent inward. Inside: the dead Burgomaster, Kolyan Indirovich — heart failure after weeks of nightly siege. A search of the manor reveals Strahd's letter (Handout 2) and the Burgomaster's personal journal documenting weeks of escalating nightly assaults. Awareness or Medicae (Challenging +0) on Ireena's throat marks reveals they radiate faint psychic energy — Strahd is draining life force through warp-touch, not conventional means. A Psyniscience (Challenging +0) test reveals Ireena is an emerging, untrained psyker.

Corruption/Insanity: None unless Strahd's letter is read aloud (1 CP from warp-resonance in the words).

GM Notes: This is where the escort quest begins. Push Ismark's desperation — he is brave but cannot protect Ireena alone on the road to Fortress Vallak. Ireena will not leave until her father receives proper funeral rites. The psychic revelation about Ireena should be kept quiet if only one Acolyte detects it — it is a slow-burn plot thread, not an immediate crisis.

Chapel of the God-Emperor

RiskTense / Dangerous
TypeFaith Test, Combat, Discovery

Faith Test: The chapel is desecrated — a faint aura of sanctity remains, but it is guttering. Forbidden Lore (Imperial Creed) (Ordinary +10) or Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Challenging +0) identifies the nature of the desecration. Attempting to pray here: Willpower (Hard -20) — success grants 1d5 temporary IP reduction; failure causes 1d5 IP from psychic backlash as corrupted warp energy rebounds through the weakened sanctity.

Enemies: Father Donavich guards the basement trapdoor behind the altar. If the Acolytes descend, they find Doru — his son, returned from a failed assault on the Zarovich Spire as a warp-touched mutant. 1 Warp-Thrall (Mutant profile, Dangerous threat; Fear 1, Regeneration 1, Unnatural Strength x2, psychic despair aura — all within 10m must pass Willpower (Challenging +0) or suffer -10 to all tests for 1d5 rounds). Scaling: Doru is a solo encounter designed for emotional impact. For 6+, add 1 Plague Revenant companion chained nearby.

Discoveries: Donavich's behaviour during the funeral — trembling hands, hollow monotone, filthy robes. Perception or Awareness (Ordinary +10) during the funeral reveals rhythmic scraping from beneath the chapel floor and a distorted voice moaning "Father..." repeatedly. Doru still remembers his father's name. He begs for death. He was once a would-be hero.

Corruption/Insanity: 1d5 IP and 1 CP for descending to the basement and witnessing Doru's state. 1 additional CP if Doru is destroyed in front of Donavich.

GM Notes: This is a tragedy, not a dungeon. Donavich is broken beyond repair. Doru is pitiable, not evil — killing him is mercy. If the Acolytes handle the situation with compassion, Donavich is ultimately grateful. Play the human cost. Doru's eyes are still human and aware. That is the worst part.

Blood of the Vein Tavern

RiskTranquil
TypeSocial, Investigation

Social: The tavern is dim, the ale is thin, and proprietor Arik is a hollow-eyed man functioning on autopilot (Medicae or Awareness (Ordinary +10) confirms severe long-term psychological trauma). Three Vostra scouts — Ratka, Sorva, and Emilian — drink in the corner. They are colourfully dressed, adorned with charms, and utterly unconcerned by the village's gloom. Charm (Challenging +0) or buying drinks (Charm gains +20 bonus) loosens their tongues. They offer cryptic warnings about Strahd, directions to the Vostra camp, and rumours about Madam Eva's Tarot readings.

Discoveries: Overhear rumours about Fortress Vallak, the "mad Burgomaster" Vallakovich, and the Vostra camp. Local rotgut available (recaf substitute; -5 to BS for 1d5 hours but +5 to social tests). Behind the bar: scratched tally marks — over 112,000 of them. A Logic (Routine +20) test or simple arithmetic reveals this is approximately 307 years of daily marks.

GM Notes: This is an information hub. Seed 2-3 hooks for Act 2 locations through the Vostra scouts and overheard rumours. The tally marks are a gut-punch if anyone does the maths — let the players work it out themselves. Do not explain it for them.

Bildrath's Store

RiskTranquil
TypeSocial

Social: Bildrath is bitter and suspicious. He charges 10x standard prices (300% markup on everything). Commerce (Hard -20) or Intimidate (Challenging +0) to negotiate prices down. Warning: Intimidate provokes Parriwimple, his nephew — an ogryn-sized simpleton who is fiercely protective of his uncle. Parriwimple is not hostile unless provoked but is a serious physical threat if angered.

Discoveries: Limited Imperial-standard supplies — mostly local equivalents. Stock includes candles, rope, dried rations of uncertain provenance, and a single battered lasgun power pack. 1 clip of autopistol ammunition is available at 25x standard price (incredibly rare on Barovus).

GM Notes: Establish the scarcity economy early. This is the worst deal the Acolytes will find in Barovus — but it may be the only option until they reach Fortress Vallak. Do not let them bully Bildrath without consequence; Parriwimple is the consequence.

Village Square

RiskTense
TypeEnvironmental, Social

Environmental: The Burgomaster's funeral procession crosses the square — rain, warp-fog creeping at the edges, villagers watching from behind shuttered windows but refusing to participate. At night: howling from the woods. If Ireena remains in the manor, nightly assaults occur — warp-hounds, servitor-soldiers, and worse scratch at walls and howl outside. Propaganda servitors patrol the streets in pairs, broadcasting loyalty oaths and recording everything through ocular sensors. Ancient vox-casters crackle to life at irregular intervals with Strahd's proclamations.

Social: At the GM's chosen moment (ideally after the funeral), an elegant servitor in formal livery approaches the most senior-looking Acolyte and delivers Strahd's letter on a silver tray. The letter is civil, warm, and laced with pure menace — Strahd knows their names, mission, location, and connection to Ireena. Public reading of the letter causes 1 CP to all listeners from warp-resonance.

Discoveries: Nightly attack patterns — assaults focus on the manor while Ireena is present. Once she leaves, the village gets one night of peace, then attacks resume anyway. This is Strahd's cruelty made manifest: the suffering was never about Ireena alone.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP from Strahd's letter (if read or heard). 1 IP from witnessing the nightly assault (screaming, scratching at walls, inhuman howling).

GM Notes: Build urgency to leave. Every night the Acolytes stay risks another assault. The letter should feel like a violation — Strahd knows everything, has always known, and wants them to know that he knows. The postscript about Ireena is the knife twist.

The airlock opens onto a boarding deck that should not exist on a vessel this size — it is cavernous, vaulted, its ceiling lost in shadow. The deck plates are Imperial standard, but warped and buckled by centuries of neglect and something worse — a faint organic sheen coats every surface, like condensation, though it is warm to the touch. Emergency lumens flicker along the bulkheads, casting a sickly amber glow. The ship's name is stencilled on the far bulkhead in faded Imperial script: DURST'S LAMENT. Standing in the centre of the boarding deck are two children — a boy and a girl, dressed in once-fine clothing now grey with age. The girl clutches a doll. The boy holds his sister's hand. They look up at you with eyes that hold a terror too large for their small faces.

Key Facts

PropertyDetail
ActAct I — Descent into the Rift (Chapter 2)
Map ReferenceMap 2 (3 deck levels, each approx. 40x25 grid)
Population / StatusDerelict for ~200 years; no living crew. Ghost-children Rose and Thorn Durst; stasis survivor Vasily Hent (hidden chamber); warp-echo specters throughout
Primary ThreatThe Lament Configuration — Lesser Daemon of Slaanesh fused to the ship's warp drive (3-phase boss encounter). Environmental hazards, traps, and aggressive Corruption/Insanity accumulation
Quest HooksDestroy the altar-engine daemon, free the ghost-children, rescue Vasily Hent, recover navigation data and sanctified items, survive the crash landing on Barovus

The Introductory Dungeon

The Vessel of Lament is the campaign's tutorial dungeon — a cursed warp ship that serves as both the introductory scenario and the mechanism that delivers the Acolytes to Barovus. It is the former command of Captain Gustav Durst, an Imperial transport captain whose family fell to Slaaneshi worship generations ago while the ship drifted in the warp anomaly. The ship is now a warp-saturated trap — a lure that draws in travellers and feeds on their suffering. It has been drifting at the edge of the anomaly for centuries, broadcasting its distress signal, waiting.

The vessel contains 22 rooms across 3 decks, mixing [CRITICAL PATH] rooms essential for narrative progression with [OPTIONAL] rooms that reward thorough exploration with useful items, lore, and atmospheric horror. The environmental design follows a deliberate corruption gradient: the Upper Deck is cold Imperial metal with subtle wrongness; the Mid Deck transitions to organic sheen and Slaaneshi excess; the Lower Deck is fully corrupted flesh-and-machine hybrid where the boundary between ship and living organism has dissolved entirely.

The dungeon teaches five critical lessons that define the campaign: the warp is everywhere and Corruption/Insanity Points are a constant cost; investigation is as important as combat; not everything can be fought; faith has tangible mechanical power; and mercy and horror coexist — the ghost-children are victims, not enemies. The Vessel of Lament should take one to two full sessions to complete.

Boarding Deck

The airlock opens into a cavernous, vaulted boarding deck — too large for a transport vessel of this class, reshaped by warp influence. The ship's name DURST'S LAMENT is stencilled on the far bulkhead. Devotional aquilas line the walls, cracked and subtly wrong. Gargoyle-headed vox-casters crouch at junction points. The ghost-children Rose and Thorn Durst appear here, begging for help against "the monster in the lower decks." If Acolytes attempt retreat, the airlock seals and corridors rearrange — the ship is the only option.

Upper Deck (7 Rooms)

UD1 — Main Corridor [CRITICAL PATH]

A grand central corridor with chequered dark iron and tarnished brass deck plates. Trophy cases display six-legged Barovian predators in cracked stasis jars. Portraits line both walls — formal Durst family pict-captures that change when not directly observed (faces rot, smiles widen to rictus grins). Willpower (Ordinary +10) on first noticing; failure: 1 Insanity Point. Slaaneshi corruption detectable with Forbidden Lore (Chaos), Challenging +0.

UD2 — Officer's Mess [CRITICAL PATH]

A long table set for a meal that appears freshly prepared — but watching it causes the food to rot in real time. Consuming any food: Toughness (Challenging +0) or 1d5 Wounds (ignoring armour) and nausea for 1d10 rounds.

UD3 — The Captain's Quarters [CRITICAL PATH]

The most important upper deck room. Data-slate racks and bookshelves fill every wall. Search (Ordinary +10) reveals Captain Gustav Durst's journal behind a false bulkhead — documenting the crew's 15-year descent into Slaaneshi heresy, the rituals, and the children's deaths ("We forgot them"). Reading in full: 1d5 Insanity Points, 1 Corruption Point, but grants +20 to subsequent Forbidden Lore (Chaos) tests on the vessel. Also contains the wedding date 14.08.37 — the armory cipher code.

UD4 — Crew Mess and Galley [CRITICAL PATH]

Largely unremarkable. Search (Challenging +0) yields expired ration packs and an ancient laspistol with 1 shot. Adjoining crew quarters show signs of hasty abandonment — bloodstains forming near-Chaos sigils.

UD5 — Bridge / Command Deck [OPTIONAL]

Sealed blast door (manual release). Three points of interest: Navigation Cogitators (Tech-Use, Challenging +0 — success grants +10 to Navigate (Surface) on Barovus for the campaign; failure by 3+ degrees: corrupted data-burst, 1 IP). Navigator's Corpse (death-grip reflex on touch — opposed Strength to break free; failure: 1d5 IP, 1 CP, but insight that the anomaly has an edge). Captain's final log (audio recording of the crash toward Barovus — narrative only).

UD6 — Armory / Ship's Locker [OPTIONAL]

Cipher-locked (code 14.08.37 from journal, or Common Lore/Scholastic Lore (Imperial Navy), Ordinary +10, or Security, Hard -20 brute force). Booby trap if forced: concealed shotgun mechanism (1d10+4 I, Pen 0, Scatter). Detect: Awareness (Challenging +0); Disarm: Security (Ordinary +10). Contents: Best-Quality autopistol (18 rounds), Best-Quality balanced boarding cutlass, 2 frag grenades.

UD7 — Astropath's Chamber [OPTIONAL]

A sanctified pocket — corruption stops at the threshold. Clean air, warm like remembered sunlight. The Astropath's skeleton sits in peaceful meditation. Sanctuary Effect: 10 minutes rest removes 1 Insanity Point (once per Acolyte). Psychic Echo (Psyniscience, Challenging +0): fragmentary message — "the children are the key... the entity fears what it consumed... the altar is the chain" — speaking the children's names during the boss fight grants +10 to Willpower Tests. Sending-Stone: grants +20 to attacks against the altar-engine; disrupts Phase 2 effects; crumbles after use.

Mid Deck (8 Rooms)

MD1 — Captain's Private Chambers [CRITICAL PATH]

Oppressively lavish — silks, perfumes, mirrors covering every surface. Mirrors show the compartment in its prime, populated by beautiful figures who are watching the Acolytes. Awareness (Ordinary +10) to notice; Willpower (Challenging +0) or 1 IP. Locked jewellery box (Security, Ordinary +10): cameo locket of Elisabeth Durst, precious stones (~200 Thrones).

MD2 — The Children's Cabin [CRITICAL PATH]

Two small beds, children's drawings, toy box. Freezing cold — breath mists. If Acolytes linger, Rose and Thorn manifest on their beds. Rose recounts their death: sealed in by parents who never returned. Willpower (Challenging +0) or 1d5 Insanity Points. The children beg the Acolytes to destroy the monster below "so we can sleep."

MD3 — Hidden Shrine [OPTIONAL]

Concealed hatch (Search, Difficult -10, or Awareness, Hard -20). Eight-pointed star inlaid in the deck, black tallow candles, blood-and-obscura offerings. 1 Corruption Point on entry (automatic), +1 CP per 10 additional minutes. Palpable Slaaneshi aura (auto-detect with Psyniscience).

MD4 — Sealed Storage Bay [CRITICAL PATH]

Contains Elisabeth Durst's preserved corpse and her sealed letter confessing to the family's damnation, the entity fused to the warp drive, and the children's fate. The letter inflicts 1 Insanity Point and provides critical context. Logic or Scholastic Lore (Occult), Ordinary +10 to piece together the full picture.

MD5 — Medicae Bay [OPTIONAL]

Warp-echo of Elisabeth Durst performing ritual vivisection plays automatically: 1 Insanity Point (no save). Search (Ordinary +10): 2 doses of de-tox, 1 stimm. Mimic-Cabinet Trap: fleshy tendrils grapple (Strength 40, 1d10+2 R/round, 12 Wounds, vulnerable to fire). Detect: Awareness (Challenging +0).

MD6 — Crew Quarters (Main) [OPTIONAL]

Vasily Hent's journal in a foot-locker: grants +10 to Fellowship Tests with ghost-children, and reveals power conduit sequence (red-blue-green) for MD7. Sleeping Gas Trap: pressure plate releases soporific gas; Toughness (Challenging +0) or 2 levels of Fatigue. Detect: Awareness (Challenging +0); disarm: Security (Ordinary +10).

MD7 — Enginarium Access Corridor [OPTIONAL]

Alternative route to lower decks. Complete darkness. Power Routing Puzzle: red-blue-green sequence restores lower deck lumens (removes darkness penalties, boss loses concealment attacks). Wrong sequence (1st): 1d10 E damage to all in corridor. Wrong (2nd): permanent failure, mid deck lighting becomes intermittent.

MD8 — Cargo Hold [OPTIONAL]

Slaaneshi tribute cache: silk, perfume, jewellery, ~200 Thrones. Taking items: 1 Corruption Point/day while carried; Willpower (Ordinary +10) daily to voluntarily discard. Sanctified Incense Censer (hidden in corner): 3 charges, each creates 5m radius sanctified zone for 10 minutes (+10 to Willpower Tests vs. warp phenomena, fear, psychic attacks). Significant find.

Lower Deck — Engineering (7 Rooms)

Descent: Hidden behind data-slate rack in captain's quarters (Search, Challenging +0). Service ladder into absolute darkness. The vessel transitions from machine to living organism — bulkheads glisten with flesh-warmth, ladder rungs are slick with copper-and-perfume moisture. All Acolytes gain 1 Corruption Point upon entering the lower decks.

LD1 — The Brig [CRITICAL PATH]

Corridor lined with brig cells. Two cells still hold skeletal remains showing ritual mutilation (Medicae, Ordinary +10 to identify Slaaneshi practices). 1 Insanity Point for close examination.

LD2 — Engineering Antechamber [CRITICAL PATH]

Metal benches, a lectern with a Chaos liturgy book. Reading the book: Willpower (Hard -20) to put it down; reading more than a few pages: 1d10 Insanity Points, 1d5 Corruption Points. With Forbidden Lore (Chaos): safe skim (1 CP only), learn the cult summoned a daemon bound to the warp drive.

LD3 — The Warp Drive Chamber [CRITICAL PATH]

The boss arena. Cathedral-vaulted engineering bay with bone-and-metal mosaic forming an eight-pointed star. The corrupted altar-engine — fused bone, black iron, engine components — pulses at the centre. See Boss Fight page for full encounter details.

LD4 — Congregation Hall [OPTIONAL]

Warp-expanded cathedral space (4x the volume the ship's schematics allow). Bone-and-metal pews, murals depicting the Durst family's fall in five panels. 1d5+2 warp-echo worshippers (non-hostile, can be dispersed by prayer or sanctified items). Studying murals: 1 Corruption Point. Peaceful dispersal of all echoes: each Acolyte regains 1 Fatigue.

LD5 — Sacrificial Preparation Chamber [OPTIONAL]

Charnel house — blood-layered bulkheads, restraint slab, instrument rack, clogged drain. Enter: Willpower (Hard -20) or 1d5 Insanity Points. Ritual Knife: Best-Quality knife (+5 damage), but 1 CP/day carried and Willpower (Challenging +0) to put down; glows near warp entities. Victim's Escape Map: scratched under slab — automatic Navigate success in lower decks, marks LD6. Pit Trap: drainage grate collapses; Awareness (Challenging +0) to detect; 1d10 I damage, Agility (Challenging +0) to climb out.

LD6 — Engine Crawlspace [OPTIONAL]

Flanking route to LD3. Narrow, dark, hot (1d5 E per 10 minutes without protection). Navigation: victim's map = auto-success, or Navigate (Surface), Challenging +0. All combat at -20 WS/BS, no two-handed weapons. Tactical Reward: emerging behind the altar-engine grants a surprise round with +20 to hit on the first round.

LD7 — Heart of the Vessel (Hidden Chamber) [OPTIONAL]

Concealed behind a bulkhead panel visible only after the altar-engine is destroyed/damaged. Clean, cold, intact — preserved by residual Gellar field. Gellar Field Modulator: single-use, creates 10m warp-ward for 8 hours (+20 to Corruption Tests, warp-touched at -10 to all Characteristics). Extraordinarily valuable for Barovus. Stasis Pod: contains Vasily Hent (Enginseer's Mate), alive after 200 years. Tech-Use (Ordinary +10) to revive. Potential NPC ally or replacement character. Gains 2d10 IP on revival; Willpower (Hard -20) or breakdown for 1d10 rounds.

Key NPCs

Rose and Thorn Durst (Ghost-Children)

Rose (approximately ten years old) and Thorn (approximately six) are warp-echoes — psychic imprints of children who died on this vessel over two centuries ago, locked in their cabin by parents who "forgot" them. They appear as living, breathing children, not obviously spectral.

Disposition: Terrified, desperate, pitiable. They are not malicious but are compelled by the ship's lure to draw victims deeper inside.

Detection: Awareness (Hard -20): they cast no shadows, their breath produces no mist, their feet do not quite touch the deck plates. Psyniscience (Challenging +0): warp-echoes, not true spirits.

Key Dialogue:

"Please. There is a monster in our ship. In the lower decks. Our parents won't wake up. Please help us."

"We died here. Mother and Father sealed the hatch. They said it was to keep us safe from the monster. But they never came back. We waited. We were so hungry. Thorn cried. Then Thorn stopped crying. Then I stopped too."

Mechanical Role: Speaking their names during the boss fight and calling on them to resist the entity grants all allies +10 to Willpower Tests for the remainder of the encounter. This clue is obtained from the Astropath's psychic echo (UD7). Vasily Hent's journal (MD6) also provides +10 to Fellowship Tests with the children.

Vasily Hent (Stasis Survivor)

Vasily is the ship's Enginseer's Mate, preserved in a stasis pod in the hidden chamber (LD7) for approximately 200 years. He sealed himself in when the cult's activities became undeniable.

Disposition: Confused, terrified, but grateful. Deeply traumatised (gains 2d10 IP on revival). Requires time and kindness to become functional.

Skills: Tech-Use (basic), Trade (Armourer) — useful for equipment maintenance on Barovus.

Role: Potential NPC ally for the campaign or replacement character hook if an Acolyte died during the dungeon. Source of historical information about the vessel and the cult's early formation.

Enemy Encounters

Warp-Echo Cultists (Phase 2 Boss Fight)

1d5 translucent, flickering spectral figures that manifest from the bulkheads during Phase 2. Use Cultist profiles with half Wounds and the Incorporeal trait (immune to mundane weapons; force weapons, sanctified weapons, and psychic attacks deal normal damage). They dissolve permanently when destroyed.

Warp-Echo Worshippers (LD4 — Congregation Hall)

1d5+2 translucent specters frozen in rapturous worship. Non-hostile. Can be dispersed by prayer (1d5 per prayer), sanctified items (incense censer disperses all instantly), or violence (any attack disrupts one, but this feels profoundly wrong). Peaceful dispersal grants Fatigue recovery.

Environmental "Enemies"

The ship itself is the primary antagonist beyond the boss. Bulkheads seal behind the Acolytes. Corridors rearrange. The organic walls contract. Power conduits rupture. The mimic-cabinet in MD5. The sleeping gas trap in MD6. The pit trap in LD5. The ship's malign intelligence works to separate, disorient, and terrorise.

Social Encounters

There are no traditional social encounters aboard the Vessel of Lament — the ship is a dead place populated by echoes and a daemon. However, the ghost-children function as a pseudo-social encounter: they respond to kindness, can be comforted (though not saved until the entity is destroyed), and provide crucial information through their dialogue. The Acolytes' treatment of Rose and Thorn is an early moral test that sets the tone for the campaign's approach to compassion in horror.

Quest Connections

  • Main Plot — Arrival on Barovus: Destroying the altar-engine destabilises the ship's position in the anomaly, dragging it through the warp rift to crash on Barovus. This is the mechanism that delivers the Acolytes to the campaign's main setting.
  • Main Plot — The Children: Rose and Thorn's tragedy foreshadows the campaign's themes of innocence destroyed by corruption. Their spectral presence echoes Ireena's vulnerability and the cycle of suffering Strahd perpetuates.
  • Relics — Sending-Stone: A key tactical resource for the boss fight. The Astropath's psychic echo also provides the clue about invoking the children's names.
  • Campaign Resource — Gellar Field Modulator: The single-use warp-ward from LD7 is one of the most valuable items in the entire campaign for surviving on Barovus.
  • Campaign Resource — Navigation Data: The +10 Navigate bonus from the bridge cogitators persists for the entire campaign.
  • NPC — Vasily Hent: Potential long-term ally or replacement character. His technical skills are useful on a world with no Mechanicus support.
  • Completion Bonus: All surviving Acolytes gain 100 XP.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd is not directly present aboard the Vessel of Lament. However, his influence permeates the experience indirectly: the ship exists because of the warp anomaly that Strahd's pact created. The anomaly pulled the Acolytes' vessel into the system. The ghost-children, the Durst family's fall, and the entity in the warp drive are all consequences of the same Slaaneshi corruption that sustains Strahd's immortality. The GM should draw these connections subtly — Captain Durst's journal references "the Lord-Governor" and his "pact with the powers beyond the veil," establishing Strahd's shadow even before the Acolytes set foot on Barovus.

The Lament Configuration

The entity is a Lesser Daemon of Slaanesh that has been bound to the vessel's warp drive, feeding on the suffering of those lured aboard. Over centuries, it has fused with the engine itself, becoming a hybrid of daemon-flesh and machine — neither fully warp entity nor fully mechanism, but something worse than either. When it manifests, it tears itself free of the altar-engine in a spray of bone, ichor, and sparking power conduits.

The corridor opens into the main engineering bay — a vaulted chamber that should not exist on a vessel of this class — vast, cathedral-like, its ceiling lost in shadow and the tangle of power conduits and coolant pipes that have fused with organic matter. The deck is a mosaic of bone and dark metal, forming a massive eight-pointed star. At its centre, where the warp drive's core housing should be, stands a corrupted altar of fused bone, black iron, and engine components — the drive and the shrine have become one, stained with centuries of dried blood and machine oil turned to ichor. The altar-engine pulses. Something within it is aware of you.

Phase 1 — The Awakening (100% to 50% Wounds)

The creature fights defensively, using tendrils to grapple and separate Acolytes. It shrieks when wounded, dealing psychic damage to all in range. It cannot leave the warp drive chamber. It prioritises isolating the most dangerous combatant and dragging them toward the altar-engine, where contact inflicts 1d5 Corruption Points per round.

The Ship Turns Hostile: Once engaged, the vessel itself works against the Acolytes. Bulkhead hatches slam shut. Organic walls constrict corridors. Power conduits rupture. Navigate (Surface) or Logic (Challenging +0) required to find the way back once the fight begins.

Phase 2 — The Surge (50% to 25% Wounds)

The creature screams — not in pain but in command. The altar-engine flares with sickly light, and the air itself splits open in a dozen places. Warp-light — raw, unfiltered Immaterium — floods the chamber in strobing pulses of pink and violet. The organic walls contract. The ceiling lowers. The room is shrinking around you.

The following effects trigger simultaneously:

  • Warp-Light Surge: All Acolytes: Willpower (Challenging +0) or Stunned 1 round. Psykers at -10 to this test.
  • Cultist Echoes: 1d5 warp-echo cultists manifest — Cultist profiles with half Wounds, Incorporeal trait. Immune to mundane weapons; vulnerable to force, sanctified, and psychic attacks. Dissolve permanently when destroyed.
  • Constricting Chamber: Organic walls contract for 3 rounds, shrinking ~1m per round. Acolytes at edges: Agility (Ordinary +10) each round or pushed inward and take 1d5 I damage.
  • Sending-Stone Disruption: If carried (from UD7), activate as a Half Action: cultist echoes dissolve, chamber stops constricting, entity takes 2d10 E damage (ignoring armour). Stone crumbles to dust.

Phase 3 — The Fusion (25% to 0% Wounds)

The creature no longer resembles anything that was ever alive. It has pulled itself into the altar-engine like a parasite burrowing into a wound, and the engine has responded — power conduits throb with black light, the bone-metal floor cracks and heaves, and the entire chamber vibrates with a frequency that makes your teeth ache and your vision blur. The entity has become the drive. The drive has become the entity. And both are furious.

Escalation: All Characteristics gain +10. Armour increases to 6 (All). New attacks:

  • Warp Vortex (Free Action, 1/round): Micro-rift strikes a random Acolyte: 2d10 E, Pen 5. Target: Willpower (Hard -20) or gain 1d5 Corruption Points. The rift point can be attacked (5 Wounds, no armour) or disrupted by prayer (+10 to hit with sanctified weapons).
  • Collapsing Floor (start of each round): Random 2m x 2m section gives way. Acolytes on it: Agility (Challenging +0) or fall for 2d10 E damage; Strength (Ordinary +10) to climb back up.

Shared Health Pool: In Phase 3, the altar-engine and entity share a single health pool — damage to either affects both. This is the entity's most dangerous but most vulnerable state.

The Altar-Engine

The corrupted warp drive core has Armour 8 and 20 Wounds. It can be attacked separately in Phases 1 and 2 (it shares a health pool with the entity only in Phase 3). Prayer while attacking grants +10 to hit, +2 damage. The entity regenerates in 1d5 rounds if destroyed without also destroying the altar-engine (Phases 1-2 only).

Defeating the Entity and the Escape

When the altar-engine is destroyed, the corrupted warp drive destabilises the vessel's position within the anomaly. The ship is seized by the warp rift and dragged toward Barovus.

The warp drive core cracks — a sound like a world breaking. Black ichor and superheated plasma erupt from the fissure, and the creature fused with it screams — not with a voice but with the fabric of reality itself. The organic bulkheads shudder, contract, and begin to rot — centuries of decay happening in seconds. And then the ship lurches. The warp anomaly is pulling you through. Toward Barovus. And it is tearing itself apart.

Escape Sequence (5 Rounds)

The Acolytes have 5 rounds to reach a crash station or saviour pod on the upper decks. The ship's malign intelligence fades with the altar-engine's destruction — corridors no longer rearrange.

The Crash

The descent is a sound beyond sound — a scream of tortured metal and howling warp energy. The vessel plunges through the rift like a burning spear. The impact is the end of everything you knew. You crawl from the wreckage into grey fog so thick it has texture — it slides across your skin like damp silk, carrying a sweet, cloying scent of flowers rotting on a grave.

The Acolytes emerge from the wreckage onto Barovus. All Acolytes gain 1 Corruption Point from exposure to the warp-fog (unavoidable). The road south leads to the Village of Barovus. All surviving Acolytes gain 100 XP for completing the Vessel of Lament.

Encounter Guide

The Vessel of Lament is the campaign's introductory dungeon — a warp-saturated cursed ship that teaches players the core lessons of Barovus: the warp corrupts everything, investigation matters as much as combat, faith has mechanical power, and not everything can be fought. 22 rooms across 3 decks, designed for 1-2 sessions. Rooms are marked [CRITICAL PATH] or [OPTIONAL]. A party in a hurry can reach the boss without visiting every compartment, but optional rooms contain valuable resources, lore, and tactical advantages.

Boarding Deck — The Children's Lure

RiskTense
TypeEnvironmental, Discovery, Social

Environmental: The airlock opens onto a cavernous boarding deck — too large for a vessel of this class. Organic sheen coats every surface. Emergency lumens flicker in sickly amber. The ship's name is stenciled on the far bulkhead: DURST'S LAMENT. Devotional aquilas line the walls, their details subtly wrong. Gargoyle-headed vox-casters crouch at junctions. If Acolytes attempt to retreat, the airlock seals and corridors rearrange — the ship will not release them.

Social: Rose and Thorn Durst — spectral children, age ~10 and ~6 — stand in the centre, appearing as living children. They beg for help: "Please, there is a monster in our ship. In the lower decks. Our parents won't wake up." Awareness (Hard -20) reveals they cast no shadows, produce no breath-mist, and their feet do not touch the deck. Psyniscience (Challenging +0) confirms they are warp-echoes — psychic imprints, not malicious but compelled to lure victims deeper.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP upon boarding (unavoidable, from anomaly exposure during the boarding sequence).

GM Notes: The children are victims, not enemies. They are part of the ship's lure but genuinely want the monster destroyed. Their names — Rose and Thorn — become mechanically important in the boss fight (UD7 clue). Establish early that retreat is impossible.

UD1-UD2: Main Corridor and Officer's Mess [CRITICAL PATH]

RiskTense
TypeEnvironmental, Discovery

Environmental: The main corridor is too grand for a transport — chequered deck plates of dark iron and tarnished brass, trophy cases with preserved six-legged predators in cracked stasis jars. The air smells of old incense and Slaaneshi musk (Forbidden Lore (Chaos) (Challenging +0) to identify). Portraits line the walls — normal when observed directly, but faces rot and smiles widen into rictus grins when looked away from and back. Willpower (Ordinary +10) required the first time this is noticed; failure: 1 IP.

Environmental: The Officer's Mess (UD2) has a table set for a formal meal — freshly prepared food that rots before the Acolytes' eyes when watched. Consuming any food: Toughness (Challenging +0) or 1d5 Wounds (ignoring armour) plus violent nausea for 1d10 rounds.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 IP (shifting portraits, first occurrence only).

GM Notes: Set the tone — the ship is wrong in ways that accumulate. The portraits are the first sign that reality is unstable here. The rotting food is visceral horror, not a trap — do not punish curiosity too harshly, but make it memorable.

UD3-UD4: Captain's Quarters and Crew Quarters [CRITICAL PATH]

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Investigation

Discoveries: The Captain's Quarters (UD3) contain the most important find on the upper deck. Search (Ordinary +10) reveals Captain Gustav Durst's hidden journal behind a false bulkhead panel. The journal documents the crew's descent into Slaaneshi heresy over 15 years — from desperation to ritual worship to the children's death by neglect. Reading in full: 1d5 IP and 1 CP, but grants +20 to subsequent Forbidden Lore (Chaos) tests within the vessel. The journal also contains the armory cipher code (14.08.37) — discoverable with Logic (Routine +20) while reviewing.

Discoveries: Crew Quarters (UD4) — largely empty. Search (Challenging +0) yields a cache of expired ration packs and a functioning ancient laspistol (common quality, 1 shot only). Bloodstains on deck plates form patterns close to Chaos sigils.

Corruption/Insanity: 1d5 IP and 1 CP (from reading Durst's journal in full).

GM Notes: The journal is essential narrative scaffolding — it explains the ship's history and makes the lower decks meaningful. Encourage thorough searching. The cipher code payoff comes at the Armory (UD6). The single-shot laspistol is a tease, not a game-changer.

RiskDangerous

Success grants +10 to Navigate (Surface) tests on Barovus for the remainder of the campaign. Failure by 3+ degrees triggers a corrupted data-burst (montage of the crew's final days): 1 IP.

Enemies: Navigator's Corpse — not true reanimation but a psychic reflex. If touched or searched, the corpse's hand clamps shut on the Acolyte's wrist. Discoveries: Captain's final bridge log — a broken audio recording: "...the drive is gone. Elisabeth's thing has consumed it. We are being pulled toward... Emperor, the planet... it is beautiful and it is wrong. I am sorry, Rose. I am sorry, Thorn. I forgot. I forgot." No mechanical effect; reinforces the tragedy.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 IP (cogitator failure). Up to 1d5 IP and 1 CP (Navigator corpse grapple).

GM Notes: The Navigation data is a genuine long-term reward. The Navigator corpse encounter is high-risk/high-reward — the endgame insight is valuable but the IP/CP cost is steep. Let players weigh the risk.
