Cybernetics Maintenance

Abaron is the only individual on Barovus capable of maintaining Imperial cybernetics. The maintenance cycle is 30 days. Without maintenance:

  • Days 31-45: Minor malfunctions (cosmetic, no penalty). GM may declare flickering bionics, spasming mechadendrites.
  • Days 46-60: -10 penalty to all Tests relying on the augmentation.
  • Days 61+: The augmentation fails entirely — dead weight until repaired.

Alternatives: Field repair (Hard (-20) Tech-Use, extends cycle by 15 days), scavenged parts (Very Hard (-30) Tech-Use, full reset but cosmetically altered).

Loot and Items of Interest

  • Belladonna Nocturnis: Rare mountain herb. Prepared tincture grants +10 to Willpower Tests vs. warp corruption for 1d5 hours. Causes -5 to Agility-based Tests for duration (nausea). 2d5 doses per foraging expedition.
  • Abaron's Medical Services: Full wound recovery, de-tox and stimms (2d5 doses per visit), cybernetics maintenance. All services cost 1d5 CP per visit.
  • Abaron's Research Data-Slates: Intelligence on Strahd's biology, the warp rift's effects on organic tissue, and the location of certain artifacts. Valuable for planning the final assault.
  • Rosette of Saint Markovia: May be in Abaron's curiosity collection (Tarot-dependent).
  • Tome of Strahd: May be visible in the Sacred Pool under specific conditions (Tarot-dependent).

Quest Connections

  • Rally the Settlements: Securing Krezk's cooperation (solving a local problem or winning Abaron's support) is one of four conditions for the Act III coalition.
  • Ireena's Arc: The Sacred Pool event is a major character moment for Ireena, potentially awakening her psychic abilities further.
  • Cybernetics Dependency: Acolytes with augmentations will return to Krezk repeatedly, creating ongoing moral tension as Abaron's demands escalate.
  • The Bride: If unresolved, the Bride becomes a plot element in Act III when Strahd attempts to use her during the final confrontation.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd's interest in Krezk is focused on two things: the Bride and Ireena. He has cultivated Abaron over centuries, nudging the Magos toward the Bride project through carefully placed suggestions and "donations" of genetic material. He monitors the Facility through servitor-skulls and through Abaron himself, who communicates with Strahd's agents via encrypted vox-channels (he considers this administrative correspondence, not collaboration).

If Ireena visits the Sacred Pool, Strahd intervenes directly — the lightning strike and his echoing voice are a personal manifestation of his will, not a pre-set trap. This is one of the few moments where Strahd loses his composure. His voice carries genuine fury and desperation. The Acolytes should understand that they have witnessed something rare: Strahd afraid.

Following the Sacred Pool event, Strahd increases surveillance of the Acolytes dramatically. Servitor-skulls appear at every rest stop. Letters arrive with greater frequency. He may send Warp-Thralls to test the party's readiness — not to kill, but to probe.

Encounter Guide

Krezk Biologis Facility is body horror wrapped in hospitality. Magos Abaron is cordial, helpful, and utterly insane — and the horror lies in how reasonable he sounds. The Sacred Pool scene is one of the campaign's dramatic pivots. Pace the facility exploration to build dread before the pool's tranquillity-to-catastrophe transition.

Village Gate

RiskTense
TypeSocial, Skill Challenge

Social: Burgomaster Dmitri Krezkov refuses entry to outsiders unless they offer something of genuine value. The standard favour: delivery of recaf or wine from the Recaf Distillery (Location 08), tying this location to that quest chain. If the Acolytes have already liberated the Distillery, entry is automatic. Otherwise: Charm (Hard -20) with a compelling personal appeal, or Command (Challenging +0) invoking Inquisitorial authority (effective but resented — Krezk has learned that Imperial officials bring trouble).

GM Notes: Krezk is isolated, suspicious, and has exactly one hundred reasons (its population) to distrust strangers. The favour quest creates a natural link to the Recaf Distillery — use it to drive exploration if the Acolytes have not yet visited. If they bypass the village, they miss the mongrelfolk rumours and the belladonna, so signal that the mountain approach has trade-offs.

Biologis Facility

RiskDangerous
TypeInvestigation, Environmental, Discovery

Environmental: Body horror throughout. The facility's central operating theatre is part surgical suite, part art gallery, part abattoir: vats of amniotic fluid containing shapes in various stages of growth, flesh-grafted servitors shambling through corridors, and the half-complete Bride on the central slab — beautiful, perfect, breathing, and unmistakably not alive. Toughness (Challenging +0) to endure the sensory assault or suffer 1d5 IP.

Investigation: Tech-Use (Ordinary +10) to recognise standard Mechanicus field equipment among Abaron's tools bearing expedition designation "Epsilon-9" — equipment from a Mechanicus survey team that arrived approximately 160 years ago. The equipment is not stored or displayed. It is integrated into his work.

Discoveries: This is Lost Expedition Site 4: Tech-Priest Epsilon-9's Equipment. A data-core containing the expedition's final survey readings and the Magos's personal log.

Magos Epsilon-9-Theta, Final Entry: "The readings are conclusive. This is not a storm. Not a rift. Not a natural phenomenon of any catalogued classification. It is a construct. Someone — or something — built this cage. The energy signatures are self-sustaining, recursive, and they respond to psychic stimuli. The Lord-Governor has been accommodating. Too accommodating. He asks the wrong questions. He wants to know what we have found. Not what we recommend. I am transmitting this log to the survey ship. If you are reading this, we did not return."

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP from the facility — unavoidable corruption from prolonged exposure to warp-tainted biologis work permeating every surface. 1d5 IP from the Bride specifically — her perfection is the worst part, the uncanny valley made flesh.

GM Notes: Abaron is cordial and helpful — a perfect host who offers medical attention, information, and shelter. That is the horror. He genuinely believes his work serves the Omnissiah and will discuss it freely, seeing no reason to hide what he considers problem-solving. The Epsilon-9 discovery confirms the warp rift is artificial and raises the question: did Abaron consume the previous expedition? Their equipment is woven into his work. He will not acknowledge this if asked directly — he has rationalised it away entirely.

Sacred Pool

RiskTranquil → Catastrophic
TypeFaith Test

Faith Test (Tranquil Phase): A natural spring at the village's edge with genuine spiritual power — golden light in the water, a sense of peace that is almost painful after the unrelenting horror of Barovus. Willpower (Ordinary +10) to pray. Success: a vision of Sergei's face in the water, a blessing, and 2d10 IP reduction — one of the most powerful healing effects in the campaign. If Ireena is present, Sergei's spirit reaches for her through the water. A moment of peace. A young man in ancient Imperial officer's regalia, reaching with desperate recognition.

Faith Test (Catastrophic Phase): Then Strahd intervenes. The pool boils. Warp-lightning splits the sky. Strahd manifests at full power — not to fight the Acolytes, but to take Ireena. His voice echoes across the mountainside: "She is MINE." If Ireena touched the water, she is partially drawn into the warp. Willpower (Very Hard -30) for Ireena to resist, or the Acolytes must physically intervene. Hard (-20) Willpower for all witnesses or suffer 1d10 IP (1d5 on success).

Corruption/Insanity: 1d10 CP if Strahd appears — proximity to a major warp entity at the height of his fury. The vision itself is healing (reduces IP) but the transition from grace to horror compounds the psychological damage.

GM Notes: This is one of the most dramatic scenes in the campaign. The transition from peace to terror must be instant — mid-sentence if possible. One moment Sergei is reaching for Ireena, the next the water is boiling and the sky is screaming. If Ireena is lost here (drawn into the warp, taken by Strahd), that is one of the four Ireena fate outcomes. Do not soften it. The cruelty is the point — this is what Strahd does to hope.

RiskTense

Approximately 30 mongrelfolk with surgically and genetically modified bodies: extra limbs, misplaced organs, composite faces, crude mechanical grafts. They are afraid but not hostile. Navigate (Ordinary +10) to update maps with settlement positions, road networks, and the visible extent of the rift boundary.

GM Notes: A rare moment of peace. Let the players breathe before or after the facility's horrors. The vista is simultaneously beautiful and devastating — a reminder of the scale of their imprisonment. The belladonna is a meaningful mechanical reward (anti-corruption tincture) that rewards exploration and preparation. Don't skip the quiet moments; they make the horror land harder.

The outpost emerges from the treeline like a fist punched through the earth. It is unmistakably Astartes architecture: brutal, angular, functional, every surface designed to absorb weapons fire and project dominance. The walls are three metres of reinforced plasteel over a rockcrete core, cracked now and overgrown with grey-green lichen but still standing after centuries of neglect. Above the gate, the chapter icon of the Silver Drakes — a winged serpent coiled around a sword — is carved in relief, partially defaced by time and deliberate vandalism. The gate stands open. Beyond it, a courtyard littered with spent bolter casings and fragments of ceramite armour. Something watches from the chapel window. A flicker of light where there should be none. Then nothing.

Narrative Description

Centuries before the warp rift, a strike force of the Silver Drakes Space Marine Chapter deployed to Barovus to address a localised daemonic incursion centred on the Zarovich ruling line. Commander Gorev led thirty Astartes and auxiliary PDF units in a campaign that lasted months and ultimately failed. Strahd, newly empowered by his daemonic pact, destroyed the Silver Drakes to the last man. Their outpost — erected as a forward operating base — stands as their tomb.

The outpost is haunted. Not by random warp-echoes or psychic phenomena, but by the actual revenants of fallen Astartes — spirits bound to the material world by unfinished duty, righteous anger, and the sheer refusal of Astartes will to accept failure, even in death. They stand vigil in silent ranks, patrol corridors they died defending, and maintain a garrison that serves no living commander. For the Acolytes, this place is both a potential sanctuary and a trial: the Silver Drakes will aid those who prove worthy of their respect, but their standards are the standards of the Adeptus Astartes, and they do not lower them for mortals.

This location carries the tone of tragic nobility — the grandeur of the Imperium's greatest warriors reduced to ghosts guarding an empty fortress on a forgotten world. It should evoke awe, sorrow, and the bitter question: if even Space Marines could not defeat Strahd, what chance do a handful of Acolytes have? The answer, as Commander Gorev will tell them, is that the Silver Drakes lacked one of three necessary elements. The Acolytes can succeed where the Silver Drakes failed — if their faith is absolute.

Key Areas of the Fallen Astartes Outpost

The Courtyard

A wide, open space of cracked rockcrete and packed earth, littered with the debris of a battle fought centuries ago: spent bolter casings corroded green with age, fragments of ceramite armour, the rusted remains of combat blades. A banner pole stands in the centre, its banner long since rotted away. The wind makes a sound through the empty buildings that is almost, but not quite, a voice.

The revenants are here. They do not immediately manifest — the Acolytes see them as peripheral flickers, half-glimpsed shapes in Mark VII power armour standing at attention or walking patrol routes. A Challenging (+0) Psyniscience or Awareness Test confirms the psychic residue is immense — this entire compound is saturated with the imprint of thirty Astartes who refused to accept death. The atmosphere is heavy, oppressive, and strangely reverential. This is not a haunted ruin. It is a shrine.

The revenants will not interfere with the Acolytes in the courtyard unless provoked. Desecrating the outpost (defacing the chapter icon, looting openly without respect, using warp-powers casually) draws an immediate hostile response — the revenants manifest fully and demand the intruders leave. Failure to comply results in psychic assault: all Acolytes within the courtyard suffer a Hard (-20) Willpower Test or take 1d10 Energy damage (warp) and are forcibly expelled through the gate.

The Barracks

Two long hab-structures flanking the courtyard. The interiors are empty but preserved with eerie precision — bunks made with military corners, equipment lockers sealed, personal effects arranged with parade-ground order. Dust does not settle here. The air is cold but clean. Each bunk bears a name-plate in High Gothic: the names of the thirty Silver Drakes who died on Barovus.

A Challenging (+0) Scholastic Lore (Imperial) or Common Lore (War) Test allows an Acolyte to identify the name-plates as a roster of the strike force. Cross-referencing with any available records (Van Richten's data-slates contain fragmentary references) confirms the Silver Drakes were a Codex-compliant chapter with a reputation for tenacity and faith-driven warfare. Their loss on Barovus is not recorded in any surviving Imperial archive — the chapter itself may have assumed the strike force was lost in the warp.

The Armoury and Relic Vault

A reinforced structure at the rear of the compound, its blast doors sealed but not locked — they open with a grinding protest when pushed. The armoury proper has been mostly looted over the centuries: empty weapon racks, depleted ammunition crates, disassembled heavy weapons stripped of critical components. The smell of old gun oil and sacred unguents lingers.

A Hard (-20) Search Test reveals a hidden compartment behind a false wall panel (triggered by pressing the Silver Drake chapter icon in a specific sequence — a Challenging (+0) Logic or Common Lore (Adeptus Astartes) Test to deduce). The compartment contains:

  • 2d5 Astartes bolt rounds (blessed, +10 damage against warp entities)
  • A combat knife of exceptional quality (Best Craftsmanship mono-edged, 1d10+3 R, Pen 2)
  • A data-crystal containing the Silver Drakes' complete tactical analysis of their campaign against Strahd — invaluable intelligence that grants +10 to all tests related to planning the assault on the Zarovich Spire

The relic vault — a gene-locked inner chamber — may contain Dawn's Edge (Tarot-dependent). Opening the vault requires a Space Marine's gene-seed (impossible under normal circumstances) or a Very Hard (-30) Tech-Use Test to bypass the biometric lock. Commander Gorev can open it if he judges the Acolytes worthy.

The Chapel

Dedicated to the Emperor, the chapel is the spiritual heart of the outpost and the site of the Trial of Faith. It is a simple space: stone walls, an altar of black marble bearing a tarnished but intact aquila, rows of stone benches worn smooth by centuries of phantom congregants. A faint golden light emanates from the altar — residual sanctity that persists despite everything. The chapel and its immediate surroundings function as weak Sanctified Ground: warp entities suffer -5 to all Tests within 10 metres, and Corruption Tests gain +5.

The stained-glass windows depict scenes from the Silver Drakes' history: their founding, their victories, and — in the final window, shattered and crudely repaired with lead — their last stand on Barovus. The repaired window shows Commander Gorev, recognisable even in abstract glass, standing alone against a figure of shadow and cold fire. The figure is Strahd.

The Strategium

The Silver Drakes' command centre, located in the outpost's central building. A circular room dominated by a hololith projector table (non-functional — the power cells died centuries ago) surrounded by cogitator banks (also dead). The walls are covered in faded tactical maps of Barovus, annotated in precise Astartes notation.

A pict-slate beneath a fallen rafter contains fragmentary records of the campaign against Strahd — tactical analyses, after-action reports, and a final, desperate entry from Commander Gorev:

"He cannot be killed by mortal arms alone. The blade must be sanctified. The light must be pure. The faith must be absolute. We had two of three. Emperor forgive us."

This entry is critical intelligence. It confirms the three-element requirement for Strahd's destruction (Dawn's Edge, the Rosette, and absolute faith) and reveals that the Silver Drakes came agonisingly close to success. A Challenging (+0) Scholastic Lore (Tarot) or Logic Test connects this entry to the Emperor's Tarot reading — the three relics the Acolytes seek correspond to what the Silver Drakes lacked.

The Beacon Tower

The outpost's highest point — a cylindrical tower rising above the compound walls, crowned by a large apparatus of polished lenses, psycho-reactive crystal arrays, and focusing mechanisms. This is the Silver Drake Beacon: a device designed to project a concentrated beam of psychoactive faith-energy visible for hundreds of kilometres. It is non-functional. Its power source — a skull carved from psycho-reactive crystal, pulsing with the residual faith of a long-dead Chapter Master — was taken from the outpost after the Silver Drakes fell.

The apparatus itself is intact and can be examined with a Challenging (+0) Tech-Use Test. The focusing mechanisms are sound. The crystal arrays are undamaged. All it needs is its heart — the Chapter Master's skull — and a psyker to channel the activation sequence.

Key NPCs

Commander Gorev

Disposition: Honourable, tragic, consumed by the failure of his mission. Threat Rating: Severe (revenant with Astartes-equivalent characteristics).

The spirit of the Silver Drakes' commanding officer. He appears as a translucent figure in battered Mark VII power armour — a massive figure even by Astartes standards, with a face carved from stone and eyes that burn with cold fire. His voice carries the weight of centuries of unfinished duty. He does not appear immediately upon the Acolytes' arrival; he observes them from the chapel, judging their conduct and intent before revealing himself.

Motivations: See Strahd destroyed and his battle-brothers' mission completed. Find mortals worthy of the task the Silver Drakes could not finish. Maintain the honour of his chapter. Dialogue Hooks: "We came to this world with bolter and blade and the Emperor's fury. It was not enough. Strahd von Zarovich broke us — not through greater strength, but through a darkness that our weapons could not cut. We had the blade. We had the faith. We did not have the light. You must succeed where we failed, mortals. The Emperor demands it. I demand it."

If the Acolytes pass the Trial of Faith, Gorev becomes a powerful ally. He provides:

  • Access to the relic vault (if Dawn's Edge is located there)
  • Sacred oils (3 applications: grant the Sanctified quality to a weapon for 24 hours)
  • +10 to Willpower Tests while within the outpost
  • Bolter ammunition (2d5 rounds, blessed, one-time gift)
  • Tactical counsel on the Spire assault (+10 to Strategic planning Tests)
  • The Chapter Master's skull location (if he knows it — this depends on GM decisions)

Chaplain Vladimir Horngaard

Disposition: Bitter, mad, actively hostile to any effort to destroy Strahd. Threat Rating: Severe (the outpost's most powerful revenant).

The spirit of the outpost's second-in-command — a Chaplain of the Silver Drakes. Unlike Gorev, Vladimir has been driven insane by centuries of undeath. He does not want Strahd destroyed. He wants Strahd to suffer — to exist forever in his cursed state, trapped and miserable, as punishment for what he did to the Silver Drakes. In Vladimir's twisted logic, killing Strahd would be a mercy, and mercy is the last thing the monster deserves.

Motivations: Ensure Strahd suffers eternally. Prevent anyone from granting Strahd the release of death. Maintain his grip on the lesser revenants who follow him. Dialogue Hooks: "You would END him? You would grant him PEACE? No. No! He destroyed us. He broke our chapter's honour. He murdered thirty brothers of the Emperor's own design. And you would let him DIE? Death is too kind. Let him rot in this prison he built. Let him hunger and rage and remember what he lost — FOREVER. That is justice. That is what the dead deserve."

Combat Profile (if it comes to violence): Vladimir is a revenant with Astartes Chaplain characteristics. WS 65, BS 50, S 55 (110), T 55 (110), Ag 40, Int 45, Per 50, WP 70, Fel 35. Wounds: 40. Spectral ceramite armour (AP 10 all locations, immune to mundane weapons — only holy, blessed, force, or psychic attacks deal full damage; mundane weapons deal half damage). Weapons: Spectral Crozius Arcanum (Melee, 2d10+12 E, Pen 8, Power Field, Holy — deals double damage to warp-touched entities), Spectral bolt pistol (Pistol, 30m, S/2/--, 1d10+9 X, Pen 5, Tearing, Blessed). Traits: Fear (3), Unnatural Strength (x2), Unnatural Toughness (x2), From Beyond, Incorporeal (can phase through solid matter). He is accompanied by 1d5+2 lesser revenants (WS 50, S 45, T 50, Wounds 25, spectral bolters and combat blades).

The Lesser Revenants

Disposition: Divided — some follow Gorev's honourable pragmatism, others follow Vladimir's bitter obsession. Threat Rating: Challenging (individually); Severe (in groups).

Approximately 30 revenant Space Marines haunt the outpost. They manifest as translucent figures in Mark VII power armour, moving through patrol routines and garrison duties with mechanical precision. Most are silent. A few murmur prayers to the Emperor in voices like wind through broken glass. They are divided between Gorev's faction (those who wish to see their mission completed) and Vladimir's faction (those consumed by hatred).

The lesser revenants will not attack the Acolytes unless provoked or ordered to by Vladimir. If the Acolytes prove worthy through the Trial of Faith, Gorev's faction stands down entirely and may provide passive assistance (opening doors, pointing out hidden areas, warding against warp intrusions). Vladimir's faction remains hostile and must be dealt with separately.

The Trial of Faith

Entering the chapel triggers the trial. The revenants of the Silver Drakes manifest, forming ranks in the nave — thirty spectral Astartes in full battle gear, their bolters held at port arms, their eyes burning with cold judgement. Commander Gorev manifests at the altar and demands the Acolytes justify their presence.

Mechanical Resolution

  1. Psychic Endurance: Each Acolyte must pass a Challenging (+0) Willpower Test to withstand the psychic pressure of thirty angry Astartes revenants. Failure inflicts 1d5 Insanity Points and the Acolyte is visibly shaken (-10 to Fellowship Tests for the remainder of the trial).
  2. The Speech: One Acolyte (chosen by the party or the GM) must address Commander Gorev and explain their mission, their devotion to the Emperor, and their plan to destroy Strahd. This is resolved as a Hard (-20) Fellowship or Command Test. The GM should grant bonuses for genuine roleplaying effort (+10 to +20 for an impassioned, in-character speech), for presenting evidence of their mission (Inquisitorial rosette, Van Richten's intelligence, recovered relics), and for demonstrating knowledge of the Silver Drakes' sacrifice (+5 per relevant fact cited).
  3. Judgement: On success, Gorev declares the Acolytes worthy. The revenants salute — a spectral crack of ceramite gauntlets striking chest-plates — and stand aside. On failure, the revenants dismiss the Acolytes as unworthy and they are expelled from the chapel. No damage, but the shame is significant. They may attempt the trial again after accomplishing a notable deed against Strahd's forces.

Vladimir's Opposition

If the Acolytes attempt to activate the Beacon or seek Gorev's full blessing, Vladimir intervenes. He manifests in the Beacon Tower or chapel with 1d5+2 lesser revenants, blocking the way. He does not attack immediately but delivers a furious, unhinged tirade about how Strahd must suffer, not die.

Resolution Options

  • Diplomacy: A Very Hard (-30) Fellowship Test. Vladimir is an Astartes Chaplain and will not be easily swayed. Arguments based on the Emperor's will or the honour of the Silver Drakes have the best chance. Success convinces him to stand aside (but not to help). Failure enrages him further.
  • Combat: Vladimir is a formidable opponent (see combat profile above). Defeating him does not destroy him permanently — he reforms in 1d5 days — but it removes his opposition for the immediate objective.
  • Gorev's Intervention: If the Acolytes have Gorev's full support and have proven themselves through significant deeds, Gorev confronts Vladimir directly. The two revenants engage in a spectral duel — the outcome depends on whether the Acolytes have sufficiently impressed Gorev (GM discretion). If Gorev prevails, Vladimir retreats in bitter silence.
  • Creative Solutions: The GM should reward creative approaches — invoking the Silver Drakes' chapter oaths, presenting evidence that Strahd's destruction will cause more suffering than his continued existence, or appealing to Vladimir's buried sense of duty rather than his dominant rage.

The Beacon — Activation and Effects

The Beacon requires two things: the Chapter Master's skull (a psycho-reactive crystal relic taken from the outpost after the Silver Drakes fell — its location is determined by the GM, possibly via Tarot or found during exploration of another location) and a psyker to channel the activation sequence.

Activation Sequence

  1. Install the skull in the Beacon apparatus (Challenging (+0) Tech-Use Test).
  2. A psyker channels faith-energy through the crystal arrays (Ordinary (+10) Psyniscience Test). On failure, the psyker suffers 1d5 Energy damage from psychic feedback but may retry next round.
  3. The Beacon ignites. A column of pure golden light punches through the fog of Barovus and into the sky.

Beacon Effects

  • Warp Suppression: All warp activity within visual range of the Beacon is reduced. Warp-touched creatures suffer -10 to all characteristics while in its light.
  • Hope: The citizens of Barovus can see the Beacon from every settlement. Settlement morale improves. NPCs in all locations become more cooperative (+5 to Fellowship-based Tests campaign-wide).
  • Strahd's Rage: Strahd is enraged. He makes destroying the Beacon a priority, likely sending a major force against the outpost (2d5 Warp-Thralls, 1d5 Elite Guards, possibly led by a personal lieutenant). The Acolytes must decide whether to defend the Beacon or let it fall — its destruction does not undo the hope it inspired, but its loss is a significant blow to morale.

Loot and Items of Interest

  • Hidden Armoury Compartment: 2d5 Astartes bolt rounds (blessed, +10 damage vs. warp entities), Best Craftsmanship mono-edged combat knife (1d10+3 R, Pen 2), campaign data-crystal (+10 to Spire assault planning)
  • Sacred Oils: 3 applications (each grants the Sanctified quality to a weapon for 24 hours). Reward for passing the Trial of Faith.
  • Bolter Ammunition: 2d5 blessed bolt rounds (one-time gift from Gorev). These cannot be replicated.
  • Dawn's Edge: May be in the gene-locked relic vault (Tarot-dependent).
  • Rosette of Saint Markovia: May be on the chapel altar (Tarot-dependent).
  • Strategium Intelligence: Gorev's final pict-slate entry confirming the three-element requirement; tactical maps of Barovus with Astartes annotations; fragmentary after-action reports.

Quest Connections

Main Plot

  • Three Relics: The outpost may contain Dawn's Edge or the Rosette (Tarot-dependent). Gorev's final entry confirms the three-element requirement for Strahd's destruction.
  • Beacon Activation: One of four conditions for the Rally the Settlements coalition (provides a symbol of hope).
  • Commander Gorev as Ally: If drawn as the Destined Ally (Tarot card 6 — "The Broken Knight"), Gorev manifests to fight alongside the Acolytes in Act III, providing spectral combat support and +20 to resist Fear within 10m.

Side Quests

  • Rally the Settlements: Activating the Beacon is one of four conditions for the Act III coalition military force.
  • The Chapter Master's Skull: Finding and returning the skull is a sub-quest that may span multiple locations.
  • Silver Drake Legacy: The data-crystal and tactical maps provide strategic advantages for the Spire assault.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd's influence at the outpost is minimal — the revenants' psychic presence creates a partial ward that makes scrying difficult. Strahd is aware of the outpost's existence and its haunted nature, but he does not fear the ghosts — they cannot leave the compound, and their hatred is impotent without living agents to act on their behalf. He considers the outpost a monument to his victory.

This changes dramatically if the Beacon is activated. The pillar of faith-light is a direct challenge to Strahd's dominion — visible, symbolic, and mechanically damaging to his forces. He responds with escalating force:

  • Within hours: Servitor-skulls arrive to assess the situation. Strahd sends a letter to the Acolytes via bat-servitor: "I congratulate you on repairing an antique. I trust you understand that antiques, however beautiful, are fragile things."
  • Within one day: A raiding force of Warp-Thralls and Elite Guards probes the outpost's defences.
  • Within three days: A full assault force arrives. If the Acolytes are present, this is a major combat encounter. If they have moved on, the Beacon may fall without their defence (GM discretion based on narrative pacing — the revenants fight but cannot hold indefinitely against physical enemies they struggle to harm).

Strahd himself does not attack the outpost. The revenants' psychic presence makes him uncomfortable — not afraid, but uncomfortable, like a man returning to the site of a crime he does not regret but cannot forget. If confronted here during a personal visit, he is uncharacteristically terse and leaves quickly. This is one of the few locations on Barovus where Strahd is not entirely at ease.

Encounter Guide

The Fallen Astartes Outpost is a tomb of legends. Everything here is built to transhuman scale — doorways the Acolytes walk through without ducking, weapons they can barely lift, armour that weighs more than they do. The horror is not corruption but failure: if the Emperor's Angels could not win here, what chance do Inquisitorial Acolytes have? Play the scale. Play the silence. Play the grief.

Courtyard

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Environmental

Environmental: War debris preserved by centuries of stillness — spent bolter casings corroded green, fragments of ceramite armour, the rusted remains of combat blades, claw marks gouged into adamantium walls. Scholastic Lore (War) (Ordinary +10) or Forbidden Lore (Adeptus Astartes) (Challenging +0) identifies Silver Drakes Chapter markings: a winged serpent coiled around a sword, partially defaced by time and deliberate vandalism.

Discoveries: A bolter round embedded in the courtyard wall — unfired, magazine-fresh, somehow pristine after centuries as though the outpost itself preserved it. Ballistic Skill test to extract without damaging it. Yields 1 bolt round — incredibly valuable by Barovus standards, and blessed by proximity to Astartes faith.

Seeing evidence of Astartes defeat — the shattered ceramite, the scale of the destruction, the knowledge that beings engineered for war by the Emperor Himself fell here — is profoundly demoralising. If they could not win, what can mortal Acolytes hope to achieve?

GM Notes: The outpost should feel like a tomb from the first step. Everything is built for transhumans — oversized doorframes, weapon racks at shoulder height for a being three metres tall, chairs that make the Acolytes feel like children. The silence is oppressive. The wind makes sounds through the empty buildings that are almost, but not quite, voices. Set the atmosphere here and maintain it throughout.

Armoury

Skill Challenge: Main weapons locker — Security (Hard -20) to open the sealed mechanism, corroded but intact. Secondary cache is gene-locked to Astartes biometrics. The accessible loot is still extraordinary by Barovus standards; impress upon them what 12 bolt rounds mean in a world where autogun magazines are treasures. The Astartes blessed bolt rounds found in the hidden compartment (2d5 rounds, +10 damage vs warp entities) require a Search (Hard -20) to locate.

Strategium

RiskTranquil
TypeDiscovery, Investigation

Investigation: The Silver Drakes' command centre. Cogitator banks are dead but a pict-slate beneath a fallen rafter contains fragmentary recordings of the Chapter's final days. Tech-Use (Challenging +0) to recover data. The recordings show a methodical, professional military retreat that devolved into chaos over weeks. Each pict-capture is more degraded and desperate than the last. The final entry shows Commander Gorev ordering the beacon activated — his voice steady, his face carved from stone, his eyes already knowing it would not be enough.

Discoveries: Strategic maps of Barovus from 200+ years ago — settlement positions, road networks, terrain analysis, daemon incursion patterns. Some locations have changed; some have not. GM Notes: The recordings should be presented as fragmentary pict-captures — visual static, audio distortion, moments of clarity amid degradation. The Astartes were not panicking, which makes it worse. They were losing with perfect discipline, every tactical withdrawal textbook-correct, every last stand conducted with honour. Professional soldiers dying professionally. The Gorev quote is a critical clue about the three relics — let the players parse it themselves.

Faith Test: The Chapel of the Silver Drakes still holds residual sanctity. Willpower (Challenging +0) to pray. Success: 1d10 IP reduction and a vision of the Chapter's last stand — thirty Astartes holding the line, falling one by one, never breaking. Failure: 1d5 IP from psychic backlash of centuries of compressed grief echoing through the chapel stones.

Social: The Silver Drake revenants manifest — translucent figures in battered Mark VII power armour, forming ranks in the nave. 3 Space Marine Revenants issue the Trial of Faith: three questions about duty, sacrifice, and the Emperor. These are roleplayed, not rolled. Good answers demonstrate genuine understanding of Imperial faith and the weight of sacrifice. GM Notes: The Trial of Faith should be roleplayed, not reduced to a dice roll. Ask each Acolyte directly: Why do you serve the Emperor? What would you sacrifice? What is duty when hope is gone? Good answers are not rehearsed catechisms — they are honest, human responses from characters who have seen what Barovus does to faith. The revenants are tragic figures: honourable warriors denied rest by unfinished duty. If blessed, the Acolytes carry the Silver Drakes' legacy forward. That should feel like weight, not a bonus.

For 6+, increase Wounds to 40 and add a sweep attack hitting all adjacent targets.

GM Notes: Vladimir is the most sympathetic enemy in the outpost. He is not wrong — the beacon DOES channel warp energy, and ending Strahd could be seen as mercy for a monster who deserves eternal suffering. This is a genuine moral dilemma, not a combat encounter with a moral veneer. If the Acolytes can articulate why Strahd must be destroyed (for Barovus, for the Imperium, for duty) rather than merely defeated, Vladimir may falter — but he will not yield easily. His 1d5+2 lesser revenants may also intervene, blocking the approach. Creative solutions (bypassing Vladimir, reasoning with Gorev to countermand him, channelling the revenants' collective will) should be rewarded.

You feel it before you see it. A pressure behind your eyes, a buzzing in your molars, a crawling sensation across every centimetre of exposed skin. The trees thin, then stop entirely, as though even the corrupted flora of Barovus refuses to approach the hilltop. The ground shifts from packed earth to something that crunches like glass and gives like flesh. Twelve standing stones crown the summit, each twice the height of a man, humming at a frequency just below hearing. At the hill's centre, rooted like a suppurating wound, the Warp-Tree pulses with sickly bioluminescence -- twenty metres tall, its trunk wider than a Leman Russ, its branches grasping at a sky that bleeds colour. Around the tree's base, robed figures chant in a language that predates Low Gothic by millennia.

GM Overview

The Warp Nexus is the point on Barovus where the barrier between realspace and the immaterium is thinnest. The twelve standing stones — xenos in origin, their provenance unknown — serve as amplifiers, focusing warp energy into a concentrated upwelling that manifests as perpetual reality distortion. Time flows strangely here: minutes may pass as hours, or hours as seconds. Colours shift without source. Shadows move independently of light. The air tastes of copper and ozone, and the ground itself seems to breathe.

The Warp-Tree is a manifestation of Strahd's subconscious — a psychic echo of a tree from his original homeworld, from a garden where he once knew peace. The warp has corrupted it into a living conduit that channels immaterium energy into realspace. As long as the Tree stands, Strahd's control over the landscape of Barovus is strengthened. Sacred Seed #1, stolen from the Recaf Distillery, is embedded in the Tree's root system, feeding its unnatural growth. This directly links the Nexus to the Distillery quest chain — recovering the seed requires destroying or severely damaging the Tree.

The cultists gathered here are the Nature-Corruption Devotees — desperate humans who have abandoned the Imperial Creed in favour of worshipping the warp as a primal force of transformation. They are not sophisticated heretics; they are broken people who chose to embrace mutation rather than die fighting it. Their leader, the massive mutant warlord Wintersplinter, was once human — now a three-metre monstrosity of bark-like skin, root-tendril limbs, and a face that is half-man, half-tree. The Devotees are attempting a twelve-hour summoning ritual that, if completed, will tear a permanent warp-gate into realspace, flooding Barovus with daemonic entities beyond any settlement's ability to withstand. The Acolytes must stop them.

Key Areas

A. The Approach — Fog-Choked Hillside

The Warp Nexus sits one travel segment from the Recaf Distillery, reached by a cross-country route through corrupted woodland. The final approach is a steep, treeless hillside — the vegetation refuses to grow within two hundred metres of the stones. The ground is a vitrified crust that crunches underfoot and occasionally gives way to soft, fleshy pockets that leak warmth. Fog clings thickly to the lower slopes but thins near the summit, replaced by the shimmering heat-haze of concentrated warp energy.

Paths: Four rough trails climb the hill from each cardinal direction. The southern approach offers the most cover (scattered boulders and dead stumps), while the northern approach is the steepest but shortest. Cultist sentries (2 per path) patrol the lower slopes during the ritual — Challenging (+0) Stealth Test to bypass them, or Ordinary (+10) Awareness to detect them first. If a sentry spots intruders, they raise the alarm with a ululating warp-touched cry that carries unnaturally far, alerting Wintersplinter and the ritual circle within 1d5 rounds.

Environmental Hazard: The vitrified ground is treacherous. Moving at full speed requires an Ordinary (+10) Agility Test or the Acolyte stumbles, taking 1d5 Impact damage from the razor-sharp glass-like crust. The warp saturation intensifies as the Acolytes climb — upon reaching the stone circle perimeter, every Acolyte must pass an Ordinary (+10) Willpower Test or gain 1 Insanity Point from the sheer wrongness of the environment.

B. The Stone Circle — Twelve Xenos Monoliths

Twelve standing stones form a rough circle approximately forty metres in diameter at the hilltop. Each stone is carved from a material that defies classification — neither stone, metal, nor crystal, but something that shifts subtly between all three depending on the angle of observation. Alien sigils cover every surface, deeply incised and still sharp-edged despite their apparent antiquity. The sigils glow faintly, cycling through colours that have no names in Low Gothic. Each stone is warm to the touch and vibrates at a sub-audible frequency that sets teeth on edge and makes augmetic components flicker.

The Ritual: One Nature-Corruption Devotee stands at each stone, chanting in a pre-Gothic language. The ritual requires twelve cultists chanting for twelve hours, one per stone. Removing a cultist from a stone by any means — killing, incapacitating, dragging them away — disrupts the ritual for 1d5 rounds but does not end it permanently. A new cultist can take the vacated position. To permanently neutralise a stone, the Acolytes must cleanse it: place a sanctified object at its base (an Aquila pendant, blessed ammunition, holy water) or have a psyker channel a Sanctification rite (Hard (-20) Willpower Test). A cleansed stone goes dark and silent. Three or more cleansed stones end the ritual permanently.

The Vision Quest: Any psyker who touches a standing stone — or any Acolyte who touches the Warp-Tree — receives an overwhelming psychic vision of Strahd's pact with Slaanesh. The vision is vivid, immersive, and indistinguishable from reality for 1d5 rounds. It shows a young officer kneeling before a mirror that reflects not his face but the visage of a Daemon Prince — beautiful, terrible, and vast beyond comprehension. The young man speaks: "I accept. Give me what I desire, and I am yours." The garden dies. The tree bleeds. The sky darkens. And Strahd von Zarovich stands, no longer young, his eyes the eyes of something that will never die and will never stop hungering.

The vision inflicts 1d10 Corruption Points and 1d5 Insanity Points, both halved (round down) on a successful Hard (-20) Willpower Test. It also grants critical intelligence: the nature of Strahd's pact (Slaanesh), the moment of its inception, and the price he paid (his humanity, his world, everything). This information is invaluable for the campaign's endgame.

C. The Warp-Tree — Heart of the Nexus

The Tree dominates the summit. Twenty metres tall, its trunk wider than a Leman Russ battle tank, its branches spread against the sky like the grasping fingers of a drowning man. It is made of wood and meat and something else — a substance that shifts between organic and mineral, pulsing with a slow, rhythmic cadence like a heartbeat. Sap the colour of old blood seeps from cracks in its bark, and where it drips, the ground writhes with tiny, boneless things that are born, suffer, and die in seconds.

Sacred Seed #1 is embedded in the Tree's root system, visible as a faintly golden glow beneath the bark at the Tree's base. Recovering it requires destroying the Tree or severing its warp connection (see GM Reference for mechanics).

Root-Tendrils: The Tree is immobile but not passive. Any creature within 5 metres is subject to lashing root-tendrils: S 50, 1d10+8 I damage, Flexible. The tendrils attack reflexively — the Tree has no tactical awareness but reacts to proximity.

Warp Saturation: The air within the stone circle is so thick with warp energy that unprotected psykers suffer Psychic Phenomena on any doubles when using powers, not just matching tens digits. Non-psykers who spend more than 30 minutes within the circle without warp protection must test for Corruption (Challenging (+0) Willpower or gain 1d5 CP per 30 minutes).

D. The Ritual Clearing

A flat area between the stone circle and the Tree's trunk serves as the Devotees' camp. Crude shelters of hide and warp-warped wood, a central fire pit burning with violet flame that gives heat but no light, and offerings piled at the Tree's base: dead animals, severed human limbs, and crude icons shaped from fused bone. Wintersplinter typically stands guard here, a towering sentinel of bark and sinew, unmoving unless the alarm is raised.

If the Acolytes approach stealthily and observe, they can count the cultists, identify Wintersplinter's position, and plan their assault. An Ordinary (+10) Scrutiny Test reveals that three of the chanting cultists appear to be flagging — exhausted by hours of sustained ritual. These three are the weakest links and could be removed with minimal resistance.

NPCs and Encounters

Nature-Corruption Devotees

Disposition: Fanatical, feral, beyond reason

Number: 12-20 (12 at the stones during the ritual, plus 2-8 additional as sentries and reserves)

The Devotees are not Chaos Space Marines or sophisticated sorcerers — they are desperate former citizens of Barovus who chose to embrace the warp's transformative power rather than resist it. Most bear minor mutations: extra fingers, discoloured skin, eyes that glow faintly in darkness, vestigial growths. They wear ragged robes over emaciated bodies and fight with crude weapons: autoguns held together with wire, blades of fused bone, and their own mutated limbs.

Profile: Use Cultist profiles with the following modifications: +5 WP (sustained warp exposure has hardened their minds), minor random mutation (roll once on the Minor Mutation table per Devotee), and Resistance (Fear) — they have seen too much to be frightened by anything mortal.

Tactics: The ritual cultists will not willingly leave their stones. They fight from their positions, calling for aid rather than abandoning the chant. Reserve Devotees mob intruders in groups of 3-4, attempting to overwhelm with numbers. If Wintersplinter falls, morale collapses — surviving Devotees must pass a Challenging (+0) Willpower Test or flee into the fog.

Social: The Devotees cannot be reasoned with through conventional means. They believe the warp is the natural order and the Imperium is the aberration. However, an Acolyte who succeeds on a Very Hard (-30) Charm or Intimidate Test can shake the faith of an individual Devotee long enough to pull them from their stone — they will not fight, but collapse weeping. This approach costs 1 Insanity Point to the Acolyte who attempts it, as the Devotee's broken worldview is genuinely pitiful.

Wintersplinter — Mutant Warlord

Disposition: Guardian of the Tree, territorial, animalistic intelligence

Threat Rating: Severe

Wintersplinter was once a man — a farmer, perhaps, or a labourer. Now it is a three-metre hulk of bark-armoured flesh, its limbs replaced by root-tendril appendages of terrible strength, its face split vertically between something recognisably human and the grooved, sap-weeping surface of living wood. It does not speak, but it understands Low Gothic and responds to the Devotees' commands with grunting compliance. It is utterly devoted to the Tree and will fight to the death to protect it.

Encounter Phases

Phase 1 — Disruption: The Acolytes engage the outer sentries and begin cleansing or clearing stones. Devotees at the stones resist but do not abandon their posts. Wintersplinter activates and moves to intercept. Reserve Devotees attack from the camp.

Phase 2 — The Warlord: Wintersplinter engages in full melee. The Tree's root-tendrils lash at anyone within range. If three or more stones are cleansed, the ritual energy destabilises — warp phenomena occur at random (roll on the Warp Phenomena table each round, affecting a random combatant).

Phase 3 — Collapse: When Wintersplinter is destroyed or the Tree is severed/destroyed, the remaining Devotees break. The warp energy dissipates visibly — the shimmering heat-haze fades, the stones go dark, and for the first time, natural wind blows across the hilltop. If Sacred Seed #1 is recovered, it glows with a warm golden light that is physically painful for warp-touched creatures to approach.

The Warp-Tree — Destruction Mechanics

Physical Destruction: TB 12, 80 Wounds. The Tree is immobile and does not dodge or parry, but its root-tendrils (S 50, 1d10+8 I, Flexible) lash reflexively at anything within 5 metres. Fire damage is doubled against the Tree. Blessed or holy weapons ignore its TB entirely.

Quest Connections

  • Vision Quest Intelligence: The vision of Strahd's pact is one of the most important pieces of narrative intelligence in the campaign.   • Emperor's Tarot: If the Tarot reading designated Dawn's Edge as located at the Warp Nexus (The Pyre result), the relic power sword is embedded in the Tree's trunk and must be physically wrenched free (Challenging (-10) Strength Test while enduring 2d10 E damage per round from warp exposure).

Strahd's Presence

Strahd does not appear at the Warp Nexus in person — the site is one of the few places on Barovus where his control is not absolute, as the xenos stones predate his pact and operate on principles he does not fully understand. However, his psychic echo permeates the Tree, and the Vision Quest is effectively a direct window into his past. He becomes aware of any Acolyte who experiences the vision and may comment on it during future encounters: "You saw the garden. You saw the mirror. Tell me — did you understand what you saw, or did you merely observe?"

If the Tree is destroyed, Strahd feels it as a physical pain — a momentary weakening of his connection to the land. He sends a servitor patrol (1d5+2 Elite Guards) to investigate within 2d10 hours. The Acolytes should be well clear by then.

The Warp Nexus is where the barrier between realspace and the immaterium is thinnest on Barovus. Xenos standing stones amplify warp energy into a concentrated upwelling; time flows strangely, colours shift, and shadows move independently. The Warp-Tree at the summit is a psychic echo of Strahd's homeworld, corrupted into a living conduit. Nature-Corruption Devotees worship here, guarding the tree and performing rituals. This is a high-corruption environment — extended exposure erodes sanity rapidly.

The slope rises sharply ahead, a hillside of dark scree and stunted, wind-bent trees. Halfway up, half-buried in the earth as though the planet itself is trying to swallow it, lies the broken hull of a Cargo-8 Ridgehauler — thirty metres of reinforced plasteel and ceramite, its forward cab crushed where it impacted the hillside, its rear cargo compartment tilted at a steep angle but structurally intact. GM Overview

The Cargo-8 Ridgehauler was part of an early resupply convoy dispatched from Fortress Vallak during a period when Strahd still maintained the appearance of Imperial governance. The convoy was ambushed by warp-mutants in the mountain passes, and this vehicle — the last in the column — was driven off the road by its panicking crew. The crew died. The mutants stripped what they could carry and left the rest. Strahd's servitor-skulls found it, marked it as his property, and left it as bait for anyone desperate or foolish enough to defy the Lord-Governor's claim.

The transport has remained largely untouched because the locals know better than to steal from Strahd's claimed property, and the approach is genuinely dangerous. For off-world Acolytes who do not yet grasp the social dynamics of Barovus, it represents the single most significant supply cache available on the planet — lasgun charge packs, bolt pistol magazines, grenades, medical supplies, armour, and communications equipment. Nothing else like it exists. Once looted, it is gone forever.

This location is designed as a short, high-tension encounter with a three-phase structure: approach through hazardous terrain, loot under pressure, and survive the consequences. The real sting is Phase 3 — Strahd's servitor-skull observes everything, ensuring the Lord-Governor knows the Acolytes have helped themselves to his property. He is not angry. He is interested. And that is far more dangerous than anger.

Key Areas

A. The Approach — Unstable Scree Slope

The crashed transport is located in the foothills between Fortress Vallak and the Warp Nexus, approximately one travel segment off the main road. Reaching it requires a Challenging (+0) Navigate (Surface) Test. The terrain is steep and unstable — loose scree, concealed sinkholes, and fog that clings to the hillside like gauze. Failure wastes 1d5 hours on false trails before finding the wreck.

Unstable Hillside: The slope surrounding the transport is treacherous. Approaching the cargo bay requires an Ordinary (+10) Agility Test. Failure means a minor slide: 1d5 Impact damage from tumbling scree, and the noise attracts attention — increase the number of warp-mutant scavengers in the encounter by +2. The scree provides poor footing: all movement on the slope counts as Difficult Terrain (half speed).

Warp-Flora Patches: Clumps of warp-corrupted vegetation dot the lower hillside — fleshy, bulbous growths with thorn-like protrusions that weep a bioluminescent ichor. Contact with the thorns requires a Routine (+20) Toughness Test or the Acolyte suffers 1d5 Toxic damage (ignoring armour) and a lingering numbness in the affected limb (-5 to tests using that limb for 1d10 rounds). The patches can be avoided with an Ordinary (+10) Awareness Test to spot them in the fog.

B. The Forward Cab

The Ridgehauler's forward cab is crushed from the impact, its armoured windscreen shattered and its control consoles buckled inward. The driver's remains are still strapped into the command throne — a skeleton in a rotted Munitorum transport uniform, one hand still gripping the steering yoke. A rosary of the Emperor hangs from the rearview mirror, its beads fused together by heat.

Salvageable Items: A Challenging (+0) Search Test recovers the following from the cab: a damaged but partially functional field vox-caster (range 5km, but broadcasts on a fixed frequency that Strahd's network monitors — the Acolytes will not know this without a Hard (-20) Tech-Use Test to diagnose), a personal data-slate belonging to the driver (contains a partial route map of the convoy's intended path and a final, panicked log entry describing the mutant ambush), and a laspistol with 2 charges remaining (Good condition).

The Driver's Log: The data-slate's final entry reads: "They came from the trees. Emperor preserve us. Kolya is dead. The road is gone. I am driving blind. If anyone finds this — the cargo is intact. Get it to Vallak. The garrison needs it. The garrison needs—" The entry ends abruptly. An Ordinary (+10) Literacy or Common Lore (Imperial Guard) Test confirms the convoy was an official Munitorum resupply run, lending legitimacy to claiming the cargo.

C. The Cargo Bay — The Prize

The rear cargo compartment is tilted at approximately thirty degrees but structurally sound. The exterior is scarred by claw marks and scorch damage from the original mutant attack, but the reinforced plasteel hull held. The cargo bay door is sealed with a standard Munitorum cipher-lock.

Opening the Lock: Requires a Challenging (+0) Security Test or a Hard (-20) Strength Test to force the corroded mechanism. An Acolyte with Common Lore (Munitorum) or Common Lore (Imperial Guard) recalls the standard emergency override codes, reducing the Security Test to Routine (+20).

Interior: Inside, crates are stacked and strapped to cargo rails, shifted by the angle but largely intact. Moisture-proof cases bear Munitorum stencils and Imperial Aquilas. The air inside is stale but dry — the seals held. Everything is covered in a fine layer of dust, undisturbed for decades.

D. The Surrounding Hillside

The hillside around the wreck is warp-mutant territory. Shallow caves in the scree serve as dens, littered with gnawed bones and scraps of corroded metal. A crude path through the rocks — barely visible — leads from the treeline to the transport's cargo bay, indicating the mutants have been circling the wreck for some time, unable to breach the Munitorum lock. Rock outcroppings at various elevations provide cover positions for both the Acolytes and their enemies. The upper map edge represents the fog ceiling — above this line, visibility drops to near zero.

Three-Phase Encounter

Phase 1 — The Pack: 2d5 Warp-Mutant Scavengers (use Warp-Mutant profiles with random minor mutations) are scattered across the hillside when the Acolytes arrive. They may already be attempting to breach the cargo bay, or they arrive drawn by noise shortly after the Acolytes open it. They are disorganised and desperate — starving creatures fighting over scraps. They attack on sight but break and flee if more than half their number are killed. One mutant, larger than the rest and bearing a crude lasgun with 1 charge remaining, serves as the pack alpha.

Phase 2 — Hillside Collapse: The noise of combat triggers a partial landslide. At the end of Round 3, all combatants must pass a Challenging (+0) Agility Test or be knocked Prone and swept 1d10 metres downhill, taking 1d10+3 I damage from tumbling rocks and scree. The cargo bay door is partially buried by displaced earth — clearing it requires a Challenging (+0) Strength Test (+10 if two Acolytes work together). This is the moment of maximum tension: the Acolytes are mid-combat, the ground is shifting beneath them, and the prize is slipping away.

Phase 3 — Observation: As the Acolytes secure the cargo, a servitor-skull descends from the fog overhead. Unlike the dead one bolted to the door, this skull is very much active: its optics glow red, its anti-grav unit hums softly, and it hovers just out of easy reach, panning slowly across the scene. It records everything. It does not intervene. After approximately one minute, it rises back into the fog and flies north — toward the Zarovich Spire. The skull has Ag 50 and TB 2, Wounds 6 if the Acolytes attempt to shoot it down. Destroying it changes nothing — Strahd has dozens — but it may make the Acolytes feel better.

Corruption and Insanity

  • Warp-flora contact: 1d5 Toxic damage (ignoring armour) on failed Routine (+20) Toughness
  • No significant Corruption or Insanity triggers at this location. The crashed transport is one of the rare "clean" sites on Barovus — no warp rituals, no daemonic presence, no psychic residue. This is intentional: the horror here is entirely mundane. Desperation, scarcity, and the knowledge that someone is always watching.

Loot and Items

See the Cargo Manifest table in Key Areas. This is a one-time supply cache — once claimed, it is gone. The GM should emphasise to the players that this is an exceptional find. Nothing else like it exists on Barovus. Additional minor salvage:

  • Forward cab: Damaged vox-caster (5km range, monitored frequency), laspistol (2 charges), driver's data-slate (partial route map, lore)
  • Mutant salvage: Crude weapons (negligible value), 1d5 ration packs (partially consumed, unappetising but edible), assorted scrap metal
  • Vehicle components: An Acolyte with Trade (Armourer) or Tech-Use can strip useful components — fuel cells (enough for a small generator or to recharge 2d10 lasgun packs), replacement armour plates, wire and cable (useful for field repairs and traps)

Quest Connections

  • Resupply: The cargo manifest represents the single largest equipment boost available in the campaign. Smart distribution of these supplies among the party is a tactical decision worth spending real time on.
  • Strahd's Interest: Strahd now knows the Acolytes have armed themselves from his claimed stockpile. He is not angry — the supplies are meaningless to him. He is interested. He may reference this during a future encounter: "I see you helped yourselves to my property. I do not mind. A well-equipped adversary is far more entertaining than a desperate one."
  • Fortress Vallak: The driver's data-slate and the cargo's Munitorum markings provide evidence that the Lord-Governor has been hoarding or neglecting Imperial supply lines — useful leverage in political dealings with Burgomaster Vallakovich or Lady Wachter.
  • Ongoing Surveillance: The servitor-skull observation establishes a pattern. From this point forward, the Acolytes should assume Strahd knows their approximate location and equipment status at all times. Paranoia is appropriate and should be encouraged.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd does not appear in person at the crash site. His presence is felt through the dead servitor-skull's territorial claim and the live servitor-skull's silent observation. The encounter is designed to make the Acolytes understand two things simultaneously: first, that Barovus is a world of scarcity where every bullet matters; and second, that Strahd's dominion extends even to abandoned wrecks on remote hillsides. Everything on Barovus belongs to him. The Acolytes are taking what is his. He allows it — because it serves his entertainment.

If the Acolytes have already drawn significant attention (destroyed the Warp-Tree, killed Strahd's forces in Fortress Vallak, etc.), the servitor-skull may carry a recorded message in Strahd's voice: "You continue to impress. Please — take what you need. I insist. The hunt is more satisfying when the quarry believes it has a chance." This message inflicts 1 Insanity Point (no save) from the casual, absolute certainty of a predator who has never been prey.

A Cargo-8 Ridgehauler — Departmento Munitorum long-haul transport — lies wedged into a hillside, half-buried in scree and corrosion. Part of an early resupply convoy ambushed by warp-mutants decades ago, it represents the single largest supply cache on Barovus outside Fortress Vallak. The locals avoid it because Strahd's servitor-skulls have marked it as his property. The Acolytes, as off-worlders, may not yet understand why that matters.

The distillery sprawls across a hillside of dead vineyards, a complex of stone buildings and fermentation towers connected by covered walkways and loading docks. In better days, it produced recaf and stimulant beverages for export across the subsector. Now it produces survival. The crops in its walled gardens are among the only reliable food sources on Barovus, and the recaf — thin, bitter, and never quite enough — is the closest thing to a luxury anyone has tasted in a generation. The distillery is also on fire. Thick black smoke rises from the eastern wing, and as you approach, the sounds of combat reach you: las-fire, screaming, and a rhythmic chanting that sets your teeth on edge.

Key FactDetail
ActAct II — The Domain of Dread
Map ReferenceMap 8 — 25x20 building interior

GM Overview

The Recaf Distillery is a vital supply point for the surviving settlements of Barovus — particularly Fortress Vallak, which depends on regular shipments of food and stimulants. It is operated by an extended branch of the Martikov family, the same warp-touched shapeshifters who run the Blue Water Inn in Fortress Vallak. When the Acolytes arrive, the distillery is under active assault by warp-corrupted flora — ambulatory vine-creatures animated by the same energy that feeds the Warp-Tree at the Nexus — and a raiding party of Nature-Corruption Devotees sent to ensure the distillery's destruction.

This location is the keystone of the campaign's supply and alliance systems. Liberating the distillery accomplishes three things simultaneously: it secures a reliable source of food, recaf, and medicinal herbs for the Acolytes and their allies; it launches the Three Sacred Seeds quest chain that spans three other major locations; and it forces the Acolytes to confront the Martikovs' secret — that their most valuable allies on Barovus are warp-touched mutants whose existence violates every tenet of Imperial doctrine. The moral dilemma is deliberate and has no clean resolution.

The distillery's unique properties — its crops grow despite the warp-corruption, its recaf has mild anti-corruption effects — derive from three sacred seeds blessed by a Ministorum saint centuries ago and planted in the distillery's soil. All three have been stolen, and the distillery is dying. Without at least one seed, the crops will fail within weeks and the last reliable food source on Barovus will be gone.

Key Areas

A. Perimeter Defences — Barricades and Watchtowers

The distillery complex is surrounded by a low stone wall — waist-height, originally designed to mark property boundaries rather than repel assault. The Martikovs have reinforced it with makeshift barricades: overturned carts, stacked barrels, sheets of corrugated plasteel scavenged from nearby ruins. Two crude watchtowers — little more than raised platforms with sandbag walls — stand at the eastern and western corners, each equipped with a mounted stubber (5 rounds remaining in each).

Breach Points: When the Acolytes arrive, the eastern barricade has been breached. Corrupted Plant-Forms are pouring through the gap, their root-limbs tearing at the stonework. The western barricade still holds but is under pressure — 1d5 Devotees are attempting to set it alight with crude incendiaries. An Acolyte who reaches the eastern breach can reinforce it with a Challenging (+0) Strength Test (pushing debris back into the gap) or by destroying the Plant-Forms in the breach zone.

The Watchtowers: Each tower is occupied by a Martikov family member with an autogun. The eastern tower's occupant is wounded and pinned down by Devotee fire. The western tower's occupant — Adrian Martikov, Davian's grandson — is holding his position but running low on ammunition. Reaching either tower requires crossing open ground under fire (Challenging (+0) Agility Test to avoid 1d10+3 I damage from Devotee autogun fire).

B. Main Distillery Floor — Processing Hall

The heart of the complex: a long, high-ceilinged stone hall filled with copper stills, fermentation vats, piping networks, and the heavy, aromatic scent of recaf processing. The machinery is old — three centuries old, in fact — but lovingly maintained by generations of Martikovs. Several vats are ruptured, their contents pooling on the flagstone floor in dark, steaming puddles. A Corrupted Plant-Form has infiltrated through a broken window and is growing into the machinery, its root tendrils wrapping around pipes and threatening to destroy the processing equipment.

The Processing Equipment: If the Plant-Form is not cleared from the machinery within 10 rounds of the Acolytes entering, it fuses permanently with the stills, rendering them inoperable. Clearing the Plant-Form from the machinery without damaging the equipment requires either careful melee work (Challenging (+0) WS with a called shot, or any attack that deals fire damage — the Plant-Form is Vulnerable to Fire, taking double damage) or a Hard (-20) Tech-Use Test to activate the emergency steam venting, which scalds the Plant-Form for 2d10 E damage but also risks damaging the pipes (10% chance).

Fermentation Vats: The large copper vats provide Heavy Cover (+8 AP to one location) but are pressurised — a stray shot that penetrates a vat causes it to rupture, spraying scalding liquid in a 3-metre radius (1d10 E damage, Ag Test to dodge). There are 6 intact vats; each can only rupture once.

C. Storage Cellars — Barrels and Hidden Passage

Below the main floor, accessed by a stone stairway, the cellars extend beneath the entire complex. Rows of recaf barrels line the walls — most are empty, a testament to how depleted the distillery's reserves have become. The air is cool, damp, and tinged with the earthy smell of aged recaf. Warp-flora has not penetrated here yet, making the cellars a relatively safe refuge for wounded Martikovs and non-combatants.

The Seed Vault: Behind a false wall at the cellar's deepest point lies a small chamber — the original planting room where the three sacred seeds were blessed and sown. The soil beds are empty, their sanctified earth grey and lifeless without the seeds. A faded Ministorum prayer scroll on the wall identifies the chamber's purpose: "By the Emperor's Grace, these seeds shall nourish the faithful and deny sustenance to the corrupt." Replanting a recovered seed here requires pressing it into the soil and reciting any Imperial prayer or litany — the seed does the rest, glowing golden as it takes root.

Hidden Passage: A narrow tunnel behind the seed vault leads to an exit point fifty metres outside the perimeter wall. The Martikovs use this as an escape route. An Ordinary (+10) Search Test reveals the tunnel if the Acolytes explore the cellars; the Martikovs will reveal it voluntarily if they trust the Acolytes.

D. Martikov Family Quarters — Upper Floor

The upper floor of the main building serves as living quarters for the extended Martikov family. Modest but clean rooms with hand-sewn furnishings, shelves of salvaged books, children's drawings pinned to walls, and a communal dining area. It is conspicuously normal — a reminder that people live here, raise families here, and are fighting to protect something that matters to them.

Davian's Study: The patriarch's private room contains a locked desk (Ordinary (+10) Security to pick, or Davian provides the key if trusted). Inside: a hand-drawn map of Barovus with Martikov raven-surveillance routes marked, a journal documenting Strahd's troop movements over the past decade, and a sealed letter addressed to "whoever comes after us" — a contingency confession of the family's shapeshifter nature, written in case they are killed, asking that whoever reads it understand they only ever wanted to protect the people of Barovus.

The Martikovs' Secret: During the battle to liberate the distillery, the Martikovs shift between human and raven form without thinking to hide it — diving from upper windows as ravens to scout enemy positions, shifting back to human form to relay information, carrying messages between watchtowers in avian form. If the Acolytes have not already learned the family's nature at the Blue Water Inn, this is the moment of revelation. The moral dilemma is immediate: these mutants are risking their lives to defend humanity. Doctrine demands their destruction. Pragmatism — and perhaps conscience — demands their preservation.

NPCs and Encounters

The Martikov Family — Warp-Touched Shapeshifters

Disposition: Cautious, loyal, frightened but resolute

Davian Martikov — Patriarch

An old man with sharp eyes and a raven's watchful stillness. Davian has led the family for four decades, coordinating their intelligence network across Barovus from this distillery and the Blue Water Inn. He is practical, unsentimental, and deeply protective of his family. He does not trust easily — the Acolytes must prove their opposition to Strahd through action, not words.

Disposition: Wary. Davian has seen outsiders before — Strahd has sent agents disguised as travelers. He will cooperate with the Acolytes during the siege out of necessity, but full trust requires completing the liberation and demonstrating genuine commitment to opposing the Lord-Governor.

What He Knows: The location of all three sacred seeds (one at the Warp Nexus, one with Baba Lysaga in Berez, one at the Zarovich Spire). Strahd's recent troop movements and patrol patterns. Van Richten's identity and location in Fortress Vallak. The political dynamics of every surviving settlement. He shares this intelligence incrementally, releasing more valuable information as trust increases.

What He Wants: The sacred seeds returned. The distillery secured. His family safe. In that order.

Adrian Martikov — Grandson, Scout

Young, reckless, and fiercely loyal to the family. Adrian is the distillery's best scout — fastest in raven form, sharpest eyes, and a talent for getting into places he should not be. He is manning the western watchtower when the Acolytes arrive and will be the first Martikov to interact with them during the siege.

Disposition: Eager. Adrian wants to fight Strahd. He sees the Acolytes as the warriors the family has been waiting for and may overshare information in his enthusiasm, earning a sharp rebuke from Davian.

Liberation Encounter

Objective: Clear the distillery of all hostile forces. This is a multi-front battle — the Acolytes must manage the eastern breach, the western barricade, the Plant-Form infiltration of the processing floor, and the Devotee fire from the treeline simultaneously.

Victory Conditions: The siege breaks when all Plant-Form swarms are destroyed and the Devotee raiding party is killed or routed. Devotees flee if their leader is killed or if they take 50% casualties. Plant-Forms continue mindlessly until destroyed.

Tactical Notes: Fire is the Acolytes' best weapon against the Plant-Forms. The fermentation vats contain alcohol-rich liquid that can be used as improvised incendiaries (Ordinary (+10) Intelligence to think of this; Challenging (+0) Agility to deploy without self-immolation). The Martikovs in raven form provide real-time intelligence on enemy positions — the GM should relay enemy movements to the players each round as the ravens report back. The hidden tunnel in the cellars can be used for flanking manoeuvres.

  • Martikov Raven Network: If the Martikovs trust the Acolytes, they provide ongoing intelligence via their raven surveillance network. Before entering any major location, the Acolytes receive accurate reconnaissance reports: enemy numbers, positions, and patrol routes. This is one of the most valuable strategic assets in the campaign.
  • Incidental Salvage: 2d5 autogun magazines, 1d5 frag grenades (taken from defeated Devotees), crude incendiaries (1d5, treat as fire bombs), miscellaneous tools and supplies.

Strahd's Presence

Strahd does not appear at the distillery in person — the location is beneath his direct attention, a minor nuisance rather than a threat. However, the Devotee raiding party was dispatched at his indirect behest. He tolerates the Nature-Corruption cult because their worship of the warp strengthens his domain, and he occasionally directs their aggression toward targets he wants destroyed without dirtying his own hands.

If the Acolytes liberate the distillery, Strahd takes note but does not retaliate immediately. He has patience measured in centuries. He may send a congratulatory message via servitor-skull: "How industrious. You have saved a recaf distillery. I confess I am almost moved. The Martikovs are useful creatures, are they not? Such loyalty. Such devotion. One almost forgets what they are." The implication is clear — he knows the Martikovs are mutants, and he is reminding the Acolytes that he could reveal this to the settlements at any time, destroying the trust the family has built over generations. This threat should hang over the Acolytes for the remainder of the campaign.

Encounter Guide

The Recaf Distillery is the last good thing on Barovus. A complex of stone buildings and fermentation towers on a hillside of dead vineyards, it produces the only reliable food and recaf on the planet. The Martikov family operates it — warp-touched shapeshifters (human/raven) who use their mutation in service to humanity. When the Acolytes arrive, the distillery is under active siege. Its unique properties derive from three sacred seeds blessed by a Ministorum saint centuries ago; two have been stolen, and the third is fading.

Approach and Siege

TypeCombat, Environmental

Environmental: The distillery is under active assault. Smoke and flames rise from the eastern wing, broken barriers litter the approach, and the sounds of las-fire and rhythmic chanting carry across the hillside. The dead vineyards provide limited cover.

The Martikovs are fighting but losing. During combat, the Martikovs shift between human and raven form without thinking to hide it — this reveals their secret if the Acolytes have not already learned it. The moral question lands immediately: mutants fighting for humanity.

Hydroponic Gardens
