Social: Martikov family members tend the gardens. Children play among the grow-beds. It is almost normal. Awareness (Ordinary +10) — the gardens are warded against warp influence by the remaining seed's power. The air is clean. The light seems warmer. This is what Barovus could be.

Discoveries: Botanical samples — Medicae (Challenging +0) or Trade (Apothecary) (Ordinary +10) to identify medicinal plants. 1d5 doses of healing herbs (equivalent to one medikit each). Belladonna grows here — anti-warp poultice, +10 vs Corruption for 1 hour per application.

GM Notes: A respite location. Let the players rest, heal, and be reminded of what they are fighting for. The Martikovs represent the best of humanity under impossible conditions — people who endure, who grow things, who raise children in a warp-blighted nightmare and refuse to stop living. After the horrors of the Nexus and the road, this place should feel like a blessing. That is the point.

The road dissolves into mud, and the mud dissolves into black water, and the black water stretches to the horizon under a sky the colour of a bruise. Berez was a village once. You can see the bones of it: hab-blocks reduced to crumbling walls protruding from the swamp like rotten teeth, a watchtower listing at a terminal angle, the rusted skeleton of a ground-car half-submerged in muck. The water glows at night — a sickly phosphorescent green that illuminates the underside of the fog and casts shadows that move against the light. Things wade through the shallows: bloated grey shapes with empty eyes and mouths open in silent screams. And somewhere deeper in, something massive is moving. You hear the groan of stressed metal, the squelch of enormous footfalls in deep mud, and a voice — old, cracked, singing a lullaby in a language you do not know but somehow understand.

Key FactDetail
ActAct II — The Domain of Dread
Map RefMap 9 (40×35 swamp/ruin grid)
Population / StatusNone living. Plague revenants, warp-fauna, and one ancient warp-hag
Primary ThreatBaba Lysaga (Psy Rating 7, Severe threat) and her walking hab-unit
Quest HooksRecover Sacred Seed #2; discover the Marina monument and the Tatyana reincarnation cycle; possible Tarot-designated artifact location; eliminate Lysaga as Strahd’s protector

Berez is a wound in the landscape of Barovus — a village drowned by its master’s rage and left to rot as a monument to his obsession. Approximately two centuries ago, a woman named Marina was born here, a previous reincarnation of Tatyana. When the villagers recognised her resemblance to the figure Strahd coveted and killed her in a desperate attempt to avoid his attention, the Lord-Governor’s fury manifested as a catastrophic psychic event that diverted a river, flooded the settlement, and slaughtered every living thing within it. The dead did not stay dead. They still wade through the black water, mindless and hungry, and the swamp itself has become saturated with warp energy so thick it is almost tangible.

The sole inhabitant of note is Baba Lysaga, the Warp-Hag — a being of impossible antiquity who claims to be Strahd’s spiritual mother. She dwells in a walking hab-unit that lurches through the swamp on massive mechanical legs, and she guards her domain with psychic powers of terrifying potency. Lysaga possesses the second sacred seed stolen from the Recaf Distillery, using its residual sanctity as fuel for her warp-rituals. She will not part with it willingly. She will not part with anything willingly. She considers every aspect of Strahd’s existence her personal charge, and she will destroy anyone she perceives as a threat to “her baby” with maternal ferocity that borders on the apocalyptic.

For the Game Master, Berez serves a dual narrative purpose. First, it is a high-danger combat location — Lysaga is one of the most dangerous non-Strahd enemies in the campaign, and arriving unprepared is a near-certain party kill. Second, the Marina monument at the centre of the ruins contains a critical lore revelation: the full cycle of Tatyana’s reincarnations across centuries, each life ending in tragedy orchestrated by Strahd’s obsession. If Ireena is present when this monument is discovered, the psychic resonance it triggers will change the trajectory of the entire campaign. The Acolytes should leave Berez waterlogged, battered, and haunted — but armed with knowledge that Strahd’s curse is far older and far more terrible than they imagined.

Key Areas

A1. The Approach — Swamp Roads

The road from Fortress Vallak deteriorates over two travel segments into a waterlogged track barely distinguishable from the surrounding marshland. The last half-segment has no road at all — only mudflats, stagnant pools, and dense banks of fog that reduce visibility to 15 metres. The air stinks of organic decay and something sweeter underneath: the cloying, chemical scent of warp-saturation.

Movement through the swamp is at half speed. All Agility-based Tests suffer −10 due to sucking mud, hidden sinkholes, and submerged debris. The water ranges from ankle-deep to waist-deep depending on the path chosen, and deeper channels exist that can swallow a fully armoured Acolyte without warning (Challenging (+0) Awareness Test to spot before stepping in; Challenging (+0) Strength Test to pull free if submerged). Plague revenants are encountered at a rate of 1d5 every 30 minutes of exploration — they rise from the water with little warning, and the terrain makes fighting them significantly more dangerous than on solid ground.

A2. The Ruined Settlement

The remains of Berez proper emerge from the waterline like the ribcage of a drowned giant. Walls of prefabricated Imperial hab-blocks jut from the black water at angles that speak of catastrophic subsidence. Rooftops that were once ground-level now serve as the only dry ground. Interior spaces are flooded, their contents reduced to sludge and corrosion, though occasionally a scavenging party can recover small items — a corroded data-slate, a waterlogged prayer book, a child’s toy fused with rust.

Navigation through the ruins requires a Challenging (+0) Navigate (Surface) or Survival Test to maintain direction. The ruins are disorienting: identical hab-block shells repeat in rows, the water reflects the perpetual grey sky so that up and down become uncertain, and the warp-glow beneath the surface creates the impression of structures continuing beneath the waterline — structures that were never there. Acolytes who fail navigation tests by three or more degrees find themselves circling back to their starting point, having lost 1d5 hours.

A3. Marina’s Monument

Near the centre of old Berez, on a raised platform of cracked rockcrete that still sits above the waterline, stands a stone marker approximately two metres tall. It is weathered but legible: a carved relief of a young woman’s face surrounded by Imperial aquilas and devotional script. The inscription reads, in faded High Gothic: “For Marina, who was loved too well by the wrong power. The Emperor protect her soul, for no one else could.”

The monument radiates a faint psychic resonance detectable by any psyker or any Acolyte who passes a Difficult (−10) Psyniscience Test. If Ireena Kolyana is present, the monument triggers a full psychic vision: Ireena (and all Acolytes within 5 metres) experiences a cascade of images and sensations — dozens of lives, each a woman with Tatyana’s face, each born on Barovus across the centuries, each found by Strahd, each ending in tragedy. Marina drowned. Another fell from the Spire. Another was burned as a witch. Another simply vanished. The vision lasts approximately one minute of real time but feels like hours. All who experience it gain 1d5 Insanity Points but also gain the knowledge that Strahd’s obsession is a cycle — Tatyana’s soul is reincarnated again and again, and Strahd has never once succeeded in claiming her. This information is critical for several of the Ireena endgame resolutions in Act IV.

A4. Baba Lysaga’s Walking Hab-Unit

The walking hab-unit is impossible to miss once encountered: a standard-pattern Imperial prefabricated dwelling module, approximately 8 metres long and 4 metres wide, mounted on four massive mechanical legs of uncertain origin. The legs are a fusion of industrial walker components, salvaged servitor limbs, and something organic — they flex and grip with an unsettling fluidity that no purely mechanical system should possess. The hab-unit’s exterior is festooned with fetishes: bones, defiled holy symbols, strips of flayed skin inscribed with warp-runes, and dozens of crude dolls made from mud and hair that Lysaga insists are “my baby’s toys.”

The hab-unit moves through the deepest parts of the swamp, its legs keeping the structure above the waterline. Lysaga occupies the upper compartment, which she has converted into a nauseating combination of living quarters, ritual chamber, and trophy room. The sacred seed from the Recaf Distillery is kept here, along with any Tarot-designated artifacts the GM has placed in Berez. A skull-mounted sentry gun is bolted to the hab-unit’s roof — a salvaged heavy stubber on an automated gimbal that Lysaga can direct with a thought (BS 35, 1d10+4 I, Pen 3, Full Auto, 60m range).

The interior stinks of spoiled food, rendered fat, and warp-ozone. Every surface is covered in wax, dried blood, and incomprehensible scrawl. Among the refuse, Acolytes who search carefully (Hard (−20) Search Test) can find fragments of genuine intelligence: old data-slates with records of Strahd’s early rule, handwritten observations of his behaviour spanning centuries, and — disturbingly — detailed notes on the Tatyana reincarnation cycle that suggest Lysaga has been tracking and, in some cases, manipulating it.

A5. The Dock Ruins

At the settlement’s eastern edge, the remnants of a small river dock project from the water. Before the flooding, Berez relied on river trade. Now the dock pilings are encrusted with something that is not quite fungus and not quite coral — a bioluminescent growth that pulses faintly in the green-lit darkness. A single flat-bottomed boat, miraculously intact, is tied to one of the pilings. It can carry up to four Acolytes and provides faster transit through the flooded ruins than wading (Ordinary (+10) Navigate (Surface) to handle it), but using it makes the party conspicuous and draws plague revenants from a wider radius.

NPCs and Encounters

Baba Lysaga — The Warp-Hag

Threat Rating: Severe | Psy Rating: 7 | Wounds: 30 | AP: 4 (warp-hardened flesh)

Lysaga is ancient beyond any natural human lifespan — centuries old, sustained by constant warp-infusion, her body a withered, twisted thing that should not be capable of movement, let alone the devastating psychic violence she unleashes. Her skin ripples and shifts as though something beneath it is trying to get out. Her fingers are too long. Her smile is too wide. Her eyes are solid black, depthless pools that reflect nothing. She was present at Strahd’s birth, served as his nursemaid, and claims with absolute conviction — and homicidal ferocity toward any who dispute it — that she is his true mother.

She made pacts with warp-entities before Strahd was born, shaping events across decades to ensure his rise to power. In her mind, everything she has done — every murder, every corruption, every abomination — has been an act of maternal love. This makes her not merely dangerous but tragic, in the way that only 40k villainy can be: a being whose devotion is genuine, absolute, and utterly insane.

Social Interaction: Lysaga will speak with the Acolytes briefly before attacking, but only if they do not mention Strahd in a threatening context. She responds well to flattery about her “son” and may provide information about Barovus’s history if the Acolytes pretend to admire Strahd’s rule (Very Hard (−30) Deceive Test). Any mention of harming, opposing, or “freeing” Strahd triggers immediate, berserk hostility. There is no diplomacy path that avoids combat if the Acolytes’ mission is known.

The swamp is full of them. Bloated, grey, leaking dark fluid, they rise from the water at a rate of 1d5 every 30 minutes. In combat with Lysaga, she can Animate Dead to summon 1d5 more per round. They attack with toxic fists/teeth (1d10+3 R, Toxic — Toughness test or 1d10 additional damage ignoring armour). They are Mindless, Shambling (act last in initiative, cannot Run), and Undying (on Critical Damage, roll 1d10: on 1–5 they ignore it; permanently destroyed only by fire, blessed weapons, or head destruction).

The miasma released when they are destroyed forces all within 3 metres to pass a Challenging (+0) Toughness Test or suffer 1d10 Toxic damage ignoring armour. In the close confines of the swamp, this creates a cascading hazard during large-scale engagements.

Combat Encounter: Lysaga’s Last Stand

This is a major boss encounter and should be treated as such. Lysaga fights from within her walking hab-unit, deploying psychic powers while the vehicle itself engages in melee. She is accompanied by 2d10 plague revenants at combat start, with reinforcements arriving via Animate Dead. Her warp-crow swarm provides additional area denial.

Terrain advantages favour Lysaga: deep water restricts Acolyte movement, unstable ground prevents stable firing positions, and limited cover means ranged attackers are exposed to her Warp Fire and Death’s Embrace. The Acolytes should be advised (through Van Richten, Vostra contacts, or their own reconnaissance) that Berez is a lethal location requiring preparation. Arriving without anti-armour weapons, blessed ammunition, or a solid tactical plan is a likely TPK.

Tactical Notes for the GM: Lysaga’s primary weakness is her emotional instability. She is insane, and her insanity can be exploited. Taunts about Strahd not loving her, claims that the Acolytes have Strahd’s blessing, or presenting a convincing forgery of a letter from Strahd (Very Hard (−30) Deceive) can cause her to hesitate for 1 round (stunned, processing emotional distress) or redirect her attacks toward the source of the emotional threat rather than the most tactically appropriate target. This is not a reliable strategy, but it can buy precious time.

Strahd’s Presence

Strahd does not appear personally in Berez unless the Acolytes are on the verge of killing Lysaga. He considers her a useful tool and an amusing relic, but he does not love her — a fact that would shatter her if she ever learned it. If the Acolytes are about to deliver the killing blow, there is a 25% chance Strahd intervenes via psychic projection: his voice echoes across the swamp, thanking the Acolytes for “pruning the old growth” and expressing mild regret that “Mother” could not adapt to the times. This intervention does not save Lysaga — it merely demonstrates Strahd’s casual cruelty and his willingness to discard even his most devoted servants. If Lysaga hears this, she suffers a psychic breakdown: stunned for 2 rounds, weeping, before fighting with renewed and utterly desperate fury (+10 to all combat tests, −20 to all defensive tests).

Strahd monitors the Acolytes’ progress through Berez via warp-crows and plague revenants serving as passive sensors. He is aware of their arrival within 1d5 hours and tracks their movements thereafter. If they recover the Marina monument’s revelation, he sends a letter via bat-servitor within 24 hours: a single line in elegant script — “Now you understand. She was always mine. She will always be mine.”

Encounter Guide

Berez was a village once. Two centuries ago, Strahd's rage over the death of Marina — a previous reincarnation of Tatyana — manifested as a catastrophic psychic event that diverted a river and drowned everything. The dead did not stay dead. Now it is a toxic swamp haunted by plague revenants, ruled by Baba Lysaga, and saturated with old warp-trauma. The water glows phosphorescent green at night, and somewhere in the swamp, a walking hab-unit lurches through the shallows while an ancient voice sings lullabies to a son who is not there.

Interrogator Vasek's Sealed Confession: "I am writing this in the knowledge that I will not leave this world. Nor should I. We came to destroy the Lord-Governor. We learned three things: the daemon-heart beneath his fortress sustains him, the blade called Dawn's Edge can wound him truly, and the Rosette of the Saint can bind his sorcery. Three conditions. We confirmed them all. And then the Inquisitor went to dinner. He went to dinner. With the creature. And when he came back... he said we should study it further. That we should understand it. That was three months ago. He has been to dinner four more times. I do not believe my Inquisitor serves the Emperor any longer. And so I write this, and I seal it, and I pray that whoever finds it is stronger than we were."

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour in the swamp. 1d5 IP from Vasek's confession — an Inquisitor turned by dinner conversation. If the Acolytes have been invited to dinner by Strahd, this should terrify them.

GM Notes: Rho-12's camp is the most mechanically valuable discovery site in the campaign. The partial Spire map and blessed unguent are tangible advantages. But Vasek's confession is the real payload — it confirms the three destruction conditions (daemon-heart, Dawn's Edge, Rosette) AND demonstrates how Strahd corrupts: not through force or sorcery, but through charm, hospitality, and the slow erosion of conviction. Let the players sit with that.

Drowned Village Ruins

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Environmental

Environmental: Submerged buildings, chest-deep water in places. Agility (Hard -20) to navigate the ruins without stumbling into hidden drops. Undercurrents — Strength (Challenging +0) or be pulled underwater for 1 round (suffocation rules apply). Hab-blocks reduced to crumbling walls, a leaning watchtower, rusted ground-car skeletons.

Discoveries: Pre-destruction village layout visible beneath the waterline. Awareness (Challenging +0): a waterlogged Imperial shrine — the aquila still visible above the water. A child's toy floating in the current. Evidence of systematic destruction — not natural flooding, but deliberate psychic wrath. The flooding pattern is radial, centred on the village square. This was not a river diversion. This was an execution.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP (the ruins radiate old warp-trauma, soaked into the stones and water). 1d5 IP from the realisation of what happened here — an entire village drowned because one woman resembled a dead girl, and the villagers tried to save themselves by killing her.

GM Notes: Berez was destroyed because Marina lived here. The environmental horror is sadness, not monsters. Let the mundane details do the work — the shrine, the toy, the walls of homes where families lived. The plague revenants wading through the ruins were those families. Do not rush this area. Silence is more effective than narration.

Marina's Monument

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Faith Test

Faith Test: A crude monument to Marina near the centre of old Berez, maintained by someone (Lysaga). Psyniscience (Challenging +0): psychic resonance saturates the monument. If Ireena is present, she feels a pull — recognition, fragments of memory, a name that is hers and not hers. Willpower (Hard -20) for Ireena or she speaks Marina's words involuntarily, describing the village, the fear, the mob, and the water rising.

Discovery: The monument reveals the reincarnation cycle — Marina, Tatyana, now Ireena. Dozens of lives, each ending in tragedy. Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Challenging +0) to understand the mechanism: Slaanesh keeps reincarnating the soul as bait for Strahd, perpetuating his torment and feeding on his obsession. The cycle is the pact's engine — Strahd's suffering is the fuel.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP (warp-resonance at the monument). 1d10 IP if Ireena channels Marina — witnessing involuntary possession is deeply disturbing, especially when the possessed voice describes its own murder with calm acceptance.

GM Notes: This is a lore-critical discovery. The reincarnation cycle is central to the campaign's themes and to understanding the possible endings. If Ireena is present, this scene is electrifying — play it as a quiet horror moment, not a dramatic one. If she is not present, the monument still provides the intelligence through inscriptions and psychic residue, but lacks the emotional impact. Encourage the party to bring Ireena here.

Lysaga's Walking Hab-Unit

RiskDeadly
TypeCombat

Enemies: Baba Lysaga (Warp-Hag, Psy Rating 5, WP 75, 40 Wounds) rides inside her walking hab-unit (Structural Integrity 30, Armour 20, stomp attack: S 60, 2d10+12 I damage, Concussive). The hab-unit is animated by warp-energy, mounted on massive mechanical legs — it lurches through the swamp like a living thing. Lysaga casts from inside using Biomancy, Telekinesis, and Telepathy, plus unique powers: Swarm of Crows (1d10 R damage/round, 10m radius, obscures vision), Death's Embrace (30m, 2d10+5 E damage, Pen 5, Warp Weapon), and Animate Dead (raises 1d5 plague revenants per round from the swamp). Accompanied by 2d10 plague revenants and warp-crows.

Skill Challenges: Tracking the hab-unit: Survival (Challenging +0) or Awareness (Challenging +0) — the tracks are enormous but the swamp fills them with water. Alternatively, follow the sound of her singing. Boarding the hab while it moves: Athletics (Very Hard -30).

Environmental: Deep water, unstable ground, limited cover. The terrain favours Lysaga entirely. Movement at half speed. Heavy armour wearers sink faster.

Scaling: Lysaga is a solo boss with the hab as a vehicle. For 3 Acolytes: reduce hab SI to 22 and Lysaga's Wounds to 30. For 6+: add 3 Warp-Mutant attendants and increase hab SI to 35.

Corruption/Insanity: 3 CP from combat with a Psy Rating 5 warp entity. 1d5 IP from the walking hab (a building should not walk — it is fundamentally wrong, a prefab housing module lurching on mechanical legs through chest-deep water while a centuries-old crone sings lullabies from inside).

GM Notes: This is one of the hardest non-Strahd encounters in the campaign. The hab-unit is meant to be a siege — slow, grinding, terrifying. Lysaga is protected inside it and rains destruction while plague revenants swarm from the water. Creative solutions should be rewarded: fire (the hab is partially wood), undermining the legs (attacking joints, Called Shot), boarding (desperate but effective), or drawing Lysaga out with provocation about Strahd (she is fanatically devoted and can be goaded). Arriving unprepared is a likely TPK.

Sacred Seed Cache

RiskDangerous
TypeSkill Challenge, Investigation

Skill Challenges: After defeating Lysaga, Tech-Use (Challenging +0) or Psyniscience (Hard -20) to locate Sacred Seed #2 within the hab wreckage. Security (Challenging +0) to extract it from its warded container without damage.

Investigation: Lysaga's notes (if the hab is intact enough to search): she worshipped Strahd as her son — delusional maternal obsession. Her research on the reincarnation cycle reveals she was trying to END it, not for Tatyana's sake, but to remove the distraction from her "son." Twisted maternal love taken to its logical extreme. Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) to decipher the notes — yields insight into the daemonic pact mechanics and may reveal details about the Empyrean Vault's true nature.

Discoveries: Sacred Seed #2. Lysaga's research notes. Collection of souls in jars — each jar costs 1 CP to open (warp-tainted container), but contains a trapped spirit that can be released with prayer. Each soul released removes 1 IP from the releaser. Net result depends on faith.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP from handling warp-tainted materials. Soul jars: 1 CP per jar opened, -1 IP per soul released through prayer. The balance is deliberate — mercy has a cost, but faith has a reward.

GM Notes: The soul jars are a CP/IP balance mechanic. Players who open jars and pray pay corruption but recover sanity; those who leave them sealed avoid corruption but leave souls trapped. There is no clean answer. Lysaga's notes are supplementary lore but valuable — they confirm the reincarnation cycle from the antagonist's perspective and may hint at the Empyrean Vault's connection to the pact. Sacred Seed #2 is the primary objective; ensure the party knows it exists before they leave Berez.

The cold is the first thing you notice. Not the cold of winter or of void-exposure but the cold of absence — as though heat itself has been consumed, drained from the air and the stone and your bones by something unspeakably hungry. Your breath crystallises instantly. Frost forms on your armour, your weapons, your eyelashes. The entrance to the Vault is a wound in the mountainside: a door twenty metres tall, carved from a single piece of material that is not stone, not metal, not crystal, but something that shares properties with all three. Its surface is covered in script — angular, flowing, beautiful, and utterly alien. No human hand carved these words. No human mind conceived them. They were old when humanity was young. The door stands open. It has stood open for a very long time. Beyond it, darkness — not the absence of light but the presence of dark, a tangible, breathing thing that presses against your lamp-packs and lumen-globes like a living membrane. And from somewhere deep within, you hear whispering. Dozens of voices. Hundreds. Offering things you have not asked for, promising everything, demanding only that you listen.

Key FactDetail
ActAct II — The Domain of Dread
Map RefMap 10 (45×35 multi-level dungeon, 3 levels)
Population / StatusNo living inhabitants. Degraded xenos constructs, bound daemons, one fragmentary AI
Primary ThreatBound daemons (psychic lures and pact temptation), Vault Guardian constructs, lethal cold, Corruption accumulation
Quest HooksDiscover Strahd’s pact and destruction conditions (Cell Alpha-Prime); resist or accept daemon pacts; guide Kasimir to his sister’s cell; possible Tarot-designated artifact location

The Empyrean Vault is the oldest structure on Barovus — older than the Imperium, older than human civilisation on this world, older perhaps than humanity itself. It was constructed by a xenos species of immense technological and psychic sophistication as a containment facility for warp entities too dangerous to destroy and too valuable to ignore. The entities were sealed in chambers of psycho-reactive material that dampened their power and prevented their escape. The facility has been deteriorating for millennia. The wards are weakening. The entities within are stirring.

And Strahd von Zarovich, centuries ago, came here and made the pact that damned him and his entire world.

For the Acolytes, the Empyrean Vault represents the campaign’s most critical revelation and its most dangerous temptation in a single location. Cell Alpha-Prime — the shattered containment chamber where Strahd bargained with a Daemon Prince of Slaanesh — contains the psychic imprint of the pact itself, revealing how Strahd was made immortal and, crucially, how that immortality can be severed. This is the information the Acolytes need to win. But to reach it, they must walk through a gauntlet of containment cells, each holding an ancient daemon that has had millennia to perfect the art of temptation. Every cell they pass whispers to them. Every daemon offers power tailored to their deepest desires and fears. Some Acolytes will accept. The Corruption cost is severe. The consequences are permanent. And the Game Master should make every offer genuinely, achingly tempting — because the horror of the Vault is not that daemons offer power, but that the power is real, and the price is one that desperate people, fighting a war they are losing, might rationally choose to pay.

The Vault is also where Kasimir Velikov seeks to resurrect his murdered sister, Patrina, using the power of a bound entity. His quest is genuine, his grief is real, and the outcome will be catastrophic. The Acolytes must decide how to handle his desperation — and whether their own desperation justifies similar bargains.

Key Areas

B1. The Mountain Approach

The Empyrean Vault sits high in the mountains of Barovus, accessible only through a series of passes that are lethal to the unprepared. The journey from any settlement takes 4 travel segments — the longest overland route in the campaign. The passes are exposed, windswept, and bitterly cold. Acolytes suffer 1d10 Energy damage (ignoring armour) per hour of exposure without adequate cold-weather gear. A Challenging (+0) Survival Test each hour reduces this damage by half. Appropriate cold-weather equipment (fur cloaks, thermal undersuits, void-suit heating elements) negates the damage entirely for the first 6 hours, after which the supernatural cold begins to overwhelm even the best gear (half damage thereafter).

The passes are patrolled by Vault Guardian constructs: xenos automatons still functioning on degraded power cells after millennia. Use modified Combat Servitor profiles with las-weapons (40m, S/2/—, 1d10+4 E, Pen 2) and force-field generators (Protection Rating 30). They attack anything that approaches without authorisation — and the only being who ever had authorisation was Strahd, centuries ago. There are 2d5 guardians scattered along the approach, typically encountered in pairs.

Avalanche risk is present on two sections of the approach. The GM should call for a Challenging (+0) Awareness Test to detect warning signs (cracking ice, shifting snowpack). If an avalanche triggers, all Acolytes must pass a Hard (−20) Agility Test or suffer 3d10 I damage and be buried (requiring a Challenging (+0) Strength Test or outside assistance to dig free; buried Acolytes suffer suffocation rules).

B2. The Entry Hall

The twenty-metre door opens into a chamber of staggering scale: a vaulted hall at least fifty metres long and thirty metres high, carved from the same alien material as the door. The walls curve in ways that defy Euclidean geometry — corners that should be ninety degrees are slightly more or slightly less, and the effect is subtly nauseating. Alien script covers every surface, pulsing with a faint bioluminescence that provides dim illumination in shades of blue-white.

At the far end of the hall, a flickering hololithic projection manifests when the Acolytes enter: the Vault Guardian AI. It is a vaguely humanoid figure, approximately three metres tall, composed of shifting geometric shapes. It speaks in halting, corrupted Low Gothic — learned from Strahd’s visit centuries ago — and its voice echoes with harmonic undertones that suggest the original language was far more complex.

The AI addresses the Acolytes as “specimens” or “subjects” and asks their purpose. It has lost most of its memory and function but can provide fragmentary information about the Vault’s layout, the nature of the bound entities, and the history of Strahd’s visit. Treating it with patience and respect (Challenging (+0) Fellowship Tests) yields better information than threats. Key information the AI can provide:

  • The Vault contains “many dozens” of containment cells; most remain sealed and functional
  • Five cells are accessible and contain entities that “actively communicate”
  • One cell — “designation Alpha-Prime” — has suffered “catastrophic containment failure”
  • A “subject” matching Strahd’s description visited “a significant duration ago” and “breached protocol”
  • The AI cannot prevent the Acolytes from entering any area but warns that “interaction with contained specimens is inadvisable for species of your psychic tolerance”

B3. The Containment Corridor (Level 2)

Below the entry hall, a spiralling ramp descends into the mountain’s heart. The temperature drops further with each level. The whispers grow louder. The corridor branches into individual cell antechambers, each sealed by a shimmering energy barrier of psycho-reactive material that dampens the entity within. The barriers are translucent: the Acolytes can see something moving behind each one, but the shapes refuse to resolve into anything comprehensible.

Simply passing a cell requires a Challenging (+0) Willpower Test. Failure means the Acolyte stops to listen. Stopping to listen requires a Hard (−20) Willpower Test to resist accepting the pact offered. The GM should roleplay each entity’s offer with maximum persuasive force — these are ancient, intelligent beings that have had millennia to perfect their pitch. They know the Acolytes’ names. They know their fears. They know exactly what each one needs most desperately.

The five accessible containment cells are detailed in the Daemon Pacts page. Cell Alpha-Prime is on Level 3.

B4. The Central Nexus (Level 2)

At the hub of the containment corridor, a circular chamber serves as the Vault’s operational centre. Alien control surfaces — smooth, organic panels that respond to touch with ripples of light — line the walls. Most are non-functional. A few still display information in the xenos script, which can be partially translated with a Very Hard (−30) Forbidden Lore (Xenos) Test. Successful translation reveals containment status readouts: most cells are listed as “STABLE / DEGRADING”, a few as “CRITICAL”, and one — Alpha-Prime — as “BREACHED / SUBJECT ABSENT.”

The nexus also contains physical storage: xenos containers holding tools, components, and materials of uncertain purpose. Among the alien detritus, Acolytes who search (Hard (−20) Search) may find relics of previous human visitors — an Inquisitorial rosette from an operative who came centuries ago and never left, corroded data-slates with partial records of earlier expeditions, and a hexagrammic ward amulet that still functions (+10 WP vs. daemonic psychic powers).

B5. Cell Alpha-Prime (Level 3)

The deepest chamber in the Vault. The containment barrier is shattered — fragments of psycho-reactive material litter the floor like broken stained glass, still faintly glowing. The cell itself is empty. The daemon that was held here is gone, claimed by a pact fulfilled centuries ago. But the cell is far from inert.

Touching the walls triggers a sensory flashback to the moment of Strahd’s pact. All Acolytes within the cell experience it simultaneously: a vision of Strahd as he was — younger, still human, still a proud Imperial officer — standing before a manifestation of the Daemon Prince of Slaanesh. The vision reveals three critical pieces of intelligence:

  • The Daemon Prince’s name — knowing a daemon’s true name grants power over it but draws its attention. Gain 1d5 Corruption Points from the knowledge alone. The name can be used in Act IV to disrupt Strahd’s connection to the Daemon Prince during the final confrontation.
  • The pact’s terms — Strahd received immortality, psychic dominion over Barovus, and the warp rift that seals his domain. In exchange, the Daemon Prince feeds on the psychic suffering of Barovus’s entire population, channelled through Strahd as a conduit, for eternity.
  • The pact’s weakness — the pact is anchored to Strahd’s soul. Destroying his physical form is insufficient; his soul reforms. The pact must be severed at its source. This requires three conditions: the relic power sword Dawn’s Edge (sanctified to sever warp-pacts) must strike the killing blow; the Rosette of Saint Markovia must be active and in proximity (suppressing his regeneration and warp-phase abilities); and the Heart of the Spire — the warp-crystal sustaining his fortress — must be destroyed first, severing his lair’s power.

This is the campaign’s central revelation. The Acolytes now know what they need and, in broad terms, where to find it. The Alpha-Prime vision also inflicts 2d10 Insanity Points on all who witness it (reduced to 1d10 on a successful Hard (−20) Willpower Test) — the psychic imprint of a Daemon Prince’s presence is not something mortal minds process cleanly.

B6. Kasimir’s Objective — Cell Kappa-4

A sealed containment cell on Level 2, indistinguishable from the others except that Kasimir has spent decades studying it from the outside. The entity within claims it can raise the dead. It can. Kasimir’s sister Patrina was murdered, and he believes this entity is his only hope of restoring her. He is correct about the entity’s capability. He is catastrophically wrong about the cost.

If the Acolytes help Kasimir access the cell, the entity raises Patrina — but she returns as a warp-tainted being: beautiful, powerful, and utterly corrupted. She possesses Psy Rating 4 and knowledge of the Vault’s secrets, making her a valuable but deeply dangerous potential ally. She may serve the Acolytes’ interests, or she may serve Strahd’s, or she may serve only herself. Kasimir, blinded by love and guilt, cannot see what she has become.

NPCs and Encounters

Kasimir Velikov — The Penitent Scholar

Kasimir is a tall, gaunt figure with an air of exhausted obsession. He has spent decades studying the Empyrean Vault from the outside, mapping its approach routes, cataloguing the xenos script on its exterior, and listening to the whispers that carry on the mountain wind. He approaches the Acolytes with a desperate bargain: he will guide them to the Vault — providing +20 to Navigation tests on the approach and +20 to Forbidden Lore (Xenos) tests within the Vault — if they help him access Cell Kappa-4 and resurrect his sister.

Social Interaction: Kasimir is not a villain. He is a grief-stricken scholar who has convinced himself that the end justifies the means. He is honest about the Vault’s dangers (he has seen others die on the approach), helpful with xenos lore, and genuinely grateful for the Acolytes’ assistance. He is also in denial about the cost of the resurrection. If the Acolytes attempt to dissuade him, he resists with increasing desperation (Opposed Willpower Tests; his WP is 55, and his conviction is absolute). If they physically prevent him from reaching Cell Kappa-4, he becomes hostile — not violently (he is no warrior) but diplomatically: he withdraws his guidance, potentially sabotages their navigation, and may attempt to return to the Vault alone.

If Kasimir succeeds: Patrina returns. She is lucid, articulate, and grateful — and she radiates a faint warp-taint that any psyker or Acolyte with Psyniscience can detect (Ordinary (+10) Psyniscience). She possesses knowledge of the Vault’s deeper secrets and can provide +10 to tests related to the containment cells and their entities. She is also a potential long-term threat: in Act III or IV, she may attempt to claim power for herself, betray the Acolytes to Strahd in exchange for dominion over Berez, or simply disappear into the Vault to continue her own research. The GM should treat Patrina as a ticking time bomb whose detonation timing is a narrative choice.

The Vault Guardian AI

The fragmentary intelligence that once managed the containment facility. It manifests as a flickering hololithic figure in the entry hall and occasionally in the central nexus. It is not hostile but is deeply confused by the passage of time and the degradation of its own memory. It refers to the bound entities as “specimens” and to the Acolytes as “unauthorised biological subjects.”

Information the AI can provide (each requires a successful Challenging (+0) Fellowship Test, representing patient, respectful communication):

  • General layout of the Vault (grants +10 to Navigate tests within the facility)
  • The nature of the containment system (psycho-reactive wards that dampen warp energy; they are failing)
  • Confirmation that “Specimen Alpha-Prime” escaped its containment via “an external catalyst” (Strahd)
  • A partial list of the other contained entities and their “risk classifications” (Tzeentch: “Psychic Hazard, Class VII”; Nurgle: “Biological Hazard, Class V”; Khorne: “Kinetic Hazard, Class IX”; Slaanesh: “Memetic Hazard, Class VIII”; Unknown: “Classification Error / Data Corrupt”)
  • A warning that “interaction with specimens accelerates containment degradation” — each pact accepted weakens the facility further

Vault Guardian Constructs

Threat Rating: Challenging | Wounds: 20 | AP: 6 (xenos alloy) | Protection Rating: 30 (force field)

Automated xenos security drones that patrol the mountain approach and, less frequently, the interior corridors. They resemble angular, insectoid forms approximately 1.5 metres tall, hovering on anti-grav units. Their weapons are las-based but of alien design (40m, S/2/—, 1d10+4 E, Pen 2). Their force fields are their primary defence: any hit must first overcome the Protection Rating (roll d100; if the roll is equal to or under 30, the shot is deflected entirely). They are not warp entities and are unaffected by blessed weapons or psychic attacks — they are purely technological, albeit of alien technology.

On the approach: 2d5 constructs total, encountered in pairs. Inside the Vault: 1d5 constructs patrol the corridors on a random schedule (encounter check every 30 minutes of exploration; constructs appear on a roll of 1–25 on d100).

Encounter: The Gauntlet of Whispers

As the Acolytes traverse the containment corridor on Level 2, each cell they pass constitutes an encounter. The bound entities are aware of the Acolytes’ presence and tailor their psychic lures to each individual. The GM should describe the sensations each Acolyte experiences as they pass each cell:

  • Cell Sigma-3 (Tzeentch): The Acolyte sees visions of perfect tactical clarity — Strahd’s weaknesses laid bare, every trap in the Spire revealed, every enemy’s position known. Knowledge without limit. Understanding without effort.
  • Cell Theta-7 (Nurgle): The Acolyte feels their wounds close, their fatigue lift, their body surge with vitality. The promise of never being hurt again. Never being sick. Never dying. Comfort. Peace. Endurance.
  • Cell Omega-1 (Khorne): The Acolyte’s blood sings with power. Their arms feel stronger, their reflexes sharper, their instincts honed to a killing edge. The certainty that no enemy could stand before them. That they could cut their way through Strahd’s army single-handed.
  • Cell Phi-9 (Slaanesh): The Acolyte hears their name whispered with adoration. They feel understood, desired, valued. The power to make others see them as they wish to be seen. To command loyalty, devotion, obedience — simply by willing it.
  • Cell Lambda-12 (Unknown): Silence. A profound, absolute absence of sensation. Then a single thought, not the Acolyte’s own: You could live forever. You could outlast everything. Even him.

Each lure requires the Willpower tests described above. The GM should personalise the offers further based on each Acolyte’s background, flaws, and current situation — a wounded Acolyte is more susceptible to Nurgle’s offer, a frustrated commander to Tzeentch’s, a grieving one to the Unknown’s.

Strahd’s Presence

Strahd does not appear at the Empyrean Vault. He avoids it. The Vault is the one place on Barovus where he made himself vulnerable, and the psychic imprint of his moment of desperation — the moment he was merely human, bargaining for power he did not yet possess — is not a memory he wishes to revisit. He does not send agents here. He does not scry here. The Vault’s xenos wards, even in their degraded state, partially block his psychic surveillance.

This means the Acolytes are, for the first and possibly only time in the campaign, genuinely beyond Strahd’s observation. They can plan, discuss, and make decisions without his knowledge. This should feel both liberating and deeply unsettling — the absence of his attention is itself a kind of horror, because it means even the master of Barovus fears something about this place.

However, if any Acolyte accepts a Slaanesh pact (Cell Phi-9), Strahd can sense that Acolyte’s location at all times thereafter, even within the Vault. The Acolyte has, in accepting the pact, tuned themselves to the same warp-frequency as Strahd’s own connection. He will know. And he will be very interested.

Daemon Pacts — The Containment Cells

Each of the five accessible containment cells holds a bound warp entity that actively offers a pact to any mortal who stops to listen. The pacts are real: the benefits are genuine and immediate, and the costs are severe and permanent. The Game Master should roleplay each entity’s offer with maximum persuasiveness. These are ancient, intelligent beings that have had millennia to refine their approach. They do not threaten. They do not bluster. They simply offer exactly what the Acolyte needs most, in exactly the terms they are most likely to accept.

Mechanical Framework: Any Acolyte who accepts a pact gains the listed benefits immediately. Corruption Points are applied immediately and may trigger mutations (roll on the Mutation Table if the Acolyte’s total Corruption exceeds their Willpower Bonus × 10). The accepting Acolyte also gains a Secret Condition: a behavioural compulsion known only to the accepting player and the GM. This condition creates tension and roleplay opportunities for the remainder of the campaign.

Cell Sigma-3 — “The Whispered Answer” (Daemon of Tzeentch)

The air shimmers behind the barrier. A voice like rustling parchment speaks from everywhere and nowhere, finishing the Acolyte’s thoughts before they form. It knows their name. It knows their mission. It knows what they do not.

AspectDetail
OfferKnowledge. The entity reveals the complete layout of the Zarovich Spire, including all traps, guard positions, secret passages, and the locations of the Heart of the Spire and Strahd’s coffin. The Acolyte retains this information as perfect, eidetic recall.
Corruption Cost2d10 Corruption Points
Additional Cost — MutationThe Acolyte gains one Minor Mutation (roll on the Mutation Table)
Secret ConditionCompulsive Curiosity. The Acolyte must pass a Willpower Test at −20 to resist investigating any anomalous phenomenon, forbidden text, sealed door, or unknown signal they encounter. Failure means they must investigate, regardless of tactical considerations or party consensus.

GM Notes: This pact has the highest tactical value for the party and the lowest apparent immediate cost. The Spire intelligence is genuinely accurate and saves the Acolytes potentially lethal trial-and-error in Act III. The compulsion, however, will drive the Acolyte into dangerous situations repeatedly — especially within the Spire itself, where curiosity can be fatal.

Cell Theta-7 — “The Undying Gift” (Daemon of Nurgle)

Warmth seeps through the barrier. Not the warmth of fire but the warmth of a body, of a fever, of life refusing to end. The Acolyte’s aches fade. Old scars tingle. A voice like a grandfather’s murmur promises that pain is simply a problem that has already been solved.

AspectDetail
OfferResilience. The Acolyte gains the Regeneration (5) trait and becomes completely immune to disease and poison.
Corruption Cost2d10 Corruption Points
Additional Cost — PhysicalThe Acolyte’s flesh becomes grey and numb. Reduce Fellowship by 15. They exude a faint aura of decay: −10 to all social interactions with non-corrupted individuals.
Secret ConditionAcceptance of Decay. The Acolyte becomes subtly indifferent to suffering — their own and others’. They must pass a Willpower Test at −10 to provide urgent medical aid, rush to a fallen comrade, or prioritise healing over other actions. Pain and death begin to feel … natural.

GM Notes: Regeneration (5) is enormously powerful in a campaign where medical supplies are scarce. The Fellowship reduction and social penalty make the Acolyte increasingly isolated from allies and NPCs. The secret condition subtly undermines team cohesion as the Acolyte becomes less responsive to emergencies.

Cell Omega-1 — “The Red Blessing” (Daemon of Khorne)

The barrier pulses like a heartbeat. The Acolyte’s pulse synchronises with it. Their muscles tense. Their hands flex. A wordless roar of exultation echoes through their skull, and for one perfect instant they feel what it would be like to be the strongest thing in any room they enter. The entity does not speak in words. It speaks in the language of adrenaline, sinew, and broken bones.

AspectDetail
OfferMartial Fury. The Acolyte gains +20 to Weapon Skill, +2 to Strength Bonus, and the Frenzy talent (if not already possessed).
Corruption Cost2d10 Corruption Points
Additional Cost — PhysicalThe Acolyte’s eyes permanently burn with a faint red glow, visible in low light. This is immediately noticeable and unsettling to anyone who sees them.
Secret ConditionBlood Compulsion. When the Acolyte witnesses violence — any violence, including combat initiated by allies — they must pass a Willpower Test at −10 or be compelled to join the fight with melee attacks, prioritising the nearest target regardless of allegiance. This includes brawls, executions, training sparring, and even animal fights.

GM Notes: The raw combat statistics are significant — +20 WS and +2 SB transforms a mediocre combatant into a formidable one. The compulsion is the trap: in a campaign with frequent violence, the Acolyte will regularly lose control. Friendly fire incidents are nearly inevitable, and the red glow makes it impossible to hide what they have become from observant NPCs.

Cell Phi-9 — “The Perfect Moment” (Daemon of Slaanesh)

The barrier does not shimmer or pulse. It sings. A single, sustained note of such exquisite beauty that it bypasses the ears entirely and resonates in the Acolyte’s soul. The entity’s voice is warm, intimate, knowing. It uses the Acolyte’s name like a caress. It speaks of understanding, of being truly seen, of the loneliness of duty and the sweetness of being obeyed.

AspectDetail
OfferDomination. The Acolyte gains a psychic ability equivalent to the Dominate power (Willpower Test, range 20m, target obeys a single command). This works even on non-psykers. The Acolyte does not need to be a psyker to use this ability.
Corruption Cost3d10 Corruption Points — the highest cost among the four named daemons. Slaanesh’s gifts are the most expensive on a world already saturated with Slaaneshi influence.
Additional Cost — SurveillanceStrahd can sense the Acolyte’s location at all times — the Acolyte has tuned to the same warp-frequency as Strahd’s pact. This is not detectable by the Acolyte. They will not know Strahd can track them until it becomes apparent through his actions.
Secret ConditionAddiction to Control. The Acolyte must pass a Willpower Test at −20 to resist using Dominate in any social confrontation — negotiations, arguments, interrogations, even disagreements with allies. The sensation of imposing their will on another is intoxicating, and each use makes the next resistance harder (−5 cumulative penalty per use).

GM Notes: This is the most insidious pact. The Dominate ability is extraordinarily useful in a campaign heavy with social encounters and NPC manipulation. The 3d10 CP cost is potentially campaign-ending (an unlucky roll could push an Acolyte past the 100 CP threshold immediately). The surveillance cost is the true danger: Strahd gains perfect intelligence on one member of the party at all times, which he will use to devastating effect in Act III. The escalating Willpower penalty means the Acolyte will eventually be unable to resist using the power, turning every social interaction into an act of psychic domination.

Cell Lambda-12 — “The Hollow Crown” (Unknown Entity)

There is nothing behind this barrier. No light, no sound, no presence. Only void. And then, between one heartbeat and the next, a thought that is not the Acolyte’s own: a vast, patient, ancient intelligence that has waited longer than star-systems for someone to ask the right question. It does not offer. It simply states a fact: you will die. Everything you love will die. Unless.

AspectDetail
OfferImmortality. The Acolyte ceases to age and gains the Undying trait: they cannot be killed by normal means. When reduced to 0 Wounds, the Acolyte’s body regenerates over 1d5 hours, returning to full Wounds. Only weapons specifically consecrated to sever warp-pacts (Dawn’s Edge) can permanently kill them.
Corruption Cost3d10 Corruption Points
Additional Cost — BindingThe Acolyte’s soul is bound to Barovus. They can never leave, even if the warp rift is closed. If the campaign ends with the rift collapsing, this Acolyte does not escape. They remain, alone, on a world that may or may not survive.
Secret ConditionErosion of Identity. The entity’s voice persists in the Acolyte’s mind, growing louder in moments of weakness (when Wounded, fatigued, or emotionally distressed). It does not command — it suggests, questions, undermines. “Why do you serve them? They will forget you. I will not.” The Acolyte must pass a Willpower Test at −10 (increasing by −5 each subsequent time) or act on the entity’s suggestion for 1 round.

GM Notes: This is the most narratively devastating pact. The Undying trait makes the Acolyte nearly unkillable, which is enormously powerful in the short term. The soul-binding means there is no happy ending for this character — they have traded escape for survival, which is the central tragic bargain of Barovus itself. The identity erosion provides a slow-burn horror arc as the Acolyte gradually becomes less themselves and more … something else. The entity’s nature is deliberately left undefined; the GM may decide it is a C’tan shard, a fragment of a deceased Chaos God, an Old One remnant, or something entirely novel.

Cell Alpha-Prime — Strahd’s Pact Site (No Pact Available)

This cell is open. The barrier is shattered. What was held here is gone, released into the world centuries ago. But the walls remember.

AspectDetail
EntityNone present. Formerly contained a Daemon Prince of Slaanesh, now bound to Strahd’s pact and feeding on Barovus’s suffering.
RevelationTouching the walls triggers a psychic flashback. All Acolytes within the cell witness Strahd’s pact. Three critical facts are revealed: the Daemon Prince’s true name (1d5 CP to learn), the pact’s terms (immortality and dominion in exchange for a world’s suffering), and the three destruction conditions (Dawn’s Edge must strike the killing blow, Rosette of Saint Markovia must be active, Heart of the Spire must be destroyed first).
Insanity Cost2d10 Insanity Points (reduced to 1d10 on a successful Hard (−20) Willpower Test)
Corruption Cost1d5 Corruption Points (from learning the Daemon Prince’s name)

GM Notes: This is the single most important room in the Empyrean Vault and arguably in the entire campaign. The information here transforms the Acolytes’ mission from “survive and escape” to “here is exactly what you need to do.” The destruction conditions give the party a concrete checklist for Act III: find Dawn’s Edge, find the Rosette, infiltrate the Spire, destroy the Heart, confront Strahd. Without this intelligence, the Acolytes are guessing. With it, they have a plan. The IP cost is high but appropriate — witnessing the psychic echo of a Daemon Prince’s manifestation should leave scars. The Daemon Prince’s name can be used in Act IV to disrupt Strahd’s regeneration for 1d5 rounds during the final battle (a Very Hard (−30) Forbidden Lore (Daemonology) Test to invoke it correctly), making it a valuable but dangerous asset.

Encounter Guide

The Empyrean Vault is the campaign's ultimate temptation dungeon. Combat is secondary to the real danger: moral choices with catastrophic spiritual consequences. Every containment cell offers genuine power at genuine cost, and the horror is that the deals are fair. The Vault should feel alien in a way that Chaos is not — pre-human, incomprehensibly old, built by something that viewed daemons as specimens to be catalogued. Track corruption aggressively; this location can push Acolytes past the 100 CP threshold.

Mountain Approach

RiskTense
TypeEnvironmental, Skill Challenge

Environmental: Lethal cold — not winter cold but absence-cold, as though heat itself has been consumed. 1d10 E damage (ignoring armour) per hour of exposure without adequate cold-weather gear. Survival (Challenging +0) to reduce damage by half. Visibility drops to 10m in blizzards. Altitude sickness from extended exposure compounds fatigue.

Skill Challenge: Navigate (Hard -20) to find the Vault entrance — a 20-metre door carved from non-stone, non-metal, non-crystal material covered in alien script, hidden in the mountainside. Failure adds travel segments and exposure damage. Survival (Challenging +0) to locate shelter if caught in a blizzard. Kasimir (if present) provides +20 to Navigate — his decades of study make him nearly essential for this approach.

Enemies: Mountain passes are patrolled by Vault Guardians — xenos constructs still functioning on degraded power cells. Use modified Combat Servitor profiles with las-weapons and force-field generators (Protection Rating 30). Numbers vary by GM discretion — 2-4 per encounter. Scaling: For 3, use 2 guardians. For 6+, use 4 guardians with increased las-weapon damage (+2).

Discovery: The approach reveals the Vault's alien nature. The mountain itself shows signs of ancient sculpting — too large-scale and too old for human hands. The architecture is pre-Imperial, pre-human, and predates anything in Mechanicus records. Forbidden Lore (Xenos) (Hard -20) to identify the builders as a species of immense technological and psychic sophistication.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour of travel. Warp concentration increases with altitude — the Vault's proximity to the immaterium bleeds through the mountain's thinning reality.

GM Notes: The approach is a resource drain by design — fatigue, cold damage, CP accumulation. Smart parties prepare with cold-weather gear (available through Vostra trade or scavenging) and move fast. Kasimir's knowledge is the difference between a brutal slog and a manageable one. If the Acolytes lack cold-weather gear, this becomes a serious survival challenge before they even reach the Vault.

Entry Hall

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Environmental

Environmental: Alien architecture — geometry that should not work, corridors that curve in directions that hurt to perceive. The darkness inside is not absence of light but presence of dark, pressing against lamp-packs like a living membrane. Willpower (Challenging +0) on entry or 1d5 IP from spatial disorientation as the brain struggles to process non-Euclidean construction.

Discovery: The Vault Guardian — a degraded artificial intelligence or xenos ghost-construct manifesting as a flickering hololithic figure of vaguely humanoid proportions. It speaks halting, corrupted Low Gothic (learned from Strahd's visit centuries ago). It does NOT attack. It observes, then warns: "The seals are broken. The dreamers wake. Turn back."

Skill Challenge: Tech-Use (Very Hard -30) or Forbidden Lore (Xenos) (Hard -20) to interact with the Guardian through psychic impression. Linguistics (Very Hard -30) or Psyniscience (Hard -20) to understand its full message, which includes a map of which containment cells are breached and which remain sealed. Treating the Guardian with respect and patience — Fellowship (Challenging +0) — yields better information than threats or force.

GM Notes: The Guardian is a plot device, not an enemy. It cannot stop the Acolytes, only warn them. Its warning is genuine — the Vault is the most dangerous non-Strahd location in the campaign. If destroyed (possible but pointless), it deactivates the last automated wards, making the corridors more dangerous. Play it as weary and dutiful — a sentinel that has watched its prison fail for millennia and knows it cannot prevent the next failure.

Sealed Corridors

RiskDangerous
TypeTrap, Environmental

Traps: Degraded xenos wards — once containment mechanisms, now random hazards. Awareness (Hard -20) to spot before triggering. Tech-Use (Very Hard -30) or Forbidden Lore (Xenos) (Hard -20) to disarm. Triggering a ward: 2d10 E damage (energy discharge) and 1d5 CP from direct contact with xenos warp-containment technology.

Environmental: The corridors shift subtly — rooms are not always in the same order between visits. Navigate (Hard -20) to maintain orientation. Failure adds encounters as the party circles back through previously cleared areas, wasting time and accumulating corruption. Random corridor encounters include: warp-echoes (ghostly replays of previous explorers' deaths), spatial anomalies (gravity shifts, temperature inversions), and occasional escaped lesser daemons.

Discovery: Wall inscriptions — pre-human pictographs depicting the Vault's purpose. Forbidden Lore (Xenos) (Challenging +0) to interpret: the Vault was a prison. The "dreamers" are daemons bound here long before humanity existed. An unknown xenos species used this world as a dumping ground for things that could not be killed — entities too dangerous to destroy and too valuable to ignore.

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP per hour inside the Vault corridors (ambient warp bleed from degrading containment). Trap damage is in addition to this baseline accumulation.

GM Notes: The corridors are meant to disorient and drain resources. Do not let the party rest here — the Vault actively resists it. Sleep is interrupted by whispered offers from the sealed cells, spatial shifts that dump sleepers into different corridors, and a persistent psychic pressure that prevents genuine recuperation. Push the party forward or drive them out.

Containment Cells

RiskCatastrophic
TypeSocial, Faith Test

Faith Test: Each cell entrance — Willpower (Challenging +0) to resist the compulsion to stop and listen to the entity within. Stopping to listen without accepting a pact: Willpower (Hard -20) to walk away after hearing the offer. Each cell inflicts 1d5 CP from proximity alone, regardless of interaction.

Social: Five accessible daemon pacts, each a temptation encounter — not combat. Each entity has had millennia to perfect its pitch. The GM should roleplay each offer with maximum persuasiveness. Every deal is genuine: the daemons honour their bargains exactly. The horror is that the deals are FAIR.

Pact — Cell Sigma-3 (Daemon of Tzeentch, "The Whispered Answer"): Knowledge — reveals the complete layout of the Zarovich Spire, including all traps, guards, and secret passages. Cost: 2d10 CP, Minor Mutation, and a compulsion to seek forbidden knowledge (Willpower -20 to resist investigating any anomalous phenomenon).

Pact — Cell Theta-7 (Daemon of Nurgle, "The Undying Gift"): Resilience — Regeneration (5) trait and immunity to disease and poison. Cost: 2d10 CP, flesh becomes grey and numb (Fellowship -15), exudes aura of decay (-10 social interactions with non-corrupted individuals).

Pact — Cell Omega-1 (Daemon of Khorne, "The Red Blessing"): Martial Fury — +20 WS, +2 SB, Frenzy talent. Cost: 2d10 CP, Willpower -10 each time witnessing violence or be compelled to join it, eyes permanently burn faint red.

Pact — Cell Phi-9 (Daemon of Slaanesh, "The Perfect Moment"): Domination — psychic ability equivalent to Dominate (WP Test, 20m range, single command). Works on non-psykers. Cost: 3d10 CP (highest — Slaanesh's gifts are most costly on a world saturated with Slaaneshi influence), addiction to sensation of control (Willpower -20 to resist using in any social confrontation), Strahd can sense the Acolyte's location at all times.

Pact — Cell Lambda-12 (Unknown Entity, "The Hollow Crown"): Immortality — ceases aging, Undying trait (body regenerates over 1d5 hours when reduced to 0 Wounds). Cost: 3d10 CP, soul bound to Barovus forever (can never leave even if rift closes), entity's voice in moments of weakness slowly eroding identity.

Corruption/Insanity: CP values per pact as listed above. Any Acolyte whose CP exceeds their WP Bonus x10 rolls immediately on the Mutation Table. Each accepting Acolyte also gains a Secret Condition: a behavioural compulsion known only to that player and the GM. Creates tension and roleplay, not immediate PvP conflict.

GM Notes: These are the campaign's most dangerous choices. Every pact is a legitimate strategic option with terrible costs. The Tzeentchian pact provides the complete Spire layout — enormous tactical value. The Slaaneshi pact lets Strahd track the party — enormous tactical liability. The Hollow Crown pact creates a potential Ending 5 (Dark Victory) candidate. Play the daemons as charming, reasonable, ancient intelligences that genuinely want to deal. They are not lying. They are not deceiving. They are offering exactly what they say, at exactly the stated price. That sincerity is the most terrifying thing about them.

Kasimir's Objective

RiskDangerous
TypeSocial, Investigation

Social: Kasimir seeks Cell Kappa-4 to resurrect his sister Patrina using a bound entity that claims it can raise the dead. It can. Kasimir begs the Acolytes for help — he guided them here, kept them alive on the mountain, and now asks for this one thing. Awareness (Challenging +0) to read Kasimir's emotional state: desperation bordering on obsession, genuine grief weaponised by decades of planning.

Investigation: Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) reveals the resurrection is fuelled by the same warp energy sustaining Strahd. Patrina returns with full knowledge of her previous life as a dark sorcerer — powerful (Psy Rating 5, knows Strahd's fortress layout) but not trustworthy. Willpower (Challenging +0) to assess Patrina's true intentions: she is sincere about killing Strahd, but plans to take his place afterward.

Moral Dilemma: Help Kasimir (gaining his gratitude and a powerful but dangerous ally), stop him (making an enemy of a man who guided you through lethal terrain), or allow the resurrection and deal with consequences. Patrina is a wild card — a genuine asset against Strahd who intends to become the next tyrant of Barovus.

Corruption/Insanity: 3 CP for participating in the resurrection ritual. 1d5 IP from witnessing it — warp energy flooding a containment cell as dead flesh reknits and a soul screams back into existence.

GM Notes: This is a trust test. Kasimir has been a loyal companion — refusing him is painful. Patrina is useful — rejecting her is strategically costly. But allowing a warp-fuelled resurrection in the heart of a daemon prison is exactly the kind of moral compromise Barovus demands. If the Acolytes allow it, Patrina becomes a significant factor in the final act. Track her movements, her conversations, and her quiet preparations. She is patient. She has waited this long.

Alpha-Prime

RiskDeadly
TypeDiscovery, Faith Test

Discovery: The deepest containment cell — Cell Alpha-Prime. Its containment field is shattered. This is where Strahd made his pact with the Daemon Prince of Slaanesh. The cell still bears his psychic imprint: touching the walls triggers a sensory flashback to the moment of the pact. Two tiers of discovery:

Discovery — Strahd's Pact: The flashback reveals: the Daemon Prince's name (Tenebrous, "The Prince of Midnight Pleasures" — knowing a daemon's true name grants power over it but draws its attention, 1d5 CP from the knowledge alone); the pact's terms (immortality and dominion in exchange for the world's psychic suffering channelled through Strahd as conduit); the pact's weakness (anchored to Strahd's soul — his physical form is insufficient, the pact must be severed at source).

Discovery — Xenos Data Repository: Not a daemon but a data archive. Tech-Use (Very Hard -30) + Forbidden Lore (Xenos) (Very Hard -30) to access (both tests required). Success reveals the complete conditions for Strahd's destruction — confirming and expanding on the three conditions: the Heart of the Spire must be shattered, his coffin must be destroyed or sanctified, and he must be struck down by Dawn's Edge (a weapon specifically consecrated to sever warp-pacts). Also reveals: the warp rift CAN be collapsed, but only if Strahd is destroyed first — his pact IS the rift's anchor.

Faith Test: Accessing xenos knowledge — Willpower (Hard -20) or 2d10 CP as the knowledge rewrites neural pathways. Success: the knowledge integrates cleanly (still 1d10 CP — the information is not human and leaves marks). Failure: the knowledge arrives garbled, contradictory, and maddening (2d10 CP + 1d10 IP).

Corruption/Insanity: Minimum 1d10 CP from the data repository, maximum 2d10 CP + 1d10 IP depending on tests. 1d5 CP from the pact flashback. This room hits hard and fast — warn players through atmosphere, not mechanics.

GM Notes: Alpha-Prime is the campaign's ultimate intelligence cache. Everything the Acolytes need to know is here — the complete picture of how to destroy Strahd and collapse the rift. But the cost of accessing it is enormous. The xenos data should feel like touching something not meant for human minds — the perspective is alien in a way that Chaos is not. It is not evil, just incomprehensibly different. The pact flashback is the emotional core: let the players experience Strahd's moment of damnation and understand that it began with grief, not malice. He wanted to live. He wanted Tatyana. And for that, a world was damned.

The road climbs for an hour, switchbacking up the sheer face of Mount Ghakis on a path wide enough for a Chimera transport but cratered and broken by centuries of neglect. Dark, organic tendrils have pushed through the cracked ferrocrete, pulsing faintly in the gloom. On either side, the remnants of an Imperial processional line stand in ruin — statues of saints with smashed faces, defaced aquilas, broken outstretched hands. And then you see it. The Zarovich Spire, rising from the mountainside like a blade thrust into the belly of heaven — a colossal fortress-palace of Terran-Gothic architecture twisted by four centuries of unshielded warp exposure into something that defies Euclidean certainty. Its buttresses claw at the sky. Its towers list at angles that should not bear weight. Its windows glow with a cold, corpse-light luminescence. A drawbridge of black iron and adamantium plate lowers itself as you approach, without signal, without command. You were expected.

Key FactDetail
ActAct III — The Zarovich Spire
Map ReferenceMap 11 (5 sub-maps: 11a Courtyard, 11b Ground Level, 11c Upper Levels, 11d Crypts, 11e Heart Chamber)
Population / Status~60 Gargoyle-Servitors, ~30 domestic servitors, 12 servitor-guards, 24 warp-thralls, Strahd himself, plus Rahadin and Cyrus Belview
