The Final Dungeon

The Zarovich Spire is the black heart of Barovus. It is the final destination of every road, the culmination of every rumour, and the singular purpose behind every prayer whispered in the dark. The Spire is not merely Strahd's home — it is Strahd, in a very real and terrible sense. The warp rift that imprisons Barovus has its nexus here, threaded through the castle's foundations like a tumour woven into living tissue. The fortress responds to Strahd's psyche: his moods shape its corridors, his rage shakes its stones, his hunger opens its doors.

The Game Master must internalise the cardinal rule of this dungeon: the Acolytes are mice in Strahd's game. They are not clearing rooms and marking them safe. They are surviving. Every moment of calm is a moment Strahd has permitted. Every discovery is something he wanted them to find — or something they found in spite of him. Within the Spire, Strahd has absolute awareness through scrying-servitors embedded in the walls (requiring a Hard (–20) Awareness test to notice), warp-sight that lets him sense living souls, and a network of hidden passages threaded through the castle's bones. He knows where the Acolytes are at all times.

The castle is alive. Its walls breathe with a faint rhythmic expansion visible only in peripheral vision. Its shadows move independently of light sources. Its corridors rearrange when the Acolytes are not looking — a Challenging (–10) Navigate (Surface) test is required to maintain bearings; failure means the party ends up somewhere unintended. Vox-casters embedded in the walls crackle with Strahd's voice, the screams of long-dead victims, or a subsonic hum that sets teeth on edge. The temperature fluctuates wildly, and the stone itself is warm to the touch in places, as though the castle has a pulse. The Acolytes should never feel in control until Strahd is destroyed or they flee.

Key Areas of the Zarovich Spire

The Spire is divided across five sub-map zones, each with a distinct atmosphere and purpose. What follows is a condensed overview; the full room-by-room detail is found in the Act III design document.

Courtyard and Approach (Map 11a)

The road to the Spire is a demoralising climb past thirty-seven defaced saint-statues with inverted aquilas and blasphemous catechisms — a Routine (+20) Willpower test upon first sight of the Spire prevents a creeping sense of wrongness. The drawbridge lowers automatically when the Acolytes come within fifty metres, controlled solely by Strahd's will. The chasm beneath is ninety metres deep, ending in a pool of liquefied warp-stuff (instantly fatal; Very Hard (–30) Willpower test or gain 1d10 Corruption Points during the fall). Beyond the drawbridge, a warp-forged iron portcullis and massive adamantium doors swing open without force.

The courtyard is an eighty-metre-square killing ground enclosed by curtain walls. Key features include: The Dead Gardens — topiary shapes that are actually chem-preserved corpses of former servants, posed in attitudes of service (Ordinary (+10) Medicae or Awareness to recognise); The Fountain — the von Zarovich crest, basin stained with old blood, touching it triggers a psychic flash of a blood-drinking gala; Strahd's Carriage — a bespoke tracked vehicle with a bound warp-entity for a machine-spirit (WP 55 to control); and Gargoyle-Servitors — forty to sixty dormant stone-like constructs perched on every parapet, indistinguishable from decoration until activated.

Entry Points: Main entrance (drawbridge and gates), a servant's door in the east curtain wall (Hard (–20) Security to locate), and a drainage grate beneath the courtyard (Challenging (–10) Awareness to find, leads to the crypts via flooded tunnels).

Ground Level (Map 11b)

The ground level is the public face of the Spire — faded Imperial grandeur rotting from within.

The Grand Entry Hall is a cathedral-space soaring thirty metres high, with pillars of black granite carved with Strahd's conquests, six two-tonne crystal chandeliers (can be dropped: Challenging (–10) BS to sever chains, dealing 4d10+10 I in a 4m radius, Concussive (3)), and a floor mosaic replacing the Emperor's face with Strahd's (Ordinary (+10) Awareness to notice; Routine (+20) WP or gain 1 Insanity Point). Organ music drifts through the hall from the loft above.

The Dining Hall hosts the pivotal Dinner Invitation scene — a table set for exactly the Acolytes' number, with name cards in Strahd's elegant hand. The food is genuine, safe, and restores 1d5 Wounds and removes one Fatigue. Strahd appears for dinner, offering polite conversation and a deal: leave Barovus, report it lost, and depart unharmed.

The Audience Chamber contains centuries of governance data-slates (searchable with Challenging (–10) Inquiry; reveals the rift's exact date, Sergei's death warrant in Strahd's hand, and unanswered petitions for Imperial rescue) and twelve dormant servitor-guards (WS 40, BS 35, S 45 Unnatural x2, Wounds 20, AP 5, lascarbines and power mauls) that activate if the throne is approached.

The Chapel retains a ghost of its original sanctification: warp entities find it uncomfortable (Strahd's lair action resistance gains +10), faith powers function at +10, Corruption tests gain +20, and a perpetual candle burns that cannot be extinguished. An Acolyte who prays at the altar may make a Challenging (–10) Willpower test to remove 1d5 Insanity Points and restore 1d5 Wounds (once per Acolyte). Dawn's Edge gains the Sanctified quality permanently if brought here.

Servant Quarters, Kitchen, and Guard Barracks round out the ground floor: thirty non-combat domestic servitors maintaining an empty household, a kitchen that replenishes itself via minor warp phenomena (eating for more than a week requires Challenging (–10) Toughness or gain 1 Corruption Point), and barracks housing twelve warp-thralls in dormant state who attack in coordinated PDF squad tactics when activated.

Upper Levels (Map 11c)

The upper levels contain the Spire's most personal and most dangerous spaces.

Strahd's Study is the most human room in the fortress — a warm, book-lined chamber with a genuine fire, a half-finished glass of wine, and a portrait of Sergei that radiates faint psychic warmth. The Tome of Strahd (encrypted data-cogitator, Hard (–20) Tech-Use or Ciphers to decrypt) sits on a side table. It contains four centuries of diary entries revealing Strahd's full history, the terms of his pact with the Daemon Prince Tenebrous, the Tatyana reincarnation cycle, and the three conditions for his permanent destruction. The bookshelves yield a +20 bonus to a single Forbidden Lore (Warp) test with a successful Challenging (–10) Scholastic Lore (Occult) search.

The Organ Loft overlooks the grand hall. A servitor hardwired into the pipe organ has played the Ecclesiarchy hymn "The Emperor's Light Endures" for over two hundred years. Playing the organ with Trade (Musician) or Performer produces warp-resonant effects: an Imperial hymn stuns warp-thralls and disorients Strahd (–10 all tests, 1d5 rounds); a piece of sorrow unlocks doors and makes spirits visible; a discordant piece triggers 1d5 Corruption Points and warp anomalies.

The Guest Quarters are genuinely comfortable and safe — Strahd's word holds here. No traps, no surveillance. Resting six hours removes all Fatigue and heals normally. The comfort is the insult.

The North Tower (Observatory) contains star-charts of the warp rift's interior (studying them: Challenging (–10) WP or 1 Insanity Point) and a cogitator with navigational data (Hard (–20) Forbidden Lore (Warp) to interpret) revealing the rift is artificial, anchored to the Heart, Strahd's will, and Sergei's remains, and expanding toward the nearest Imperial system.

The South Tower is where Tatyana fell. The psychic imprint is seared into the warp-stuff: psykers must pass Hard (–20) WP or experience a devastating vision of Tatyana's final moments (1d5 Insanity Points, 1 Corruption Point), but gain understanding that may grant +10 to social tests against Strahd.

The Crypts (Map 11d)

Beneath the Spire, a labyrinthine network of corridors and burial vaults extends far beyond the castle's footprint — a spatial impossibility enabled by the warp rift. Navigation is Hard (–20). All light sources have halved range. Fear resistance suffers –10. Temperature is –5°C (Fatigue from cold after 2 hours without gear, Challenging (–10) Toughness per hour).

Ten named crypts are detailed in the Heart and Crypts page. Of particular note: Sergei's tomb (incorrupt body, possible Dawn's Edge location, spirit offers blessing of +10 WP vs. Strahd), Strahd's coffin (deepest chamber, behind a false wall, guarded by six warp-thralls), Ireena's prepared crypt (empty sarcophagus with wedding veil — pure horror, no combat), and the Chained Daemon (a lesser Slaaneshi daemon offering accurate information for release at a cost of 2d10 Corruption Points).

Seven teleportation braziers form a rapid-transit network throughout the Spire (see Heart and Crypts page for details).

Heart Chamber (Map 11e)

Behind three successive warded doors, a spherical chamber thirty metres in diameter contains the Heart of the Spire — a metre-wide crystal of solidified warp energy, pulsing with Strahd's own heartbeat, suspended in crackling warp-lightning. Two bound Warp Stalkers (lesser daemons of Slaanesh) serve as eternal sentinels. The Heart's destruction is one of three conditions for permanently killing Strahd and triggers catastrophic effects: castle-wide earthquake, Strahd's frenzied response, destabilisation of the Spire's architecture, and stunned warp-touched creatures throughout the fortress. Full mechanics are detailed in the Heart and Crypts page.

Quest Connections

All three relics potentially converge in the Spire. The Emperor's Tarot reading from Act I determines where each is found — one or more may be located within the Spire itself (Dawn's Edge in Sergei's tomb, the Rosette in the crypts, the Tome in Strahd's study). The Acolytes' primary objectives within the Spire are:

  1. Recover the Tome of Strahd to learn the three conditions for permanent destruction.
  2. Destroy the Heart of the Spire (Heart Chamber, Map 11e).
  3. Find and destroy or sanctify Strahd's coffin (deepest crypt, Map 11d).
  4. Strike Strahd down with Dawn's Edge while the Rosette is active and both the Heart and coffin are neutralised.

Strahd's Tactics

When he engages: Strahd singles out the most martially skilled Acolyte for duelling, uses lair actions to control the battlefield, and directs minions with +10 to all their tests. He parries with contemptuous ease (Parry 75) and ripostes with lethal precision.

When he withdraws: Strahd phases through walls to reposition, retreats to his coffin to regenerate (1d10 hours, or 1d5 if the Heart is intact), and redeploys forces between forays. Each time the Acolytes re-enter the Spire, he has adapted: repositioned forces, reset traps, adjusted strategy.

How he uses the lair: Strahd separates the party through architecture, funnels them into ambushes, blocks escape routes, and creates environmental hazards. He extinguishes lights, seals rooms, and summons servitors at will. The castle is his weapon.

Heart of the Spire

Behind the warded doors — three sets, each sealed with hexagrammic sigils that burn cold to the touch — the corridor widens into a chamber that should not exist. The room is a sphere, thirty metres in diameter, carved from the living rock of the mountain. The walls are covered in script grown into the stone like veins in flesh, in no language any of you recognise. And at the centre of the sphere, suspended in empty air, turning slowly in a web of crackling warp-lightning, is the Heart. A crystal — a metre across, roughly spherical, translucent, pulsing with a deep arterial red light that throbs in time with a rhythm you can feel in your chest. It is, you realise with horror, a heartbeat. The castle's heartbeat. Strahd's heartbeat.

The Heart of the Spire is the nexus of the warp rift's connection to the castle and, through the castle, to Strahd. It is the mechanism by which the pact's power is channelled into the physical world. Destroying it is one of the three conditions necessary to permanently kill Strahd.

The Warded Doors

Three successive doors guard the approach. Each is sealed with hexagrammic wards that inflict 2d10 Energy damage (Pen 5, ignoring non-psychic armour) to any warp-touched entity that attempts to pass. Strahd can bypass them (keyed to him); his servants cannot. The wards do not affect untainted humans. Each door: Challenging (–10) Forbidden Lore (Warp) or Security to open; alternatively, brute force (Armour 10, Structural Integrity 35 per door).

Destroying the Heart

When the Heart is destroyed, the following effects trigger simultaneously:

  2. Strahd's Scream: An agonised scream echoes through the entire castle, inflicting 1d5 Insanity Points on anyone who hears it (no save). Strahd becomes Frenzied and moves toward the Heart Chamber immediately.
  3. Destabilisation: Navigation suffers an additional –10. Random encounters increase to every 15 minutes. Cracks appear in walls, ceilings sag, dust fills the air.
  4. Warp-Touched Stun: All warp-touched creatures in the Spire: Challenging (–10) Willpower or Stunned for 1d5 rounds.
  5. Strahd loses Regeneration permanently. Loses all Heart-derived benefits. Drops to Phase 2 regardless of Wounds.
  6. The Castle Bleeds (automatic).
  7. Warp backlash (in chamber): Everyone present: Very Hard (–30) WP or gain 1d10 Corruption Points and 1d10 Insanity Points. Chamber becomes unstable — 15% chance per round of wall collapse (2d10+5 E from warp exposure). Approximately 10 rounds before the chamber is unsurvivable.

The Crypts

The stairs descend far longer than they should — far longer than the mountain's geology would permit. The temperature drops with every step. Your lamp-packs push against a darkness that seems to have physical weight. At the bottom, the passage opens into a low, vaulted corridor lined with hundreds of niches, each containing remains. Some skeletal. Some mummified. Some appearing freshly dead. None of them are truly at rest.

Strahd's Coffin — Permanent Destruction

The coffin is a masterwork of dark wood and adamantium banding, lined with crimson silk, engraved with hexagrammic wards of preservation. It radiates a faint psychic pulse. When Strahd is reduced to Critical Damage, he retreats here and regenerates fully in 1d10 hours (1d5 if Heart intact).

Destroying the coffin: Inflict 30 points of damage (Armour 8, immune to warp/psychic damage) or hold the Rosette of Saint Markovia against it for three consecutive rounds (Challenging (+0) WP each round; coffin deals 1d10+3 E, Pen 4 to bearer each round).

Sanctifying the coffin: Perform a full consecration ritual over three rounds while the coffin is exposed to the Emperor's light via Rosette or Dawn's Edge. Requires Rite of Sanctification or Very Hard (–30) Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed). Does not destroy the coffin but renders it useless — Strahd can no longer regenerate within it.

The Three Conditions for Permanent Destruction

Lord-Governor Strahd von Zarovich can only be permanently destroyed if all three conditions are met simultaneously:

  1. The Heart of the Spire must be destroyed — removing his regeneration and severing his connection to the pact's power source.
  2. His coffin must be destroyed or sanctified — eliminating his ability to retreat and reform.
  3. He must be struck down by Dawn's Edge while the Rosette of Saint Markovia is active — the killing blow must come from a weapon of faith, sanctified by the Emperor's light.

If any single condition is unmet, Strahd regenerates within 1d10 days. The Tome of Strahd contains this information; without it, the Acolytes risk destroying his body only to have him return. The Tome transforms the final battle from a slugfest into a strategic operation.

Encounter Guide

The Zarovich Spire is the final dungeon — a living predator that learns, adapts, and serves its master's will. Every area should feel consequential: rooms are not cleared and marked safe, they are survived. Strahd is always watching through scrying-servitors in the walls (Awareness, Hard -20 to spot), warp-sight, and hidden passages. Track his behavioural escalation across sessions: Curious (1-2) to Amused (2-3) to Irritated (3-4) to Furious (4) to Desperate (final). The Spire is designed for 3-5 sessions of exploration. Do not let the Acolytes clear it in a single foray.

One statue, better preserved: a figure in Ministorum robes whose hands have been repositioned to point accusingly toward the Spire. The last statue before the bridge is Saint Markovia — her face intact though marred. The Rosette was hers.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP from approaching the Spire — warp concentration intensifies with proximity to the rift's nexus.

GM Notes: The approach is theatre. Let Strahd control the drawbridge to demonstrate absolute authority — it lowers for the Acolytes when he is ready, mocking any attempt to cross by other means (grapnel, jump pack) by lowering anyway. If Strahd does not want visitors, the bridge stays up: Athletics (Very Hard -30) to cross the gap by other means, certain death on failure. The statues set the tone — systematic desecration performed with care and skill over centuries.

Courtyard

RiskDangerous
TypeCombat, Discovery

Enemies: Gargoyle-Servitors — ceramite-plated constructs perched on every parapet, indistinguishable from architectural decoration until activated by Strahd's will, an attempt to flee, or violence against the castle. When triggered, swarms of 4-6 detach and attack. 4 Gargoyle-Servitors per wave (WS 35, S 40, T 45, Ag 30, 15 Wounds, AP 6 all, Flight 8, Natural Weapons: claws 1d10+4 R Pen 2, Fear 1, Machine 4, Unnatural Toughness 2). Relentless mob tactics — surround and overwhelm, prioritise anyone attempting to leave the Spire. Scaling: For 3, reduce to 3 per wave. For 6+, add 2 per wave and increase to 6. Total available: 40-60 gargoyle-servitors in the Spire.

Discovery: Dead gardens — not topiary sculptures but chem-treated, warp-stasis-preserved corpses of former servants, posed in attitudes of service. Medicae (Ordinary +10) or Awareness (Ordinary +10) to identify the truth. A fountain with the von Zarovich crest runs with dark liquid — Medicae (Challenging +0) confirms human blood, preserved by warp energy. Touching the fountain: brief psychic flash of the fountain running bright red while figures in formal dress drink from crystal goblets. Strahd's personal carriage sits beneath an awning — a bespoke tracked vehicle with a bound warp-entity replacing its machine-spirit (WP 55, obeys only Strahd).

Environmental: 80m square kill zone overlooked by dozens of windows. The Acolytes are observed at all times. Awareness (Challenging +0) detects movement behind the glass. The courtyard offers no cover against the gargoyle-servitors.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP from the blood fountain (warp-preserved organic material). 1 IP from being watched — the certainty that eyes track every movement from every window.

GM Notes: The courtyard is designed as a kill zone. If the gargoyle-servitors activate, the Acolytes are in the open with no cover and enemies dropping from above. Smart parties arrive by invitation — Strahd's dinner invitation or the black carriage — and bypass this entirely. That bypass is itself unsettling: the monster opened the door for you.

Grand Entry Hall

RiskTense
TypeDiscovery, Faith Test

Discovery: A 30m-high cathedral space with black granite pillars carved with conquest scenes. The floor mosaic depicts the Emperor enthroned — but His face has been replaced with Strahd's. Awareness (Ordinary +10) to notice the substitution, which is done with such skill it is not immediately obvious. Scholastic Lore (War) (Ordinary +10) on the pillar carvings: the depicted tactics are brilliant — Strahd was a genuinely gifted commander. Scholastic Lore (Occult) (Hard -20): later carvings show enemies dissolving, withering, consumed by shadow — the transition from conventional warfare to something else, documented in stone. Six chandeliers (2 tonnes each) can be dropped on enemies: BS (Challenging +0) to shoot through the chain, 4d10+10 I damage in 4m radius, Concussive (3).

Faith Test: An organ plays itself — a servitor hardwired into a massive pipe organ, playing the Imperial hymn "The Emperor's Light Endures" on infinite loop for 200+ years. Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Routine +20) recognises the hymn. The music is warp-resonant: Willpower (Challenging +0) or be compelled to listen (1d5 rounds lost, 1 CP). Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) identifies the music as a psychic lure designed to calm intruders and lower defences. Resisting actively with prayer: Willpower (Hard -20), success grants +10 to WP tests for 1 hour as the Emperor's light pushes back against Strahd's domain.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP from the organ music (unavoidable if heard). Can be countered by faith. 1 IP from the blasphemous mosaic (Willpower, Routine +20 to resist).

GM Notes: The Entry Hall sets the Spire's tone — Strahd is cultured, refined, and patient. He does not need to attack. The music does his work for him. The mosaic is a theological statement: Strahd has placed himself in the Emperor's position. Prayer is the counter to the music, and this should reinforce the campaign's central theme — faith matters mechanically and narratively on Barovus.

Dining Hall

RiskTense
TypeSocial

Social: THE Strahd scene — the Dinner Invitation. A 20m table set for exactly the party's number, each place marked with a name card in elegant script. The food is real, excellently prepared, and not poisoned — Strahd considers poisoning guests vulgar. Medicae (Ordinary +10) or Trade (Cook) (Ordinary +10) confirms safety. Eating restores 1d5 Wounds and removes 1 Fatigue. Strahd arrives not through a door but by simply being there, as though he had always been present. He is calm, articulate, and terrifyingly polite.

Social — Strahd's Objectives: Assess the Acolytes' strength and resolve. Identify the weakest-willed member for future corruption attempts. If Ireena is present, his attention fixes on her with intensity masked by perfect courtesy — Awareness (Challenging +0) catches the mask slipping when he calls her "Tatyana" and catches himself. He offers a deal: leave Barovus, report the world as lost, and he permits departure. He is sincere. If refused, he is disappointed, not angry: "A pity. I had hoped you would be reasonable."

Social — Information Gathering: Willpower (Hard -20) to remember this is a monster while enjoying his hospitality. Charm/Deceive (Very Hard -30) to gain information from Strahd without revealing plans. He freely admits his age, his rule, the rift's origin. He will not discuss the pact's terms, the Heart, or Dawn's Edge — these topics are deflected with four centuries of practiced authority.

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP from prolonged proximity to Strahd — the most powerful warp-touched entity on Barovus, at arm's length, pouring wine. 1d5 IP from the cognitive dissonance of dining with a monster who is genuinely pleasant. Reference Interrogator Vasek's confession: "He was civilised. Charming. He asked about my homeworld..." The Acolytes are experiencing exactly what corrupted an Inquisitor.

GM Notes: This is the single most important scene in the Spire. Play Strahd at his absolute best — compelling, human, and terrifying in equal measure. The food is good. The conversation is fascinating. The wine is superb. The horror is how EASY it is to forget what he is. If the Acolytes attack during dinner, Strahd simply vanishes with weary disappointment. The food remains. The candles burn. The silence accuses. Make this feel like a mistake — not through punishment, but through the profound discomfort of the aftermath.

Audience Chamber

RiskDangerous
TypeCombat, Investigation

Enemies: 12 Servitor-Guards in dormant mode around the throne dais — activate if anyone sits on the throne or by Strahd's command. Servitor-Guards (WS 40, BS 35, S 45 Unnatural Strength x2, T 40, Ag 20, 20 Wounds, AP 5 all, Machine 3). Armed with built-in lascarbines (75m, S/2/-, 1d10+3 E, Reliable) and power mauls (1d10+6 E, Pen 4, Power Field, Shocking). Fight without tactics or self-preservation. Scaling: For 3, reduce to 8 active (others remain dormant). For 6+, all 12 activate simultaneously and Strahd commands coordinated tactics (+10 to tests).

Investigation: Centuries of governance records in crystal data-slate racks. Inquiry (Challenging +0) or Scholastic Lore (Administratum) (Challenging +0) (requires 1+ hour of searching): the exact date the warp rift closed (437.M39), records of mass disappearances and psychic phenomena immediately after, citizen petitions for Imperial rescue stamped "RECEIVED — NO ACTION REQUIRED" in Strahd's handwriting, and a death warrant for Sergei von Zarovich signed by Strahd on the day of Sergei's wedding. A pattern emerges: early records show a just if stern ruler; later records show increasing paranoia, cruelty, and references to "the unworthy." The descent is documented.

Discovery: Hidden passage behind the throne leads to the chapel and study. Awareness (Very Hard -30) or Search (Hard -20) to locate. A sufficiently bold Acolyte who sits on the throne may attempt Willpower (Very Hard -30): success grants a disorienting vision of the Spire's layout from Strahd's perspective — revealing artifact locations, the Heart, and the coffin. Failure: 2d10 CP and Strahd's immediate hostile attention.

GM Notes: The servitors only attack if the Acolytes threaten the space or Strahd commands it. If the party are "guests," they can explore freely — Strahd's confidence is absolute. The data-slates are a goldmine for investigation-focused players. The throne gambit is high-risk, high-reward — advertise the danger through atmosphere (the warpstone surface shifting with half-seen faces) but let brave players attempt it.

Chapel

RiskTranquil
TypeFaith Test, Discovery

Faith Test: Sanctified ground — the only true safe space in the Spire. Despite centuries of desecration, the original consecration holds. The Emperor's light flickers here: a single candle burns without fuel in a saint's alcove, inextinguishable by any means. Willpower (Challenging +0) to pray at the altar — success: vision of the chapel as it once was (bright, clean, singing voices, golden aquila), removes 1d5 IP and restores 1d5 Wounds (once per Acolyte). Warp entities (including Strahd) find the chapel uncomfortable — Strahd can enter but avoids it. All tests to resist his lair actions gain +10 here. Faith and Emperor-aligned psychic powers function at +10. Corruption tests gain +20 bonus.

Discovery: Saint Markovia's personal effects — journals, prayer books, the altar she prayed at. Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Challenging +0) confirms these are genuine relics. If the Rosette of Saint Markovia is placed on this altar, it fully charges to maximum power for the final confrontation. If Dawn's Edge is brought here, it blazes with golden fire and gains the Sanctified quality permanently (if not already possessed).

Corruption/Insanity: None — the chapel REMOVES CP and IP. -1d5 CP for entering and praying (minimum 0). A genuine sanctuary in the heart of the monster's lair.

GM Notes: The chapel is a strategic rest point and should feel like finding breathable air underwater. Strahd HATES it — he cannot destroy it, and its existence mocks him. If the Acolytes fortify here, Strahd tries to lure them out (temptation, threats, staging attacks on allies elsewhere) but will not breach the sanctified ground. This is also the optimal location for reconsecration during the final battle — if performed (3 Full Actions, Hard -20 Willpower each round, requires Rosette), Strahd suffers 3d10 E damage (Pen all, Sanctified) and -20 to all tests while in the chapel.

Strahd's Study

RiskDangerous
TypeInvestigation, Discovery, Trap

Investigation: The Tome of Strahd — an ancient, ornate data-cogitator containing 400 years of encrypted High Gothic diary entries. Tech-Use (Hard -20) or Ciphers (Imperial Codes) (Hard -20) to decrypt (failure locks the device for 1d10 hours). Contents: Strahd's complete history, the pact with Daemon Prince Tenebrous, his murder of Sergei on the wedding day, the reincarnation cycle, and the three conditions for permanent destruction (Heart destroyed + coffin neutralised + struck down by Dawn's Edge). Also reveals vulnerabilities: blessed silver (+2 damage), the Hymn of the Golden Throne (forces WP (Challenging +0) or -10 to all tests for 1 round), Sergei's personal effects (each forces WP test or lose next turn). Reading the Tome grants all who study it: +10 to resist Strahd's psychic powers, +10 to combat tests against Strahd, and +10 to fear effects — detailed knowledge of his fighting style, habits, and patterns.

Trap: The Tome is warded. Psyniscience (Hard -20) to detect the ward before contact. Touching without dispelling: 2d10 E damage + 1d10 CP (psychic feedback of 300 years of compressed rage). Willpower (Very Hard -30) to dispel the ward psychically, or Tech-Use (Hard -20) to physically bypass by disconnecting the ward circuit.

Discovery: Strahd's personal effects throughout the study — star-charts, coded correspondence with the Daemon Prince, and portraits of every Tatyana reincarnation spanning centuries, each painted with devastating skill. The portraits show awareness — Strahd KNOWS about the reincarnation cycle and chooses to pursue each incarnation anyway. The study is warm — a fireplace with actual logs, a half-finished glass of wine, a portrait of Sergei above the mantle. The most human space in the Spire.

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP from handling the Tome (unavoidable warp residue). 1d10 IP from reading it — 300 years of horror, obsession, and self-aware damnation compressed into one session. The +10 bonuses against Strahd are worth the cost.

GM Notes: The Study is a treasure trove and a trap. The Tome is the most important item in the room — it transforms the final battle from a slugfest into a strategic operation. But every other discovery adds depth. The portraits are particularly haunting: dozens of women, spanning centuries, all with Ireena's face. The scattered diary entries of self-awareness — moments where the man Strahd used to be surfaces in shaky handwriting — should be the most disturbing thing in the Spire. He knows. He has always known.

Organ Loft

RiskTense
TypeSkill Challenge, Environmental

Environmental: The organ from the Entry Hall extends here — massive pipes of blackened metal, the music louder and more insistent. The servitor-organist is hardwired to the console, playing for 200+ years, biological components sustained by nutrient feeds. Willpower (Hard -20) each round or be compelled to play. If played: Perform/Trade (Musician) (Challenging +0) — playing feeds warp energy into the Spire, 1 CP per round to all within earshot. The organ is a psychic amplifier — its acoustic properties channel and distort psychic resonance throughout the Spire.

Skill Challenge: Tech-Use (Hard -20) to disable the organ's warp-resonance mechanism. Requires access to internal workings — Athletics (Challenging +0) to climb into the pipe structure. Disabling the organ removes the compulsion effect throughout the Spire and eliminates one of Strahd's lair actions ("The Spire Speaks") from the final battle. Alternatively, playing an Imperial hymn: the castle shudders, warp-thralls within earshot are Stunned for 1 round, and Strahd suffers -10 to all tests for 1d5 rounds.

Discovery: Inside the organ — a crystallised psychic node amplifying Strahd's psychic powers within the Spire. Psyniscience (Hard -20) to identify. Destroying it (S 40+ melee hit or psychic attack): -10 to Strahd's WP for the final battle — a permanent, stacking tactical advantage.

GM Notes: The organ is optional but highly tactical. Disabling the resonance mechanism AND destroying the psychic node before the final battle removes a lair action AND weakens Strahd's WP. Players who explore thoroughly are rewarded with meaningful mechanical advantages. Playing a discordant or chaotic piece is dangerous — warp energy surges, everyone tests WP (Challenging +0) or gains 1d5 CP, and the castle's geometry destabilises further.

Towers

RiskDangerous
TypeDiscovery, Environmental

Environmental — North Tower (Observatory): Structurally unsound. Awareness (Challenging +0) to notice signs of instability. Entering without caution: Agility (Hard -20) or partial collapse — 3d10 I damage and trapped in rubble. Contains star-charts and cogitator console. Tech-Use (Challenging +0) to activate the cogitator: navigational data showing the warp rift's interior topology. Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) to interpret: the rift is artificial (created by the pact), anchored to three points (Heart, Strahd's will, Sergei's remains), and slowly expanding — will engulf the nearest inhabited Imperial system in approximately 200 years. This transforms the mission from liberation to subsector-wide strategic priority.

Environmental — South Tower (Sergei's Tower): Empty — bare stone spiralling to an open platform. The parapet is broken on one side, torn outward. This is where Tatyana fell. Any psyker entering must pass Willpower (Hard -20) or be overwhelmed by a vision of Tatyana's final moments — her terror, Strahd reaching for her, her expression shifting from terror to pity: "You are already dead." Then she falls. Non-psykers feel only a profound, inexplicable sadness.

Discovery: The towers contain Strahd's collections — art, artefacts, trophies from centuries. Awareness (Hard -20) in one tower reveals Strahd's personal armoury — Dawn's Edge is NOT here, but its empty display case is, with a plaque: "Dawn's Edge — let the unworthy never touch it again." A taunt and a clue: the sword is elsewhere in the world, not the Spire.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per tower explored (ambient warp). 1d5 IP + 1 CP from the South Tower vision (raw warp-emotional resonance of Tatyana's death). The South Tower vision also grants a potential +10 bonus to social tests against Strahd (GM discretion) — understanding the monster's grief makes him easier to predict.

GM Notes: The towers are exploration content — no mandatory encounters, but rich discoveries. The Observatory data is strategically critical (subsector-level threat), the South Tower is emotionally devastating (Tatyana's last moments), and the armoury is a deliberate misdirection (Dawn's Edge is NOT here). Let investigation-focused players mine these for every advantage. The structural instability of the North Tower is a genuine hazard — describe groaning stone and shifting floors before the Agility test.

Crypts

RiskDeadly
TypeCombat, Discovery, Trap, Faith Test

Environmental: Labyrinthine network significantly larger than the castle above — spatial impossibility enabled by the warp rift. Navigate (Hard -20) to avoid becoming lost. All light sources halved range. All WP tests to resist Fear suffer -10. Temperature: -5C, Toughness (Challenging +0) per hour without cold gear or gain Fatigue.

Enemies: 10 named crypts with varied inhabitants. Servitor crypts contain 2-4 combat servitors each, activated by intrusion. Total possible across all crypts: 12 Servitor-Guards + 6 Warp-Thralls. The party will not fight all at once unless they clear every crypt systematically. Per-crypt: Scaling: Reduce by 1 for 3, add 1 for 6+. Special threats: General Grislek's revenant (Crypt 6: WS 50, S 45 USx2, T 40, 25 Wounds, AP 4, power sword + bolt pistol — attacks immediately, cannot be reasoned with). Ludmilla's crypt (Crypt 7: appears to negotiate but IS the daemon — freeing her releases a Daemonette of Slaanesh with +10 to all characteristics).

Traps: Teleportation traps in 3 crypts. Awareness (Hard -20) to detect. Triggering teleports the victim to a random Spire location (including OUTSIDE on a ledge). Willpower (Challenging +0) to resist. 1d5 CP per teleportation from brief warp transit. The False Crypt of Saint Markovia (Crypt 8) scatters the entire party — each Acolyte tests Willpower (Hard -20) or is teleported individually to different Spire locations. Those who resist: 2d10 E damage from discharged warp energy.

Faith Test: Sergei's crypt is sealed with sanctified wards (golden light). Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Ordinary +10) to open with prayer, or brute force (Armour 12, SI 30 — forcing the seal: 2d10 E burst to warp-touched creatures within 5m). Sergei's body is incorrupt — 400 years dead and appears merely sleeping. His spirit manifests: blessing grants +10 WP vs Strahd's abilities for the remainder of the campaign. He confirms the three destruction conditions. If Ireena touches his locket, a moment of peace. King Barov's crypt: his spirit answers questions about Strahd with imperious shame. Queen Ravenovia's crypt: she weeps and reveals the coffin is behind a false wall marked with the family crest.

Discovery: Ireena's prepared crypt (Crypt 5) — empty sarcophagus marked "IREENA KOLYANA — BELOVED" with blank dates and a folded wedding veil inside. No encounter. No trap. Just horror. If Ireena is present: WP (Hard -20) or Stunned 1d5 rounds. All other Acolytes: 1 IP. The Chained Daemon (Crypt 9): a lesser Slaaneshi daemon imprisoned by Strahd for a century, bound in blessed adamantium. Knows the complete crypt layout, coffin location, Heart weaknesses, and teleportation brazier command words. Offers this freely for release. It is telling the truth. Releasing it: Forbidden Lore (Daemonology) (Hard -20) and 2d10 CP. The freed daemon flees the Spire entirely. Tomb of the Forgotten (Crypt 10): mass grave of Strahd's victims — men, women, children. No encounter. 1 IP from finding a child's toy or an unsent letter among the bones.

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP per crypt entered (ambient). +1d5 CP in warp-thrall crypts. Sergei's crypt reduces IP (a sanctuary within the nightmare). Teleportation braziers throughout the crypts: Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) or Tech-Use (Hard -20) to activate, WP (Challenging +0) or 1d5 CP per use. Seven braziers connect: crypt entrance, study, Heart chamber, courtyard, north tower, chapel, and coffin chamber.

GM Notes: The crypts are a dungeon within a dungeon. They should be explored methodically, not rushed — each crypt tells a story. Sergei's crypt is the emotional core: save it for a dramatic moment. Ireena's empty tomb should silence the table. The Chained Daemon is the crypts' moral dilemma — genuine, useful intelligence at genuine spiritual cost. Ludmilla (Crypt 7) is a deliberate betrayal to punish trust — after the daemon offered truth, Ludmilla offers lies. Vary the rhythm: quiet horror, then combat, then moral choice, then quiet horror again.

Heart Chamber

RiskCatastrophic
TypeCombat, Skill Challenge, Environmental

Enemies: The Heart of the Spire — a crystallised warp entity, 1m across, pulsing arterial red, suspended in warp-lightning at the chamber's centre. Guarded by 2 Warp Stalkers (lesser Slaaneshi daemons, chained to the chamber walls, freed when anyone enters without Strahd's permission). Heart profile: Armour 8 (warp-infused crystal), SI 50, Immune to non-physical damage, half damage from energy weapons, full damage from Sanctified/Holy/faith-powered weapons, DOUBLE damage from Dawn's Edge. While the Heart exists: Strahd benefits from Regeneration (5) — heals 5 Wounds per turn. The chamber contains 5 conduits connecting the Heart to the Spire's power grid. Each conduit destroyed (S 30+ hit) reduces Regeneration by 2. Scaling: For 3, reduce to 1 Warp Stalker and SI to 40. For 6+, add 1 Warp Stalker and increase SI to 60.

Skill Challenge: Tech-Use (Very Hard -30) to sever the Heart's connection to the Spire's power grid, reducing SI by 15. Psyniscience (Hard -20) to identify the optimal conduit destruction sequence (most efficient order, reducing Regeneration fastest). The 5-conduit mechanic rewards tactical play over brute force.

Environmental: The Heart pulses raw warp energy — Willpower (Hard -20) each round or 1 CP + 1d5 IP. Three successive warded doors guard the approach: each requires Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Challenging +0) or Security (Challenging +0) to open (or Armour 10, SI 35 per door). The wards inflict 2d10 E (Pen 5, ignoring non-psychic armour) to any warp-touched entity passing through — warp-thralls and servitors CANNOT follow the Acolytes here.

Corruption/Insanity: 3 CP per round in the chamber. 1d10 IP on first seeing the Heart — it is alive, it is screaming, it has been screaming for 300 years. Destroying it: everyone tests Willpower (Very Hard -30) or gains 1d10 CP + 1d10 IP as the warp rushes in. Strahd screams (1d5 IP, no save, castle-wide). The chamber becomes unstable — 15% chance per round of wall collapse (2d10+5 E from warp exposure within 5m). Approximately 10 rounds before the chamber is unsurvivable.

GM Notes: Destroying the Heart is one of three conditions for killing Strahd. Without it, he regenerates indefinitely. The Heart should feel like a living thing in pain — this is horror, not a health bar. Describe the rhythmic pulsing that matches the Acolytes' heartbeats, the screaming that has echoed for centuries, the way the crystal weeps luminous tears of warp-stuff. Post-destruction: the entire Spire shakes, Strahd becomes Frenzied and moves immediately toward this chamber, warp-touched creatures are Stunned 1d5 rounds, and Navigation tests worsen by -10. The Acolytes should feel the castle dying around them.

Strahd's Coffin

RiskDeadly
TypeCombat, Investigation

Investigation: The deepest crypt, behind a false wall marked with the von Zarovich crest. Navigate (Very Hard -30) or Search (Hard -20) to find without guidance. Queen Ravenovia's spirit provides directions (+20). The partial Spire map from Van Richten's data-slate provides +10. The coffin: masterwork dark wood and adamantium banding, crimson silk lining, hexagrammic wards of preservation. Radiates a faint psychic pulse like vast, sleeping breath.

Investigation — Destroying the Coffin: Armour 8, immune to warp and psychic damage. Requires 30 damage to destroy, OR the Rosette of Saint Markovia held against it for 3 consecutive rounds (WP (Challenging +0) each round to maintain contact as the coffin shrieks and lashes out: 1d10+3 E, Pen 4 to the bearer per round). Takes double damage from Sanctified weapons. Alternatively, sanctification ritual: Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Very Hard -30) + 3 rounds of consecration while the coffin is exposed to the Rosette or Dawn's Edge. Sanctification does not destroy the coffin but renders it useless — Strahd can no longer regenerate within it.

Enemies: 6 Warp-Thralls standing guard (WS 40, BS 30, S 40 USx2, T 35, Ag 35, 18 Wounds, AP Body 3/Other 1, lasguns + warp-fangs: 1d10+4 R Pen 2 Tearing, bite drains 1 Fatigue on failed Toughness (Challenging +0), Fear 1, Regeneration 1 within Spire). If Strahd is aware of the intrusion, he arrives within 2d10 rounds via teleportation brazier. If the final confrontation occurs here: Strahd at full profile — WS 65, BS 55, S 55 USx2, T 50 UTx2 (+4 if Heart intact), Ag 60, WP 70, 80 Wounds, Psy Rating 5, Fear 3, Regeneration 1d10/round (if Heart intact), Phase, Stuff of Nightmares, AP 6 all. Armed with corrupted power sword (1d10+12 E Pen 7 Warp Weapon), bolt pistol with warp-tainted rounds (1d10+7 X Pen 5 Tearing Warp Weapon), and Drain touch (1d10+10 R Pen 2, heals Strahd equal to damage dealt on failed Toughness, Challenging +0).

Scaling: Strahd himself does not scale — he is a fixed threat. The environment scales: for 3, remove 2 warp-thrall guards. For 6+, Strahd summons 4 additional Warp-Thralls at 50% health. Three combat phases: Phase 1 (Lord-Governor, above 40 Wounds) — tactical duelist with lair actions; Phase 2 (Warp-Touched, below 40 Wounds) — mutations manifest, Fear 4, Psy Rating 7, Phase used aggressively, new lair actions (Warp-Fire, Walls Close, Floor of Madness); Phase 3 (Daemon Ascendant, below 10 Wounds with coffin destroyed) — optional, daemonic avatar, Fear 5, Psy Rating 9, Daemonic trait, Unnatural x3, BUT loses 5 Wounds per turn (built-in 8-round timer). Phase 3 does NOT occur if Ireena has sacrificed herself.

Corruption/Insanity: 5 CP from the final confrontation (unavoidable — the nexus of the warp rift, a 400-year-old monster fighting for its existence, and the raw power of a Daemon Prince pouring through the Spire). Additional CP/IP depend on combat phase, lair actions, and outcome. Witnessing Phase 3: WP (Hard -20) or 1d5 CP from the Daemon Prince's offers. Strahd's death: a moment of silence — the castle shakes, the rift responds, and the campaign's resolution begins.

GM Notes: This is the end. Strahd should fight with everything — lair actions, psychic powers, environmental manipulation, summoned minions. But he should also TALK. He has been waiting for this. He wants to know if they are worthy. In Phase 1, he is performing. In Phase 2, the mask is gone and the monster is revealed. In Phase 3 (if triggered), the Daemon Prince speaks through him — but at key moments (when struck by Dawn's Edge, when he sees Ireena, when an Acolyte speaks Sergei's name), Strahd himself surfaces: "Kill... me. Before it... takes everything." If the Acolytes have all three relics and the Heart is destroyed, he knows he can die — and part of him is relieved. The tragedy of Strahd is that he wants it to end but cannot stop fighting. Let the final moment breathe. When he falls, describe not fire and fury but quiet dissolution — ash, like the last ember of a fire that burned too long. Then the castle begins to shake.

Travel on Barovus

The roads of Barovus are not roads in any Imperial sense. They are suggestions, scratched into mud and gravel by centuries of cart tracks and desperate feet. They do not go where you expect. They do not take as long as they should. And they are never, ever safe.

There are no functional ground vehicles on Barovus. The promethium reserves ran dry generations ago, the machine spirits of the remaining transports long since fled or gone mad, and the warp-fog corrodes engine components with a thoroughness that would impress even a Mechanicus reclamation team. Travel is conducted on foot, by beast-drawn cart, or — for those fortunate or desperate enough to secure passage — aboard a Vostra caravan. Distances are measured in hours, not kilometres, because the warp-fog distorts spatial perception in ways that make cartography an exercise in futility. A road that took four hours yesterday may take six today and two tomorrow. The landscape does not change. Your perception of it does.

Travel between locations is measured in abstract travel segments. Each segment represents roughly four to six hours of movement on foot. The Game Master determines the number of segments between locations based on narrative pacing, but the route descriptions on the following page provide baseline distances. For each travel segment, the GM should: (1) describe the environment — the fog, the silence, the wrongness; (2) call for a Navigation Test; and (3) roll for Random Encounters (once per segment by day, twice by night).
