Navigation failure (2nd)Lost in the Mists — see Encounter Guide

The Day/Night Cycle

Time matters on Barovus. The world's sun — if it can even be called that through the perpetual haze — rises weakly and sets early. Days are grey and muted. Nights are absolute.

Daytime (approximately 10 hours): The fog is present but thinner. Warp phenomena are reduced. Most hostile creatures are dormant or weakened. Travel is merely dangerous.

Nighttime (approximately 14 hours): The fog thickens to near-opacity. Warp activity surges. All warp-touched creatures gain +10 to combat characteristics. Psychic powers are easier to manifest but harder to control (reduce Threshold by 1, but Psychic Phenomena occur on any doubles). The dead walk more freely. Strahd is at his most powerful.

The Witching Hour (approximately 02:00–04:00 local): The barriers between the materium and the immaterium are at their thinnest. All Corruption and Insanity Tests suffer -10. Psykers must pass a Willpower (Challenging +0) Test each hour or manifest uncontrolled minor phenomena. The fog occasionally parts, revealing brief glimpses of the true warp beyond — 1d5 IP for any who witness it without averting their eyes (Willpower (Hard -20) to look away in time).

The Vostra

Vostra caravans travel the roads regularly — convoys of 2d5 wagons, their void-shield-equipped transports humming through the fog like Imperial prayer-beads clicking through nervous fingers. They are the safest way to travel. Strahd's creatures avoid them, usually — a courtesy extended by the Lord-Governor himself, for reasons even the Vostra do not fully understand. Hiring Vostra escort requires a Commerce (Challenging +0) Test or a favour owed. They know every route and its dangers. They know which roads the wolves hunt at which hours. They know where the fog thickens and where it thins. They know these things because they have been walking these roads for three centuries, and they are still alive, which on Barovus is the highest credential anyone can offer.

Vostra safe passage negates one Random Encounter roll per travel segment and grants +20 to Navigate tests. The Vostra will not, however, escort the Acolytes to the Empyrean Vault, the Warp Nexus, or Berez. Some roads even the Vostra will not walk.

Strahd's Surveillance

Strahd is always aware of the Acolytes' location when they travel the roads. His surveillance network is comprehensive and layered: bat-servitors (aerial reconnaissance, nearly silent, equipped with pict-recorders), wolf-packs (ground-level tracking, psychically linked to Strahd's awareness), and informant villagers (every settlement has eyes that report to the Spire). Awareness (Hard -20) to detect surveillance. Evading it entirely is nearly impossible, but Stealth (Very Hard -30) allows 1d5 hours of unobserved travel — enough to make a detour, set an ambush, or reach a location without Strahd knowing the exact route taken.

The surveillance is not a punishment. It is theatre. Strahd wants the Acolytes to know they are watched. He wants them to feel the weight of his attention on their backs as they walk his roads. He wants them to understand that every step they take is taken because he permits it. The wolves that shadow the treeline, the servitor-skull that hovers just at the edge of visibility, the villager who watches from a window and then hurries inside — these are not threats. They are reminders. You are in my house. You walk my halls. And I am always, always watching.

Resupply on the Road

Travel consumes resources. Each Acolyte requires 1 ration pack per day of travel. Failure to eat results in 1 cumulative Fatigue per day without food. Water is generally available (Barovus has abundant, if foul-tasting, surface water), but purification is recommended — untreated water requires a Toughness (Routine +20) Test or causes 1 Fatigue from intestinal distress.

Ammunition expenditure during travel encounters should be tracked. The GM should remind players that every bolt round and lasgun charge pack spent on the road is one fewer available for the Spire. Scarcity is the campaign's silent antagonist — Strahd is patient, the warp is eternal, but the Acolytes' supplies are finite.

Route Descriptions

The following routes describe the major travel corridors between locations on Barovus. Each entry provides distance, terrain, hazards, and atmospheric detail. The GM should use these descriptions to narrate travel — not as scripts, but as frameworks for building tension, pacing encounters, and establishing the oppressive atmosphere that defines overworld movement on this cursed world.

1. Barovus to Fortress Vallak — The Main Road

Distance3 segments (~12–18 hours on foot)
TerrainManaged forest, cracked arterial road
Risk LevelTense — the most "maintained" route on the planet
NavigationNavigate (Ordinary +10) — road markers assist

The main arterial road between the Village of Barovus and Fortress Vallak is the closest thing to a highway that exists on this world. It was once a proper Imperial transit corridor — six metres wide, surfaced with rockcrete, bordered by drainage channels and illuminated by solar-charged lumen-posts. Three centuries of neglect have reduced it to a cracked, root-buckled path through dense, grey forest, but its bones remain visible. The drainage channels are clogged with leaf-mould and something that might be organic. The lumen-posts stand at intervals like the skeletons of sentries, their solar cells dead, their housings colonised by pale fungal growths that glow faintly at night.

Road markers appear every kilometre — stone pillars bearing distance measurements, directional arrows, and prayer inscriptions in faded High Gothic. Some are intact. Some have been defaced — scratched over with crude symbols, smeared with substances best left unidentified, or simply toppled. Each marker bears a prayer: the first, near Barovus, reads "The Emperor Protects." The prayers become more desperate as the journey progresses. By the halfway point, they read "The Emperor Watches" and "The Emperor Remembers." The final marker before Fortress Vallak reads: "HOPE IS A LIE. ENDURE."

Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Ordinary +10) to identify the prayer sequence as a degraded form of the Litany of Endurance — a prayer specifically composed for soldiers on garrison duty in hostile environments. Whoever carved these markers was trained by the Ministorum, and they were losing faith in real time.

The warp-fog varies along this route from light (no effect, visibility adequate) to thick (visibility 10m, -20 Perception, +1 CP per hour of exposure). There is no predicting the density — it shifts without cause, thickening in hollows and thinning on rises, sometimes parting entirely to reveal a sky the colour of a bruise before closing again like a wound sealing.

2. Fortress Vallak to Krezk — The Mountain Road

Distance2 segments (~8–12 hours on foot)
TerrainAscending mountain road, exposed switchbacks
Risk LevelDangerous — exposure, cold, predators at altitude
NavigationNavigate (Challenging +0) — road forks, dead ends

The mountain road to Krezk climbs steadily from the moment it leaves Fortress Vallak's western gate. The first hour is deceptive — gentle inclines through thinning forest, the road still recognisable as an Imperial construction, guard posts visible at intervals (all abandoned, some burned, one containing a skeleton in PDF uniform still seated at its desk with a half-written report crumbling in its fingers). Then the treeline ends, and the road becomes something else entirely.

Above the treeline, the wind strips away all pretence of shelter. The temperature drops markedly — after hour 3, Toughness (Challenging +0) per hour or suffer 1d10 E damage (cold, reduced by cold-weather gear). The road narrows to switchbacks carved into the mountainside, with sheer drops on one side and unstable rock faces on the other. Visibility decreases as altitude increases — the warp-fog is thinner here but replaced by mountain cloud and driving sleet. The road forks multiple times; some forks lead to dead ends, others to cliff edges. Navigate (Challenging +0) at each fork or waste 1d5 hours on a wrong turn. Survival (Hard -20) to find emergency shelter if weather turns violent.

Warp-wolves hunt above the treeline — 50% chance of a pack encounter per hour after hour 4. The wolves at altitude are leaner, faster, and more desperate than their lowland cousins. The views, when the cloud parts, are extraordinary: the entire domain of Barovus spread below, the warp-fog visible as a solid boundary at the world's edge — a wall of writhing, luminescent mist that extends from ground level to the upper atmosphere, enclosing everything. From this altitude, the prison is visible. The sight costs 1 IP the first time it is witnessed.

3. Fortress Vallak to the Recaf Distillery — The Vineyard Road

Distance1 segment (~3–4 hours on foot)
TerrainCultivated lowland, vineyard terraces
Risk LevelTranquil/Tense — the safest route on Barovus
NavigationNavigate (Routine +20) — well-trodden, marked

The Vineyard Road is an anomaly. It is short, relatively well-maintained, and frequented by Vostra caravans hauling recaf and supplies between the distillery and Fortress Vallak. The road passes through what were once extensive recaf vineyards — hectares of terraced hillside that still produce a thin, bitter crop tended by frightened farmers who emerge at dawn and retreat behind locked doors well before dusk. The fields are not healthy — the soil is warp-tainted, the plants grow in colours that are not quite right — but they grow. On Barovus, that qualifies as a miracle.

Survival (Ordinary +10) reveals something curious: the recaf plants seem to purify the soil around them. Patches of earth near the plants are measurably less warp-saturated than the surrounding ground. Forbidden Lore (Warp) (Hard -20) or Psyniscience (Challenging +0) confirms it — the sacred seeds in the distillery's vault radiate a subtle anti-corruption field that extends across the vineyard. This is why the road feels different. This is why the fog is thinner here. This is why, for three blessed hours, the Acolytes might almost feel safe.

Something should feel wrong about how safe it is. The GM should play this road as a reprieve — but an unsettling one. The farmers wave but do not speak. The Vostra caravans pass with nods and half-smiles. The warp-wolves do not howl here. The silence is not the silence of danger but the silence of a held breath, as if the entire road is aware that its safety exists at someone's pleasure, and that pleasure could be revoked at any moment.

4. Fortress Vallak to Berez — The Swamp Tracks

Distance2 segments (~8–12 hours on foot)
TerrainDegrading road to swamp, then trackless marsh
Risk LevelDangerous — environmental attrition, navigation essential
NavigationNavigate (Hard -20) after the road ends

The road to Berez begins as a road and ends as a memory. The first hour follows a secondary Imperial track — narrow, poorly maintained, but passable. By hour 2, the track has softened to mud. By hour 3, the mud has become standing water. By hour 4, the road is gone entirely, swallowed by the swamp that was once the River Berez's flood plain and is now a permanent toxic marshland created by Strahd's psychic rage two centuries past.

After the road ends: knee-deep water, Agility (Challenging +0, -10 for heavy armour) each hour or fall prone. Leeches: Toughness (Ordinary +10) or 1d5 R damage (blood drain) per hour. Toxic fumes after hour 4: Toughness (Hard -20) or 1 Fatigue (rebreathers negate this). Navigate (Hard -20) required every hour — failure means 1d5 hours lost circling through identical-looking reed beds and half-submerged ruins. Critical failure leads into quicksand: Athletics (Hard -20) to escape or sink — suffocation after 3 rounds.

Nobody travels to Berez willingly. The locals speak of it in whispers, if they speak of it at all. The Vostra refuse to guide anyone there — not for any price, not for any favour. The swamp is not merely dangerous. It is grieving. It is the grave of an entire community drowned by a lovesick monster, and the water remembers. At night, the phosphorescent glow of warp-saturated water illuminates the underside of the fog, and shapes wade through the shallows — plague revenants that were once the villagers of Berez, still walking their drowned streets, still trying to go home.

5. To the Empyrean Vault — The Mountain Passes

Distance4 segments (~16–24 hours from Krezk)
TerrainHigh altitude mountain passes, lethal cold
Risk LevelDeadly — the most dangerous non-combat route on Barovus
NavigationNavigate (Very Hard -30), -10 without intelligence, +20 if Kasimir guides

The mountain passes leading to the Empyrean Vault are not a road. They are a gauntlet. The route climbs beyond the Krezk plateau into the high peaks where the air thins, the cold intensifies past the point of mere discomfort into genuine lethality, and the warp bleeds through the weakened veil with increasing ferocity. This is a survival expedition, not a journey. Supply management, Fatigue tracking, and cold damage create genuine attrition before the Acolytes reach their destination.

Above 3000m: lethal cold. Toughness (Hard -20) per hour or suffer 1d10 E damage (cold, reduced by cold-weather gear). Blizzards (30% chance per hour): visibility 5m, -30 to everything, Navigate (Very Hard -30) or lost at altitude — being lost here means Toughness (Hard -20) per hour or 2d10 E damage. Survival (Hard -20) to establish camp safely. Tech-Use (Challenging +0) to maintain vox contact with base (the altitude and warp interference degrade signals rapidly). 2 CP per hour above 3000m — the immaterium bleeds through more easily at altitude, where the barrier between realspace and the warp grows thin as the air itself.

The passes are also patrolled by degraded xenos constructs — Vault Guardians still functioning on ancient power cells, their original purpose (containment enforcement) long since corrupted into simple territorial aggression. They fire on anything that moves. Their las-weapons are archaic but functional, and their force-field generators still flicker intermittently. The Acolytes should not attempt this route unprepared. Adequate cold-weather gear, sufficient rations (minimum 3 days' supply), and ideally a guide (Kasimir provides +20 to Navigate) are essential. Without preparation, the mountain passes will kill the party before the Vault's inhabitants get the chance.

6. To the Warp Nexus — Cross-Country

Distance1 segment from the Distillery, 2 from Vallak (~4–8 hours)
TerrainCorrupted woodland, hills, no path
Risk LevelDangerous — warp corruption intensifies as you approach
NavigationNavigate (Challenging +0) required, no road

There is no road to the Warp Nexus. There never was. The xenos standing stones predate human settlement on Barovus by millennia, and no sane Imperial planner would build a road to a site of concentrated warp energy. The route is cross-country — through forest that grows increasingly wrong as the Nexus approaches. The trees lean toward the stones. Their bark is grey and smooth, like skin. Their branches move without wind. The undergrowth rustles with things that are not animals.

Navigation is required every hour — the landscape shifts subtly, and compass readings become unreliable within 2 kilometres of the stones (the warp energy interferes with magnetic instruments). Psyniscience becomes increasingly useful as the Nexus approaches — the psychic resonance grows from a whisper to a roar, and a psyker can follow it like a beacon. Non-psykers must rely on landmarks, and the landmarks have a tendency to move. 1 CP per hour of travel in the corrupted woodland. The warp-fog here is not passive — it reaches, tugs, and whispers. It knows your name.

7. To the Fallen Astartes Outpost — The Overgrown Road

Distance2 segments (~8–12 hours from Fortress Vallak)
TerrainSecondary Imperial road, heavily overgrown
Risk LevelTense, escalating to Dangerous — increasingly haunted
NavigationNavigate (Challenging +0) — road exists but is obscured

A secondary Imperial road once connected Fortress Vallak to the Silver Drakes' forward observation post. It was a military road — wider than necessary, reinforced for heavy vehicle traffic, with defensive positions built into the verges at regular intervals. The Silver Drakes are centuries gone, and their road has been reclaimed by the forest with a thoroughness that suggests intent rather than neglect. Trees have grown through the rockcrete surface. Roots have lifted entire slabs. The defensive positions are overgrown mounds, barely recognisable as foxholes and gun emplacements.

The road has an atmosphere that is distinct from any other route on Barovus. It is not the oppressive dread of the main road, nor the hostile corruption of the Nexus approach. It is sorrow. A heavy, pervasive melancholy that settles on the chest and thickens with every step. Psyniscience (Ordinary +10) identifies it as psychic residue — the emotional imprint of a Chapter that knew it was dying and kept fighting anyway. Willpower (Ordinary +10) per hour or suffer 1 IP from the weight of accumulated grief. As the outpost approaches, Acolytes may hear fragments of vox-transmissions — ghost signals on frequencies that the Silver Drakes used centuries ago. The transmissions are not recordings. They are echoes. The dead Astartes are still broadcasting, still reporting, still holding the line in whatever afterlife the warp has trapped them in.

8. To Zarovich Spire — The Spire Road

Distance1 segment (~3–4 hours from Fortress Vallak)
TerrainWell-maintained Imperial road, ascending
Risk LevelTranquil (physically) / Catastrophic (psychologically)
NavigationNone required — the road is unmistakable

The Spire Road is the only well-maintained route on Barovus, and it is maintained by Strahd's own servitors — mechanical constructs that emerge at night to fill potholes, clear debris, and replace the road's distinctive illumination: skull-lanterns. Every fifty metres, a human skull mounted on a wrought-iron post, its eye sockets fitted with perpetual-glow lumen beads that cast a cold blue light across the road's surface. The skulls are real. The light they cast is adequate. The effect is exactly as intimidating as Strahd intends.

Nothing attacks on the Spire Road. Not wolves, not mutants, not plague revenants, not daemons. Nothing. The Random Encounter Table is suspended entirely on this route. This is Strahd's road, and his authority here is absolute. The creatures of Barovus understand this instinctively — they do not hunt on the Spire Road because to do so would be to challenge the Lord-Governor's sovereignty, and nothing on this world is that foolish.

The safety is the horror. The Acolytes walk for three hours on a perfect road, well-lit, unmolested, through a world that has tried to kill them every other moment of every other day — and the reason they are safe is that a monster has claimed this path as his own. The road ascends steadily toward the Spire, which is visible from the moment of departure: a black needle against the grey sky, growing larger with each step, its silhouette wrong in ways that become apparent only gradually (the towers are too tall, the angles are too sharp, the structure defies architectural logic in a manner that suggests warp-influence on the construction itself).

The psychological toll is the point. Willpower (Challenging +0) upon reaching the Spire gates or gain 1d5 IP — not from danger, but from the dawning realisation that you have walked willingly into the lair of the most powerful entity on the planet, along a road he built specifically for this purpose, and he has been watching you approach for three hours without lifting a finger to stop you because he wants you here.

Encounter Guide

The roads of Barovus are not transit corridors — they are hunting grounds, psychological warfare zones, and slow-acting environmental hazards. This encounter guide covers the eight major encounter areas that the Game Master should deploy during overworld travel. These areas are not tied to specific map locations but to travel conditions: the type of road, the time of day, the density of the fog, and the whims of the Lord-Governor. Use them to fill travel segments with tension, discovery, and the grinding attrition that defines movement across this cursed world.

Main Road (Barovus to Vallak)

RiskTense
TypeEnvironmental, Discovery

Environmental: Warp-fog density varies along the main road. Roll 1d10 per travel segment: 1–3 light fog (no mechanical effect, visibility adequate), 4–6 medium fog (-10 to Perception tests, visibility 30m), 7–9 thick fog (-20 to Perception tests, +1 CP per hour, visibility 10m), 10 impenetrable fog (lost — trigger "Lost in the Mists," see Area 7 below). The fog does not transition gradually. It thickens in an instant, as though a door has closed. One moment the road stretches ahead, grey and miserable but visible. The next, the Acolyte in front of you is a silhouette, and the one behind you is gone.

Discovery: Road markers appear every kilometre — stone pillars with distance measurements, directional arrows, and prayer inscriptions in faded High Gothic. One marker per hour of travel. Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Ordinary +10) to read the prayers. The sequence tells a story: faith degrading in real time, carved into stone by Ministorum-trained hands that were losing their grip on belief. The first marker near Barovus reads "The Emperor Protects." Subsequent markers: "The Emperor Watches." "The Emperor Remembers." "The Emperor Endures." "Endure." "Endure." "HOPE IS A LIE. ENDURE." The final marker before Fortress Vallak has been defaced — the prayer scratched out and replaced with a single word in a different hand: "RUN."

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour in thick fog. 1 IP from reading the complete prayer sequence — watching faith die one stone pillar at a time.

GM Notes: Set the tone for all travel with this route. The main road is the most-used corridor in the campaign and should never feel routine. Vary the fog density, use the road markers as environmental storytelling, and remember that the road is haunted not by specific entities but by atmosphere. The silence between encounters is the encounter. Every crackle of static on the vox, every shape half-seen in the fog, every moment the Acolytes spend wondering if the shadow ahead is a tree or something else — that is the road doing its work.

Mountain Road (Vallak to Krezk)

RiskDangerous
TypeEnvironmental, Skill Challenge

Environmental: Ascending altitude with real mechanical consequences. After hour 3: Toughness (Challenging +0) per hour or suffer 1d10 E damage (cold, reduced by cold-weather gear). Visibility decreases with altitude. Wind increases — ranged attacks at -10 above the treeline, -20 during gusts. Switchbacks and exposed cliff-edge paths: Agility (Challenging +0) during high wind or risk being blown toward a drop (a second Agility (Hard -20) Test to catch oneself, or 3d10+5 I damage from a fall). The guard posts at intervals are empty shells — abandoned decades or centuries ago, their doors hanging open, their interiors stripped of anything useful.

Skill Challenge: Navigate (Challenging +0) at each fork in the road — the route splits multiple times, and the signage is gone. Some forks lead to dead ends against cliff faces. Some lead to precipices that drop into fog. One fork leads to an abandoned guard post containing a single, intact vox-unit that plays a looping recording: a PDF sergeant's voice, calm and professional, reporting that all roads to Krezk are closed due to "environmental hazard" — a recording three centuries old, still playing to an audience of nobody. Survival (Hard -20) to locate emergency shelter if weather turns severe — a cave, an overhang, a guard post with enough roof remaining to block the wind.

Enemies: Warp-wolf pack (50% chance per hour after hour 4). 4 Warp-Wolves — use Warp-Mutant profile with +10 Ag and Pack Tactics (wolves that successfully hit the same target in the same round inflict an additional 1d10 R damage from coordinated tearing). The wolves at altitude are desperate — they do not break off when wounded. They fight to the death or until every wolf is down. Scaling: For 3 Acolytes, reduce to 3 wolves. For 6+, add 2 wolves and a pack alpha (double Wounds, Fear 1).

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour above the treeline (warp exposure at altitude — the barrier thins where the air thins). 1 IP from the first clear view of the warp-fog boundary — the prison walls of Barovus, visible and absolute.

GM Notes: The mountain road is an attrition encounter. Cold damage, Fatigue, and wolf attacks grind the party down before they ever reach Krezk. The guard posts should feel like archaeological evidence of a functional Imperial world that no longer exists — each one a snapshot of normalcy preserved in decay. The vox recording in the dead-end guard post is a particular gut-punch: a man doing his duty, reporting to command, unaware that command stopped listening three centuries ago. Let the players sit with that.

Vineyard Road (Vallak to Distillery)

RiskTranquil/Tense
TypeSocial, Discovery

Social: Vostra caravans (50% chance of encounter on this route). They are friendly here — this is their territory, their supply line, and they are comfortable. They share news from Fortress Vallak and the distillery, trade supplies at fair-ish prices, and offer escort for the final stretch. Charm (Ordinary +10) to establish genuine rapport — the Vostra on the Vineyard Road are less guarded than those encountered elsewhere, more willing to gossip, more likely to share a flask of recaf and a story. They know things. They always know things.

Discovery: The cultivated fields flanking the road are barely functional but stubbornly alive. Terrified farmers tend thin recaf crops in fields that should not support growth. Survival (Ordinary +10) reveals the anomaly: the soil near the recaf plants is measurably less warp-saturated than the surrounding earth. The plants are purifying the ground. Psyniscience (Challenging +0) confirms a faint anti-corruption field radiating from the direction of the distillery — the sacred seeds' influence, extending across the vineyard like a blessing soaked into the earth.

Corruption/Insanity: No CP on this route under normal conditions — the sacred seeds' influence provides a buffer. This is the only route on Barovus where this is true. 0 IP unless something disrupts the journey.

GM Notes: The safest road in the campaign. Use it for social encounters, resupply, and a false sense of security. The absence of danger is itself unsettling — after days of constant threat, three hours of peace should feel wrong. Something should feel wrong about how safe it is. The farmers wave but do not speak. The Vostra are friendly but leave before dusk. The wolves do not howl here. The silence is not threatening — it is held, like a breath, like a courtesy extended by someone who could revoke it. Because someone could. Because someone is watching the Vineyard Road too, and the reason it is safe is not that Strahd cannot reach it. It is that Strahd has chosen not to.

Swamp Tracks (Vallak to Berez)

RiskDangerous
TypeEnvironmental, Skill Challenge

Environmental: The road degrades from track to marsh across three distinct phases. Phase 1 (Hours 1–2): Deteriorating road — mud, standing water in ruts, increasingly poor footing. Manageable. Phase 2 (Hours 3–4): Knee-deep water. Agility (Challenging +0, -10 for heavy armour) each hour or fall prone in sucking mud. Leeches: Toughness (Ordinary +10) or 1d5 R damage (blood drain) per hour — the leeches are not warp-touched, merely enormous. Phase 3 (Hours 5+): Deep swamp. Toxic fumes: Toughness (Hard -20) per hour or 1 Fatigue (rebreathers negate). Visibility 15m. The water glows faintly phosphorescent green — warp residue from the catastrophe that created the swamp. Things move in the water. Not all of them are revenants.

Skill Challenge: Navigate (Hard -20) required every hour after the road ends. Failure: 1d5 hours lost circling through identical reed beds and half-submerged ruins. The landscape repeats — the same broken wall, the same leaning watchtower, the same half-submerged ground-car skeleton. Willpower (Challenging +0) to recognise this as warp-spatial distortion rather than genuine disorientation. Critical Navigate failure: led into quicksand — Athletics (Hard -20) to escape or sink. Sinking means suffocation after 3 rounds. Companions can assist: Strength (Challenging +0) with a rope or improvised aid.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour in the swamp (the water is warp-saturated — the catastrophe soaked corruption into the groundwater permanently). 1 IP upon first encountering the phosphorescent glow — light should not come from beneath you, and the things silhouetted by that light should not have human shapes.

GM Notes: The swamp tracks are designed to exhaust the party before they reach Berez proper. Fatigue from toxic fumes, damage from leeches and cold water, and the constant drain of Navigation tests and CP accumulation create a war of attrition that mirrors the setting's themes. Nobody comes to Berez prepared enough. The swamp ensures it. Remind the players that turning back is always an option — and that the swamp is equally dangerous in both directions.

Mountain Passes (to the Empyrean Vault)

RiskDeadly
TypeEnvironmental, Skill Challenge

Environmental: Lethal cold above 3000m. Toughness (Hard -20) per hour or suffer 1d10 E damage (cold, reduced by cold-weather gear — without gear, this damage is unavoidable and cumulative). Blizzards (30% chance per hour): visibility 5m, -30 to all tests, Navigate (Very Hard -30) or lost at altitude. Being lost above 3000m: Toughness (Hard -20) per hour or 2d10 E damage as wind chill and exposure strip heat from the body faster than the body can produce it. The cold is not natural — it is the cold of absence, as though heat itself has been consumed by something vast and hungry and patient.

Skill Challenge: Navigate (Very Hard -30) to find the Vault entrance. Modifiers: -10 without prior intelligence about the location, +20 if Kasimir guides (he has studied the approach for decades). Survival (Hard -20) to establish camp safely — finding shelter above the treeline requires either luck or skill, and failing means sleeping exposed, which means another Toughness test against cold damage. Tech-Use (Challenging +0) to maintain vox contact with base — the altitude, atmospheric interference, and warp energy degrade signals to static within hours.

Enemies: Vault Guardians — degraded xenos constructs still patrolling on ancient power cells. Use modified Combat Servitor profiles with archaic las-weapons and intermittent force-field generators (Protection Rating 30, but flickering — 50% chance of function per hit). They fire on anything that moves. They do not communicate. They do not negotiate. They are machines following orders given by a civilisation that died before humanity learned to use fire.

Corruption/Insanity: 2 CP per hour above 3000m. The warp bleeds through at altitude — the barrier between realspace and the immaterium is gossamer-thin here, and the whispers of bound entities in the Vault below can be heard as faint, persuasive murmurs on the wind. 1d5 IP from extended exposure (4+ hours) to the whispers — they are not random noise, they are tailored, addressing each Acolyte's specific fears and desires. Willpower (Hard -20) to recognise them as external rather than internal thoughts.

GM Notes: The mountain passes should feel like a survival expedition — a genre shift from gothic horror to arctic survival thriller. Supply management becomes critical: rations, cold-weather gear, stimms to fight Fatigue, medikits for cold damage. The passes are designed to make the Acolytes spend resources before they reach the Vault, ensuring they arrive depleted. This is intentional — the Vault's temptations are harder to resist when you are cold, tired, wounded, and desperate. Kasimir as a guide is nearly essential; without him, the Navigation tests are brutal. If the party insists on going alone, let them. The mountain will teach them.

The Black Carriage

RiskTense
TypeSocial, Environmental

Social: Random event — 10% chance per road journey (roll once per complete trip between locations, not per segment). Strahd's personal transport materialises from the warp-fog: an ornate, antigrav groundcar of archaic design, jet black with silver filigree bearing the Zarovich crest, drawn by two massive augmetic horses with glowing red optical sensors. It glides silently out of the fog and stops before the party. The door opens. Inside: velvet-lined interior, temperature-controlled, comfortable in a way that nothing on Barovus is comfortable. A handwritten invitation on parchment rests on the seat, penned in Strahd's precise, elegant script.

If accepted: the Acolyte (or Acolytes) are transported directly and instantly to the Zarovich Spire. Strahd receives them for dinner — courteous, erudite, terrifying in his hospitality. This is almost certainly a trap, but it is also the fastest route to the final confrontation, and the intelligence gathered at Strahd's table can be invaluable. If refused: the carriage follows the party for 1d5 hours before vanishing back into the fog, its augmetic horses keeping perfect pace, the open door a constant invitation at the edge of peripheral vision.

Environmental: While the carriage follows: Willpower (Challenging +0) each hour or gain 1 CP — not from warp exposure, but from the compulsion to turn back and enter. The pull is not magical. It is psychological. The carriage represents warmth, safety, answers, an end to walking. The corruption comes from wanting those things badly enough to accept them from Strahd. While the carriage is present, all random encounters are suppressed — nothing attacks. Nothing approaches. The wolves retreat, the revenants sink beneath the water, the fog parts around the carriage's path. Strahd is demonstrating something: the danger on the roads exists because he allows it.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour of carriage proximity. Accepting the ride: 2 CP (willing entry into Strahd's domain, on his terms, at his invitation — a moral compromise regardless of tactical justification). 1d5 IP from the dinner itself (Strahd's psychic presence at close range, sustained, for hours).

GM Notes: The Black Carriage is pure theatre. It is Strahd saying: "I can reach you anywhere, at any time, and offer you everything you need, and all it costs is your dignity." The suppressed encounters are the real message — not that Strahd protects the Acolytes, but that the road's dangers are his to command. He turns them off like a light switch. The dinner, if accepted, should be roleplayed in full — Strahd is charming, attentive, and genuinely interested in the Acolytes. He shares real intelligence. He asks thoughtful questions. He is the best host the Acolytes have ever met, and that is the horror. Reference Interrogator Vasek's confession from Berez: "He went to dinner. And when he came back, he said we should study it further."

Lost in the Mists

RiskCatastrophic
TypeEnvironmental, Faith Test

Environmental: Triggered by: critical Navigate failure, impenetrable warp-fog (1d10 roll of 10 on the main road), or Strahd's direct intervention (he can push the Acolytes into the mists as punishment or amusement). The party is lost — not delayed, not off-course, but lost in the warp-fog of Barovus, where direction is meaningless and time is negotiable.

Time dilates. What feels like hours may be days. What feels like days may be minutes. Clocks disagree with each other. The sun does not move. The fog is not passive — it has intent, or something very like it. Navigate tests are meaningless inside the mists; the fog does not respond to skill, only to will. Reality degrades progressively: sounds from nowhere (footsteps behind that stop when you stop, voices calling names the Acolytes have not spoken aloud), shapes in the fog (humanoid, always at the edge of visibility, always moving away), and whispers of dead friends (if any Acolytes have died during the campaign, they hear those voices — warm, concerned, asking them to follow).

Faith Test: Escape requires a Willpower (Very Hard -30) group test — one success is sufficient. Prayer adds +10 (the Emperor's light is dim on Barovus but it is not gone, and the mists are not yet strong enough to silence it entirely). Litany of Protection adds +20 but must be recited correctly: Scholastic Lore (Imperial Creed) (Challenging +0) under extreme duress. On failure: 1d10 CP + 1d10 IP, and the party emerges 1d5 days later at a random location (roll 1d8: 1 — Village of Barovus, 2 — Fortress Vallak outskirts, 3 — Vineyard Road, 4 — swamp edge near Berez, 5 — forest near Astartes Outpost, 6 — mountain foothills, 7 — Warp Nexus perimeter, 8 — base of the Spire Road). Rations consumed for lost days. On critical failure: one party member (randomly determined) experiences a temporal displacement — they live a fragment of Strahd's memory as though it were their own. They feel what he felt. They see through his eyes. They understand, for a brief and terrible moment, why he made his choices. 1d10 CP + 2d10 IP, but the displaced Acolyte gains a genuine clue about Strahd's weakness (GM's choice — the location of an artifact, a vulnerability in the Spire's defences, or a detail about the pact that can be exploited).

Corruption/Insanity: Minimum 1d5 CP from exposure to the raw warp-stuff of the mists. IP and additional CP from the experience as described above. Even a successful escape costs: the mists leave a residue on the soul that does not wash off.

GM Notes: "Lost in the Mists" is the ultimate environmental threat on Barovus. Use it sparingly — once or twice in the entire campaign, maximum. It should feel like the world itself has turned hostile, like the ground has opened beneath the Acolytes and dropped them into something that is not a place but a state. The escape mechanic is deliberately simple (one WP test, group, one success needed) because the point is the experience, not the puzzle. The mists are not a challenge to be solved. They are a horror to be survived. The temporal displacement on critical failure is the campaign's most aggressive narrative tool — use it to deliver crucial intelligence at maximum psychological cost. The Acolyte who lives Strahd's memory will never see him the same way again. That is the point.

Night Travel

RiskDangerous
TypeEnvironmental, Combat

Environmental: Barovus at night is active. The warp-fog thickens to near-opacity. All warp-touched creatures gain +10 to combat characteristics. The witching hour (02:00–04:00 local) is the apex: warp-fog at maximum density, all Perception tests at -20, Corruption and Insanity tests at -10, and things move at the edge of vision that are not wholly there — shapes that exist in the space between realspace and the immaterium, visible only in peripheral vision, gone when looked at directly. Willpower (Challenging +0) each hour of night travel or gain 1 IP — not from any specific horror, but from the sustained, grinding terror of walking through absolute darkness on a road you cannot see, surrounded by things you cannot identify, toward a destination you may never reach.

Combat: Encounter chance is doubled during night travel (roll twice per segment on the Random Encounter Table, add +20 to each roll). Most likely encounters during night travel — roll 1d10: 1–4 Warp-Wolf pack (4–6 wolves, +10 to all characteristics from nighttime bonus, glowing violet eyes visible before anything else), 5–7 Plague Revenants (2–4, shambling from the treeline or rising from roadside ditches where they lay dormant during the day), 8–9 Warp-Mutant stalker (a lone, intelligent mutant that has been tracking the party since dusk — Awareness (Hard -20) to detect before it strikes), 10 Strahd himself (observing from the fog, not attacking, his eyes the only thing visible — two points of cold light in the darkness, watching, always watching). Scaling: Standard per-encounter scaling applies. Night combat imposes -10 to BS (darkness) unless the Acolytes have illumination, which reveals their position to everything within line of sight.

Discovery: Night travel reveals things invisible by day. The standing stones of the Warp Nexus emit a visible warp-glow (pale violet, pulsing in rhythm with an unseen heartbeat) that can be seen from the main road on clear nights — a useful navigation aid and a deeply unsettling one. Ghost-lights appear in the forest: will-o-wisps of concentrated warp energy that bob and weave between the trees, leading toward either danger (50% — a revenant nest, a mutant den, a sinkhole) or discovery (50% — a supply cache, a hidden shrine, a lost data-slate). Willpower (Challenging +0) to resist following a ghost-light; Psyniscience (Hard -20) to determine its nature before following. Most critically, the true shape of the warp-fog boundary is visible at night — a solid wall of writhing, luminescent mist at the world's edge, stretching from ground to sky, casting its own sickly light across the landscape. It is not fog. It is a barrier. It is a cage. Seeing it clearly for the first time costs 1d5 IP.

Corruption/Insanity: 1 CP per hour of night travel (ambient warp exposure, heightened at night). 1 IP per combat encounter (violence in darkness, against things that should not exist, is qualitatively worse than the same violence by day). 1d5 IP from a clear view of the warp-fog boundary (first time only).

GM Notes: Night travel should be discouraged but never forbidden. Sometimes the party must travel at night — because a deadline demands it, because they are being pursued, because a quest objective requires it. When they do, make it memorable. The witching hour phenomena should escalate — do not front-load the horror. Start with silence and fog. Add sounds. Add shapes. Add the feeling of being watched. Add the certainty that something is pacing them just beyond the light. Build it layer by layer until the players are genuinely tense, and then — only then — spring the combat encounter. The silence afterward, when the bodies are cooling and the road stretches on into nothing, is the real horror. Let them walk in that silence. Let them hear their own breathing and the crunch of their boots and nothing else, for a very long time, before the next sound comes.
